PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MASON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 19 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support, or, if necessary, to initiate a Federal inquiry into South West Tasmania.

Your petitioners also call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for construction of dams in the South West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIBRAA

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 26 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Bipartisan concern exists in the Australian community over involvement of Australian military forces in the Middle East where those forces are not under United Nations auspices;
2. Concern is also evident about Australia's military capacity to provide those forces without weakening Australia's defence;
3. Sinai is not an area within Australia's sphere of influence; and,
4. Australian agricultural export markets may be adversely affected by Australian military participation in Sinai.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament does not ratify Australian military participation in the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force, unless that force is fully controlled by the United Nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SIDDONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 15 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of sales tax on items concerned with home building and contents, clothing, books, magazines and newspapers.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Parliament not to implement such legislation as will permit these increases in costs to become a further burden on home builders, families and children, or inhibit the purchase of news or information.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 1,284 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They value the immeasurable contribution to the cultural life of Sydney made over 23 years by the Ensemble Theatre through theatre performances and theatre training.
2. They completely oppose the withdrawal of funding to the Ensemble Theatre for 1982.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal Government will-
1. Restore funding to the Ensemble Theatre for 1982.

2. Make an immediate supplementary grant of $1,180,000 to the Australia Council to restore funding cuts to the eight drama companies whose funding has been totally withdrawn and those companies whose funding has been cut by up to 20%.
3. Reassess its policy on the funding of the performing arts through the Australia Council.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCLAREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 105 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, M.P., and the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, M.P.

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony, M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $15,005.

(2) That in 1970 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Nixon, M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $30,352 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 6.25% and that at 1.10.81 the amount of principal outstanding was $28,404.

(3) Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government immediately extend these most generous terms to the many thousands of young couples in South Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHIPP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 24 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to support, or, if necessary, to initiate a Federal Inquiry into South West Tasmania.

Your petitioners also call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate or allow funds to be raised for construction of dams in the South West of Tasmania but to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national asset and Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth-

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the national average male earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $200m into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Carrick (from 120 citizens), Harradine (from 240 citizens) and Lajovic (from 165 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshop provide the main source of access by citizens to Government information and publications.
That this information distribution is an essential prerequisite for a democratic system, and that all Government publications should be readily available to the community.

That control of the distribution of government publications is an essential service and should not be in the private sector where only high demand, and hence profitable publications will be carried, leading to a restriction on publications available to the community.
Our petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject outright any proposal to transfer the functions of the AGPS bookshops to the private sector.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Multicultural Television: Wollongong
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the electors and residents within the City of Wollongong (State of New South Wales) respectfully showeth that:
(1) despite promises from the Government Radio 2EA did not begin transmission in Wollongong until 1979
(2) Wollongong has one of the largest migrant population in Australia in that over half the population are born overseas or have one or more parent born overseas
(3) we cannot receive Channel O
(4) the cost of privately installing UHF aerials is prohibitive for many migrants in the City.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate use its powers to ensure that a repeater transmitter be opened in Wollongong on both UHF and VHF bands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate.

The humble petition of citizens in Victoria showeth that at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12th August, 1981:

'We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognising that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the shortage of staff members in the Department of Social Security has resulted in poor service to clients and delays in payment of benefits.
That the recent stand-downs of staff of the Department of Social Security have exacerbated the above situation and caused undue hardship to pensioners and beneficiaries.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) Staffing levels in the Department be increased to a level acceptable to staff members.
(2) The Government demonstrate its concern for clients by rescinding the stand-downs and allowing staff back to work with no loss of salary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:

downgrading a large number of official post offices; reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period; reducing the number of street posting boxes; delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices; downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to investigate downgrading or closure of Ballarat East Post Office places in jeopardy the existing postal and mail services to our community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission taking any action to downgrade the postal and mail services of our community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate expressses its grave concern at the continuing downturn in building approvals in South Australia as revealed in the Australian Bureau of Statistics Building Statistics Bulletin of September 1981, No. 8704.4:

(a) in the three months to September 1981 approvals for new dwellings in South Australia had slumped to a level of 28.6 per cent below that in the corresponding period of 1979 when there was a Labor Government in office; and
(b) actual numbers of dwellings approved in South Australia totalled 2,817 to September 1979 but only 2,011 to September 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to sessional order, I give notice that it is my intention, on the next day of sitting at giving notices of motion, to withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name and relating to the disallowance of the Money Lenders (Amendment) Ordinance 1981.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Electoral System, be appointed to inquire into and report upon all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament of the Commonwealth and matters related thereto, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing-
(a) public funding and disclosure of sources of funds;
(b) electoral advertising;
(c) franchise and registration of voters;
(d) voting systems;
(e) polling procedures;
(f) legislation governing, and operation of, the Australian Electoral Office;
(g) ballot paper format;
(h) media coverage; and
(i) electoral distribution, procedures and systems.
(2) That provisions relating to the composition and powers of the Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.
(3) That the date on which the Committee shall commence its inquiry be contained in a subsequent resolution.

(4) That, as soon as practicable after this resolution is agreed to by the Senate, the President shall authorise, and cause to be made, public advertisements advising of the establishment of the Committee and inviting submissions in relation to the matters referred to in paragraph (1) of this resolution, such submissions to be lodged with the Clerk of the Senate on or before 10 March 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Did the Treasurer say yesterday that the visit to Saudi Arabia by a senior Department of the Treasury official, Mr Des Moore, was simply to establish personal contact between the Treasury and a senior official 'of the monetary agency of a friendly country'? Did he say also that the visit was simply a courtesy call? If that is so, why was Cabinet informed of it and why did the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, tell the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs that details of Mr Moore's visit were being held 'very tightly'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — In response to a question on this matter yesterday, I said that the Treasurer had commented that Mr Moore, of the Treasury, will be stopping in Riyadh on his return to Australia from Switzerland in order to meet the Governor of the Saudia Arabian Monetary Agency, that the purpose of the meeting is to establish contact between an official of the Treasurer's Department and the monetary authority, and that it will be in just the same nature as other meetings which are held from time to time in established monetary centres around the world. The Treasurer made some comments yesterday on this matter. I have nothing to add to the comments that were made by the Treasurer or to the comments that I made on his behalf yesterday. As was stated, contact is to be made between the monetary authority and the Treasurer's Department. The visit will be in the nature of the usual contact that is made in this sort of circumstance. I have no comment to make on any matters which are the subject of Cabinet discussions.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Minister repeated my question very nicely, but the question is: Why did the Secretary to the Treasury, in a letter to the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, describe Mr Moore's visit as one which is being held very tightly; that is, secretly? Why is that discretion exercised in respect of this visit as distinct from all other visits made by Treasury officials?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think the nature of the questioning shows why the Secretary to the Treasury should have chosen to exercise some discretion. The fact that this line of questioning is being pursued about a normal contact that is to be made shows that he was probably wise in putting the matter to the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs in a very discreet way. In response to questions yesterday the Treasurer said that it was a normal contact that was to be made. He had no personal concern about it being publicly known that the contact was to be made. I think the line of questioning shows that there are people who wish to make something out of nothing.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, is asked in light of the grant of aid for humanitarian reasons to Poland by the Australian Government in recent days. Without in any way taking away from the humanitarian nature of that gesture, I ask the Minister: Will the Government consider giving to Poland favoured nation status in terms of trade and tariff with Australia to assist to stimulate the Polish economy and to go in some fundamental way towards meeting the problems in that country? Even if that status is not given, will the Government consider strengthening the Australian Trade Commissioner's representation in Poland? If the Government considers any favoured nation status, will it make a temporary arrangement for a specific period of, say, two years, to be reviewed at the end of that time and possibly terminated if the objective is met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of specific things were asked by Senator Martin. As I announced last week, the Minister for Foreign Affairs is visiting Poland at the invitation of the Polish Foreign Minister. He left Australia just a few days ago. Prior to going he said that he was looking forward to having discussions with the Foreign Minister and others in the Polish Government about a range of international and bilateral matters. He hoped that in the brief time available to him he would have contacts with Polish society and that, as a result of his visit, he would have a better understanding of developments within Poland.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the questions raised by Senator Martin could be encompassed by some of the discussions that the Minister might have. But I am not able to comment on the likely outcome of those discussions or on any decisions that might be taken by the Australian Government as a result of the visit. However, I am sure that as a result of the visit we will have a better understanding of what would be of assistance to Poland, in addition to the appeal fund which was opened by the Prime Minister last Sunday and to which the Australian Government contributed $1m. The visit is important because it is the first by an Australian Government Minister since 1975. It is also the first by a Foreign Minister from this country. As soon as I am able to refer the matters raised by Senator Martin to the Minister for Foreign Affairs I will see that she is advised of any response. If any general statement needs to be made it will be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the 1st Battalion Royal Australian Regiment Support Company based at Townsville is engaged in regular and intense riot control exercises with particular emphasis being given to the use of flexiglass shields, tear gas and batons. If this is a fact, will the Minister inform the Senate of the purpose of this specialist training and whether it has been ordered because of the recent statement by Mr Charles Perkins concerning the forthcoming Commonwealth Games to be held in Brisbane and the report yesterday that the Queensland Minister for Police, Russ Hinze, has received Cabinet approval for security legislation which could be put into use during the Games next year?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence and ask him to provide an early answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and it is about the activities of the Industrial Relations Bureau in Victoria. Is the Minister aware of claims by the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce that the Industrial Relations Bureau has been giving unwarranted attention to employers in the retail motor industry, that officers of the Bureau have been making frequent and unreasonable demands on these employers and that this has been the subject of some disputation with the Victorian Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau? Is the Minister aware of allegations about a business at Bayswater where a driver was dismissed for what appear to be legitimate reasons but the employer claims to have been continually subjected to interviews and inquiries by the Bureau at great expense to all parties? Has Victoria a higher ratio of complaints than other States? Has any investigation been carried out into the allegations and complaints of the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce and with what results?

—I am aware of claims by the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce because I think it sent the same letter to me as it sent to other honourable senators and honourable members which drew our attention to the complaints that it had received. I suppose the complaints are a reminder to the Senate and to the people of Australia of what was perhaps a little obscured in the original debate on the Industrial Relations Bureau and that was that the Bureau was intended not only to look at the behaviour of trade unions in the industrial area but also to look at the behaviour of employers. The complaint from the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce is that it has been over-enthusiastic in its concern about the behaviour of employers. The same letter, I think, has been sent to Mr Viner. I asked him what he was doing about the matter and he has advised me that he has referred the letter to the Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau and asked for a full and comprehensive report on the matters which have been raised. I do not know whether the matters raised with Mr Viner include the particular matter of the Bayswater case, raised by Senator Lewis, but I will refer that to Mr Viner and make sure that he also gets a report on that matter.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory and also the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction. It refers to a planned underground facility-I understand two floors underground-at the new Parliament House which has been referred to by a variety of names including Crisis Command Centre, Administrative Command Centre and Executive Policy Direction Facility.
—And Fraser's funk hole.

—I did not want to say that but the honourable senator has said it for me. Is it really a nuclear bunker to save people in the event of a nuclear catastrophe? Is the total floor space of this bunker 1800 square metres? Who would use this bunker in the event of a nuclear blast? Do plans include the Governor-General and members of families of senior Ministers who may be in Canberra? How long will these people be able to survive in the bunker under current plans? What sorts of facilities will be provided in the bunker? Will the centre have full facilities to protect the occupants against nuclear blast and fallout and to provide communications with civil defence authorities to co-ordinate the defence of Australia?

—I can confirm that the area involved and set aside, under the present plan, is about 1,800 square metres. Apart from that, however, very little information is available on the matter. I understand that in fact the specific requirements have not yet been determined. No doubt the specification will need to be awaited for further consideration of timing in relation to the actual building proposition. However, I would like to make the point that the area is not specifically related to nuclear disasters, as Senator Mason would have us believe. In fact, I understand that it would be best described as being a crisis centre, one which would handle not only--
—What kind of disasters would you have in mind?

—Natural ones. It would relate to matters such as natural disasters and/or other extended emergencies. As to the people who might be invited to visit the bunker from time to time-if 'bunker' is the word that Senator Mason would like us to use-I would perhaps be able to extend an invitation to him in the event of a nuclear disaster but I would need to refer to the Minister to obtain further information about who might be invited along with him.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer and his assurance that this underground bunker of 1,800 square metres is in the plans, how can he justify effectively what is to be a nuclear centre-let us not fool ourselves-for senior members of the government while persisting in a refusal to provide effective civil defence facilities for all other Australians?

—The point I was seeking to make was that it is not to be especially established, as I understand it, as a nuclear shelter. Rather it is designed to be a command centre in the event of natural disasters or any other kind of emergency that might arise in Australia. For that reason, while its eventual purpose and the equipment to be set up in it have not been specifically spelt out as yet, clearly it would be for that purpose and not narrowly for a nuclear fall-out shelter. Therefore Senator Mason's question in relation to the rest of Australia is covered by his addressing an appropriate question to the Minister for Defence about the whole area of civil defence.
—We have.

—I will certainly ask for a reply from the Minister for Defence in that regard. Might I again refer Senator Mason to the point that it is not specifically to be a nuclear fall-out shelter, something about which he appears to have a fixation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to claims made by the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region. The Supervising Scientist said this in his 1981 annual report:

QUESTION.PARA: The Northern Territory Authorities have been tardy in providing six-monthly reports to the Co-ordinating Committee and their content is inadequate to provide the material on which the Supervising Scientist could base a report upon the effectiveness of the Northern Territory's regulatory program.

Does the Minister agree that for the Government to evaluate the full impact of uranium projects on the community it must have access to adequate reports on the environmental effects of uranium mining? If so, will an investigation be made by the Government into the claims of the Supervising Scientist that the Northern Territory Government's reports are tardy and inadequate? What action will be taken by the Government to ensure that the monitoring and inspection programs used by the Northern Territory authorities are clearly defined and are complied with by companies mining in the Northern Territory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that Senator Missen asks this question in the context of events which have occurred in the last few days and in which it has been the Northern Territory Government--
—No, not in that context.

—Nevertheless, the context exists. The Northern Territory Government moved very decisively when it became aware of some breach of environmental conditions. The honourable senator asks about tardiness in presenting certain reports. I think he would also be concerned about the content of those reports and whether the content is adequate. Rather than have the Commonwealth Government initiate an investigation, I can report to the honourable senator that there has been some action. The Supervising Scientist has already had discussions with the Co-ordinator-General of the Northern Territory about the content and the format of the reports by the Northern Territory supervising authorities. In addition, the monitoring and inspection programs by which the Northern Territory supervising authorities will verify that the mining companies are complying with both Northern Territory and Commonwealth environmental requirements have been reviewed.

ANSWER.PARA: These matters were considered within the last week at the meeting of the Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region. The revised procedures were endorsed at that meeting. It remains now for the Northern Territory authorities to require the companies to monitor the report as agreed and to spell out the details of the check monitoring, that is, the inspections required and the reporting required. This will be carried out by the Northern Territory supervising authorities. I hope that any tardiness in providing these reports can be overcome quickly, as I agree with the honourable senator that reports which are timely and which contain appropriate content are essential to achieve the goals to which the honourable senator referred in his question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF TRADE AND RESOURCES: HIRE CARS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. By way of preface I inform the Minister that I will be placing more detailed questions on notice for response from the Minister himself, but I feel we are entitled to have replies to the following questions before this Parliament rises, whenever that may be: Is it a fact that two private hire cars and drivers are stationed at the Department of Trade and Resources all day each working day in case the Department has a need to transport persons or documents to other departments? Is it a fact that those two cars at the moment carry New South Wales number plates? Will the Minister advise the Senate of the cost per hour for this private hiring and the name of the owner of the two vehicles? Was permission for this hiring received from the Minister for Administrative Services or authorised by the Minister for Trade and Resources? If so, when? Why are Commonwealth cars which are on duty each day not being used?
—That question clearly requires such detailed information that I suggest that the honourable senator place it on notice.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I had already informed the Minister that I intended putting more detailed questions on notice. I believe it is important that we have this information before the Parliament rises. It is a matter of getting a phone call through to the Department of Trade and Resources to find out whether the matters I have raised are factual. He can get a response either by the end of Question Time today or by tomorrow.
—Mr President, the honourable senator may become as petulant as she wishes. She has asked a question and she will get a response--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I believe that the term the Minister used was insulting to the honourable senator who asked the question. I suggest that he be asked to withdraw it. It is offensive to me.
—I call the Minister.
—I have indicated to the honourable senator that she should place the question on notice. We will attempt to get an answer for the honourable senator. That I undertake to do.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to evidence given by Professor Neale of the Australian Archives during the Estimates hearings recently concerning current staffing levels in the Archives. Professor Neale said that an increase in staff would improve efficiency and save over $15m. He also said that material was deteriorating at a much greater rate than could be dealt with by present staff, and that three out of five conservation laboratories-one being in Darwin-were not working. Will the Minister advise what action has been taken by the Government to preserve historical materials, particularly in the Northern Territory, as it is in the process of compiling an historical record and, due to serious shortages of staff in the Archives, is experiencing many problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the problem is perhaps slightly more complex than that. In fact, a joint management review was carried out recently. In the Darwin regional office at present there is an additional problem of determining the custody and ownership of records as between the Northern Territory and the Commonwealth. Clearly, until that matter is resolved it is not possible to provide a simple answer to the question asked by the honourable senator.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has provided in Darwin an excellent archives building, with adequate atmospheric control, in the interests of preventative conservation, but some records have deteriorated and do need active conservation. In fact, already some have been sent to the Archives Conservation Laboratory in Canberra for restoration. Within the limits of existing ceilings it is hoped that a conservator will be allotted to the Darwin office to assist with problems of disposal in related areas, to assist with conservation, and to assist with the determination of custody and ownership of records as between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. A fortnight ago when the Minister was defending Government policy on income equalisation deposits she said that these enabled farmers to 'smooth out their income flows for taxation purposes by making deposits in high income years and withdrawals in low income years'. She continued:

QUESTION.PARA: In this way they can reduce the adverse effects on their taxation liabilities which would result from the interaction of a progressive tax rate scale and fluctuating incomes.

Will she acknowledge that what she said then has not been correct since 1978, when the Government amended the tax averaging provisions, and that a farmer using IEDs now to smooth taxable income will actually pay more tax-that is, that the correct position is the opposite of what she asserted a fortnight ago? Will she apologise for misleading the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — When we were having the discussion on the income equalisation deposits scheme we were also looking at the interaction of other Government policies such as tax averaging. In the comments that were made by me in the description of the income equalisation deposits scheme I outlined the purpose of the scheme and the way in which it was designed to operate. If the speech were read as a whole it would also be acknowledged that it was said that anomalies did arise from the interaction of other Government policies such as averaging, that a committee was looking at these anomalies and that any anomalies that had arisen would be addressed as a result of the recommendations of that committee. As far as the comments of Senator Walsh are concerned, perhaps it could have been said that, since 1977, with the change in the averaging provisions that--
—In 1978 the Act was changed.

— Well, I think in 1977 the Government decided to change the averaging provisions. Since that time undoubtedly anomalies have arisen. It is for that purpose that the committee was set up to look at these anomalies and to make recommendations that would correct them. The interaction of different policies has resulted in some of the effects that were outlined by Senator Walsh in the speech he made. I do not think anyone has argued differently. However--
—You did. You asserted the opposite.

— I described the purpose of the income equalisation deposits scheme and the way in which it was designed. It was designed to do those things. It was also acknowledged that the interaction of other policies created anomalies and that a committee was set up to look at them. I would expect that as a result of that committee's recommendations the Government will need to look at the interaction and the anomalies that have arisen. I am sure there would be those in the community who would expect that some action would be taken.

—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, as usual of course, has dodged the question. The question is not about anomalies; it is about a matter of fact as to whether the use of income equalisation deposits to smooth out taxable income results in farmers paying more tax, or less tax as the Minister asserted a fortnight ago. The Minister asserted that farmers using income equalisation deposits to smooth out taxable income would pay less tax. There was no reference to anomalies. Will she acknowledge that that statement is the reverse of what is true and will she apologise for misleading the Senate? If she refuses to do either of those things, will she submit her assertion in the Senate of a fortnight ago to someone who is numerate-for example, the Secretary to the Treasury or someone deputed by him-for comment upon the accuracy or otherwise of her assertion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Walsh seems to make much of a debate that occurred in the Senate--
—Much of you telling lies in the Senate.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you accused the Minister of telling lies. I ask you to withdraw that.
—I will withdraw. Obviously she is too innumerate to know what the situation is.
—I ask you to withdraw unconditionally, Senator.
—I withdraw.

— As I have said, Senator Walsh seems to have a great interest in the debate because he has mentioned it a number of times. The information given to the Senate was given from the Department of the Treasury to explain the way in which the income equalisation deposits scheme operated. The whole of the debate looked at the interaction of these other policies. If any misunderstanding were to arise from a reading of one part of my statement, of course I would extend an apology appropriate to the circumstances. However, if the whole of the speech had been looked at, along with the comments made by me on the interaction of this scheme and the averaging provisions and the fact that the anomalies that had arisen or could arise were being addressed, I doubt that at the end of that debate there would have been any real misunderstanding as to the attitude of the Government on this whole question. However, if Senator Walsh wishes to pursue the matter and feels that I ought to make some apology, I would have no hesitation in making any apology that would be appropriate to circumstances that have arisen from any information that I have given.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to an article in the magazine Canadian Consumer in which the greatest athlete of the twentieth century, Jessie Owens, raised the various points for and against the modern and very fashionable practice of jogging? Has the information been considered and in particular is it considered that the warnings given to the variety of people regarded as being unsuitable for jogging are sufficiently well known? If not, in the interests of public health should not these warnings be better publicised, along with appropriate alternative exercise forms?

—I note that this question from one Tasmanian senator has almost caused apoplexy in another Tasmanian senator who is a well known jogger. I have seen the article to which the honourable senator refers. I cannot help observing that Jessie Owens, who was a famous athlete, was also a heavy smoker and that he died not so long ago of lung cancer, which could be linked causally with his heavy cigarette smoking.
—A good wine and a cigarette would do you the world of good.

—I am interested in Senator Elstob's defence of cigarette smoking. I think even Senator Elstob has recently cut down his cigarette smoking. The article referred to is part of a continuing debate about the pros and cons of jogging. The major point to make-the article does make this point-is that if one wants to increase one's cardiovascular efficiency and have a healthier heart it is better to engage in some form of exercise for at least 20 minutes several times a week. Jogging, of course, is easy and cheap and to many it is a very enjoyable form of exercise, but there are other ways in which one can achieve the same results. Cycling, swimming and calisthenics are alternative forms of exercise and they, too, have their share of hazards. Because of the concern that many Australians may be entering fun runs such as the City to Surf and other runs like that without sufficient preparation, the Department of Health is in the process of publishing a guide to fun running which contains a list of precautions and a preparation schedule that emphasises gradualism. One thing is for sure; it is better to be healthy and fit than to take no exercise at all. I come back to the point at which I started. It is a very sad thing that Jessie Owens, who wrote about jogging, was also a chain smoker.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is he aware that a copy of a letter marked 'personal and in confidence', signed by the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Stone, and addressed to the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, is pinned to the notice board in the Press Gallery of Parliament House? Is it true, as reported this morning, that the original of the letter has not yet reached the Department of Foreign Affairs? What action, if any, has been taken to determine how this letter reached the Press Gallery? Is this an example of what was described in 1975 as a circumstance 'in which a Treasury official could regard his overriding duty to Australia as being greater than his duty to a government'?

—I am not aware that a copy of the letter is pinned to the Press notice board. If in fact it is a copy of a piece of private correspondence that should in the ordinary lawful sense have gone between two departments, this is once again an example of behaviour that lacks ethics.
—No; it is permitted if you have a higher duty.

—Mr President, I suggest in the interests of Senator Button's hypertension that he had better take up jogging, because he seems to be becoming somewhat frenetic about this situation. I do not know whether the letter is on the Press notice board because I have not looked at the Press notice board. I understand a number of things. I understand that a letter, the full text of which I think is purported to be published in one newspaper today, therefore giving a total rebuttal to the commentary on the letter in the previous day's Press in another section as such, had not reached its destination. That, I think, is regrettable and, indeed, reprehensible. I have no idea what action is being taken. There is a slight difference between circumstances in 1975 and now. The situation in 1975 was--

—Mr President, the more they shout the more I will go on with the story. The situation in 1975 was that a completely illegal Executive Council meeting was held in secret and without the knowledge of the Governor-General. The fact is that an Executive Council meeting was held to raise a loan of some $4,000m, repayable in commission rates and in interest rates that were indefensible. It was quite proper that the advice given by the Treasury in those days-that that loan should never have been raised-should have been given. To compare that situation with a letter which is purported simply to say that a Treasury officer is visiting another country is to distort the whole purpose of the situation. But if Senator Button takes joy in picking up snippets out of the rubbish heap, let him jog in his joy.

—I ask a supplementary question. Am I to understand the Minister to have been referring to the present Prime Minister's statement of 1975, in which he laid down the standards of morality which would apply in his government if he came to power, as snippets from the rubbish heap? If so, are the Minister and I for the first time in our careers in agreement about that question?

—I would be astonished if we were in agreement. I was not referring to the Prime Minister's statement. I was referring to a question in which Senator Button asked me for a parallel between what was judged in the ballot box to be one of the most reprehensible actions by a government since Federation and a confidential letter from the Secretary to the Treasury to the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, simply saying that an officer was making a visit to another country.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Why has the Government withdrawn funding for research into sudden infant death syndrome at the University of Tasmania? What was the state of funding for this project in the last financial year?
—I can only presume that the funding for the research project into the sudden infant death syndrome was through the National Health and Medical Research Council.
—You only gave them petty cash anyway.

—Senator Keeffe, who interjects incorrectly, might be interested to know that the funding for the 1980 calendar year for the NHMRC was something under $16m and that for the 1981 calendar year its funding exceeds $23m at this stage. There has been a very significant improvement and increase in the Government's support for medical research. Whether a particular project is supported depends on peer assessment within the NHMRC by committees which look at the many competing requests for funding and assess them on merit. There is an attempt to look at the different projects to work out which have most merit. I have no idea at all whether a project in the University of Tasmania does or does not have continuing funding. If in fact it is a project funded through the NHMRC and if in fact it is not getting funding in the future it will be for one reason only, and that is that in the opinion of those who evaluate projects there are other projects more deserving of funding; and that is the way that medical research has been and continues to be funded in this country.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REPATRIATION COMMISSION: APPLICATION OF HIGH COURT DECISION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to an extract from the reasons given for a decision by the Repatriation Commission concerning an appeal against a finding that the death of a veteran was not related to his war service. I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: Having considered the decision of the High Court of Australia dated 16 October 1981 in the case of the Repatriation Commission v. Mrs Nancy Law [the Commission] is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that the essential factors which were present in that case, i.e.
(1) that the member commenced smoking whilst on war service,
(2) that the member died from a condition which could have been causally related to his smoking habits; and
(3) his smoking habits were held to have arisen out of or been attributable to his war service;
are not present in this case and that the High Court decision should not be used as a guide in this case.

Does this mean that the High Court decision will be referred to only when the factors are essentially similar to those in that particular case, and especially when smoking is involved? Did not the High Court case have much wider application than this? If so, for what reason is the Repatriation Commission deliberately disregarding the decision of the High Court?

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been pointed out in earlier discussions in relation to the Nancy Law decision, the fact is that the bodies which take decisions on the cases that come before them within the repatriation system, including the Repatriation Review Tribunal and later the courts of appeal, do so on the basis of the facts that are before them at the time. It is clearly for them to make decisions on the basis of those facts and on an interpretation of whatever the law is at that stage. Senator Colston seems to have been outlining the facts of a specific case in his question although he did not give any reference to the name of the case. I am not in a position to give him legal opinion on the likely outcome. But if he cares to raise the specific case with me I will be pleased to have it examined.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to the article in the Adelaide Advertiser on 19 November which reported that studies undertaken by the American company Ralph M. Parsons have found South Australian Wakefield coal to be economically viable for conversion to gas. The report states that 'preliminary studies are believed to show that gas produced from a coal conversion plant towards the end of this decade will be comparable with costs expected at that time for natural gas'. The report further states that the preliminary results of the Parsons survey have encouraged the Shell and Westinghouse energy companies to test much larger quantities of Wakefield coal for conversion to gas. Given that both the South Australian Department of Mines and Energy and the Iron Triangle Study Group, as reported in the said article, have applied to the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council for funding for the pilot tests, will the findings of the Ralph M. Parsons study be taken into account before the NERDDC funding decisions for 1981-82 are announced?
—I will ensure that my Department has all the available evidence and that NERDDC, in its consideration of all such matters, has the evidence before it.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs inform the Parliament whether the Iwasaki beef production interests in the Central Queensland region have an agreement with a local export meat processing firm for the killing of cattle produced on the Iwasaki properties, the processing of the beef and its export to Japan? Can the Minister advise the Parliament whether the processed beef is then deducted from the regular meat export quota between Australia and Japan? Is the Minister aware whether it is a fact that the processed beef is independently sold by Iwasaki interests in Japan, or is it disposed of through normal channels and dealers when it arrives in that country?
—In view of the detailed nature of that question, on which I have no information, I ask Senator Keeffe to put it on notice.
—I ask a supplementary question: If the Minister cannot reply to the question now, can he get the information for me tomorrow as a number of producers want it urgently?
—In view of Senator Keeffe's particular interest, I will endeavour to obtain some information for him today.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and concerns the Family Support Services Scheme. As the triennium for this Scheme ends this month, can the Minister advise the Senate whether the scheme is to be reimplemented? If so, under what conditions and with what guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the Senate that the Family Support Services Scheme is to be continued. The Government undertook to do that at the last election. I wrote to State Ministers earlier this year indicating a three-year funding program commencing on 1 January 1982 and that currently funded projects would be funded to the end of December. Precisely which projects will be funded is a matter on which I am still awaiting some advice from State Ministers. The expectation is that the great majority of those family support projects which are currently being funded will continue to be funded. The scheme is conducted in co-operation with State departments and committees in each State have monitored the effectiveness of these projects. I anticipate receiving recommendations from State Ministers in the very near future.

ANSWER.PARA: The forward commitment on this program, which has been given to the States, is a total of $10m. It is anticipated that a lot of the very valuable work which has been done under this scheme will continue into the future. I approved a set of guidelines for the operation of the scheme. I will make it available to the Senate. It is a fairly bulky document and I do not think that there would be wide enough interest in it to request that it be incorporated in Hansard. If any other honourable senator wants to see guidelines, they are available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The Treasurer referred in his Budget Speech to correcting anomalies and inconsistencies in the administration of sales tax. Included in items previously not taxed but now to be taxed at 17 1/2 per cent are motor vehicle seat belts. How much revenue does the Minister anticipate will be raised from this tax on safety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have the appropriate figures for the proposed tax on seat belts but I could obtain them from the Treasurer and see that Senator Hearn is advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In view of the growing popularity of holiday tour packages which have railway trips as a component, will the Australian National Railways Commission consider opening the Launceston to Hobart railway to specific tourist packages?

—The reopening of any railway is essentially a matter for the Australian National Railways Commission. However, I take on board the point made by Senator Walters. It is a most interesting suggestion. On behalf of the Minister, I undertake to take the matter up with the Commission and put it forward as a suggestion. I understand that there was some discussion in the Senate on this matter a week or so ago. I can point out that the particular track to which Senator Walters refers was inspected by railway track experts accompanied by the Chairman of the Australian National Railways Commission and senior Commission officers during August of this year. As a result of that inspection the Commission will not, I think, be inclined to look favourably at such a question at this time, in view of the very large rehabilitation program which would need to be undertaken on that track at this time. Nevertheless, I will refer the question to the Minister and get some further information for the honourable senator.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether there is valid commercial justification and whether it is usual for a government to practice secrecy when it is seeking to raise loans overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If, for example, this question is directed to the letter from the Secretary to the Treasury to the Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs, let me say, as the Treasurer said, that the purpose of that letter and the purpose of the visit was not to raise loans overseas. If the text of the letter published I think in the Australian today purporting to be the full text of the letter is the text, Senator McIntosh will know that there is no mention of loans at all, and no hint of loans in it.

ANSWER.PARA: The discussions on matters that relate in particular to the International Monetary Fund, that relate to the whole of the international monetary operations, of course are, as to some parts of them, highly confidential. Therefore it is natural that those matters would be confidential. But let me say emphatically that the correspondence from the Secretary to the Treasury relating to the visit of the particular officer did not relate to loan raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the extreme secrecy surrounding Mr Moore's visit to Riyadh consistent with the action of a government actually seeking a loan rather than that of a government officer discussing the world money scene over a cup of tea?

—That question, of course, bears no relation to the former one. The visit to Saudi Arabia by the Treasury officer is part of a normal process of visits to various countries by our high Treasury officers to have discussions on matters arising out of matters discussed at the international level, particularly at the International Monetary Fund. They are not matters discussed over a cup of tea. They are confidential matters, and other countries would expect the discussions to be confidential.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to Australia's conditional decision to participate in the Sinai peace monitoring force. Australia's participation is conditional upon there being a significant European involvement in the Sinai such as is proposed on the part of the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands and Italy. I ask about the additional Australian condition that there be significant prospect of Israel and the Palestinians progressing with autonomy talks. Is not this Australian condition tantamount to the European view expressed in the European Economic Community's Venice declaration, which calls for Palestinian participation in the peace process? In these circumstances, is it not true that if Israel does not accept the European countries' participation along with their Venice declaration Israel at the same time will not accept Australia's participation along with our Palestinian condition? Finally, when does the Australian Government expect the Israeli response to be concluded in respect of European and Australian involvement in the Sinai force?

—I thought that the question was addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister quite properly tells me that I have been taking the Sinai questions. I did not in fact take the full purport of the question. I suggest that Senator Teague ask me that question tomorrow at Question Time and I will certainly respond to him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to the recently released statement by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, which establishes new processes for persons eligible to use government transport. In this statement the Government makes it clear that there will in the future be increasing reliance on the private sector for individual transport and freight transport covered by the Department of Administrative Services. Mr Newman says that this will result in the driver strength of the car pool being reduced and 20 to 30 positions in the freight services fleet being affected. Does this statement establish two classes of persons using government transport? Has there been a cost-benefit analysis of the proposal, a proposal which drastically alters the established practices of the Department? Should not this procedure have been raised during this chamber's consideration of the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services which have just been dealt with? Will the Minister concede that this is another example of the Parliament being by-passed by the Executive?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the purposes of Ministers making public statements is to enable the subjects of those statements to be raised in the Parliament. The only way in which the Parliament could have been by-passed would have been if the matter had been dealt with other than by public announcement. What is raised in the Estimates Committees is entirely a matter for individual senators who make up those committees. Honourable senators will know that the debate is wide-ranging and often fairly prolonged. There is no attempt to truncate the proceedings or to prevent honourable senators from raising matters which they think are important. Had there been some appropriate appropriation item-I am sure there would have been-for the Department of Administrative Services it would have been quite possible for someone to raise this matter. However, I take it that Mr Newman was not able to make his announcement ahead of an appropriate Government decision. If that is what Senator Gietzelt is referring to I assure him that Mr Newman's statement followed fairly closely upon an appropriate Government decision.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that there has been an examination of the cost-benefit structure of providing transport generally, a matter to which part of Senator Gietzelt's question was addressed. I do not have the details of it but I understand that the costs of providing transport through different modes were examined. The Government has taken a decision to try to obtain the best, most efficient, and most effective use of the transport options available to it. It has not decided to do away with the Commonwealth transport fleet in any way. It has decided to try to find out how best to integrate the use of the Commonwealth car and heavy transport fleet with that of private industry. It is not the Government's view that it is in any way creating different classes of users of the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is it a fact that the Minister for Administrative Services announced this change in the process after this chamber had dealt with the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services? Has he had a report from Mr Marks, who was formerly associated with the management of Brambles Industries Ltd, which is a private transport organisation? Does the Minister concede that the matter ought to have been brought up so that it could have been dealt with by this place when it was dealing with the estimates of the Department of Administrative Services?

—I understand Senator Gietzelt's concern but I must say again that Mr Newman was in no position to announce any decision of government until such a decision had been made. I put it to the honourable senator: How could he have done otherwise?
—It depends how long he had the report.

—No, that is not correct. What it depends upon is how long he had the government decision. In fact, the report can be nothing more than a basis for consideration by government of the course which it proposes to take. I have already said that Mr Newman's statement followed closely upon the decision taken by government.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STATE DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL OF SOUTH AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the Minister aware of the report of the State Development Council of South Australia in today's Press calling for an end to traditional reliance on protected industry? The report having come from this most authoritative body in a State where protection is very much a way of life, will the Federal Government stop hiding under its economic mushrooms and move towards the progressive reduction of excessive tariff levels so that the Australian economy can grow and the decline in our standards of living, relative to other nations, be countered?

—I have read something to the effect of what Senator MacGibbon has said. In fact, in recent weeks I have read a whole variety of comments by those who seek to lower protection and by those who seek to increase it. It is common knowledge that the Government at this moment is studying the whole matter. Therefore, it would not be proper for me to comment on it because it is a policy matter. Suffice to say that one must reconcile in this country a series of needs; on the one hand the essential need to have industries that are essential to Australia, viable in their technology for Australia and able to provide employment, and on the other hand a state of efficiency and competitiveness that enables us to reach out to trade with the world. Those two factors take a considerable amount of reconciling.
—Plus employment of our work force.

—The interjection of Senator Chipp was unnecessary because I had indicated that we should take into account the employment of our work force. The matter raised by Senator MacGibbon is one of the factors that will be in the mind of Cabinet during its deliberation.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to questions asked by Senator Button and me on 10 November concerning the death of the Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist Tony Joyce. Can we expect answers to our questions before the Senate rises this week or will the Government continue to sweep this matter under the carpet?

—The Government has no intention of sweeping the matter under the carpet. If I have not provided any outstanding answers I will seek to do so. From memory, those questions asked concerned some suggestion of a report. There is no report other than the letter involved. There was some suggestion that our diplomatic people in the area may have had evidence to bear. It is my understanding that there was only one other Australian witness and that was the passenger. Therefore, the basic situation is that the Government believes that there is no way in which it can reasonably-after all its earnest endeavours-find further information. I will look to the questions outstanding. If there is further information I will make it available tomorrow.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As Senator Carrick has now said for the first time that the official letter from Dr Kaunda to Mr Fraser is the only report from the Zambian Government on the incident, will the Minister look at the question asked by Senator Button and make available the official reports on this issue from our diplomats overseas to the Department of Foreign Affairs?

—I will refer that matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Of course, my understanding is that all such reports are confidential. The letter that I referred to is a letter between heads of government and therefore must remain confidential.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Leader ask Cabinet to consider tabling in the Senate more frequently than every six months a manifest of the flights of VIP aircraft?
—I will bring that question to the attention of the responsible Minister.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Gietzelt proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to assist citizens to have adequate accommodation and contain interest rates.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition again raises in the Senate the crucial social issue of housing in Australia. We believe that it is a major responsibility of a national government to provide an environment in which Australian citizens have a right to solve their accommodation problems. They should be able to do that either by purchasing or erecting their own home or, if they are unable to do that due to economic circumstances, the national government should respond by providing public housing. As my colleague, the shadow Minister for urban and regional affairs, Mr Uren, and the leader of my party, Mr Hayden, have stressed in the past week or so, the growing crisis in housing and home ownership has become a major social problem, alongside the problem of unemployment. That fact is being recognised by many of the leading newspapers. The Sydney Sun stated last Monday:

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, Mr Howard, is splitting hairs when he says the rise in the price of housing and land has done more to prevent home-buying than have rising interest rates in the past three years.
The Sun went on to state:
What confronts him now is the total failure of the government housing policies.

I stress the point made by the Sun, that there has been a total failure of the Government's housing policy. The Australian Labor Party has chosen the last week of the parliamentary sittings for 1981, a week in which the Government has seen fit finally to retreat from its responsibilities to the people of Australia, once again to raise this matter of housing. We will do it again and again until we see a genuine change of heart and a change of policy by the Fraser-Howard Government, until we see it addressing itself seriously and responsibly to the topic of this matter of public importance, namely:
The failure of the Government to assist citizens to have adequate accommodation and contain interest rates.

The cost of housing is rising to a higher level than ever before. Rents are at an all-time record high and we are building fewer houses in 1981 than in previous years. The point that has to be made in this debate is that the cost of housing has risen, in general terms-it differs from State to State-at a rate more than three times that of inflation. We should recognise that the biggest single item purchased or attempted to be purchased by the average family in our country is a home. I wish to canvass several related matters in today's debate. Briefly, they are: The Government's economic philosophy, strategy and policy, particularly its obsession with the so-called free market and the money supply, a philosophy which is constantly echoed in this place by the Leader of the Government, Senator Carrick; the nature of the economic advice the Government is receiving from its Treasury; the inquiry into the Australian financial system; the pressure being applied to interest rates; and the housing crisis that is being created as a result of all these elements.

The Liberal-National Country Party Government seems proud of its free market, Adam Smith credentials. Time and again it makes statements that make its founding father, Sir Robert Menzies, seem like a doyen of downright socialism with his talk of protection for employment industries, regulation and control of interest rates and the like. All of this has come into the news again with the release of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. We are privy to the failure of Thatcherism in the United Kingdom and the repudiation of Reaganism in the United States of America even by one of the United States Governments closest economic advisers, Mr Stockman. Yet the Fraser Government persists with its outdated attitudes. As we all now know, the Government, represented in this case by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, laid down the type of report it wanted in the terms of reference it gave to the Campbell Inquiry. The report was to be influenced by the Government's philosophical position, the Government's 'free enterprise objectives'. It was to be, as one newspaper noted, Mr Howard's major political victory. It was to bear the stamp of his Department all over it. It has certainly done that.

The Campbell report looks like being the biggest failure of Mr Howard's short but notable time in the spotlight, for his economic theories are falling apart here, as indeed they are in other parts of the world. As an economic document the Campbell report is callous and lacking in social thought or vision. It shows the logic to which a conservative government can stretch. It is a bench-mark by which we can measure conservative governments, with its emphasis on deregulation, freeing up of the financial system to market forces and, of course, to foreign banks, cutting back on government intervention, government interest, government concern and planning, et cetera. It tells us much about this conservative Liberal-National Country Party Government and how it thinks. That is its value for us today.

Much of the Campbell report's views are echoed elsewhere at the senior reaches of the Department of the Treasury. For example, last week, just one day before the public saw the Campbell report, the Secretary to the Treasury was reported as suggesting that the Government would need to make more room for private investment in Australia if Australia was to take full advantage of its economic opportunities, especially in the natural resource area. He saw the Australian preference for home ownership as a means of diverting capital away from other uses such as resource development and posed the question whether we ought not to see one against the other instead of seeing them complementing one another. Of course, that is Mr Stone's view. Let us remember that this is the view of a very senior government adviser whose views have held sway in the Government's economic thinking for the last five or six years.

In Mr Stone's view, significant sectors of the Australian economy should be squeezed back in order to make more room for an expanded inflow of capital and to facilitate a transfer of domestic funds towards investment in resource-type development. This policy, the Stone policy-the stone-age policy-is already in place in many areas of government economic management, despite reported differences between Messrs Howard and Stone, as suggested on the radio program PM last night. The Stone-Treasury line of a free play for the market and a cutting back to make room for the public sector has been a feature in each of the Fraser-Howard Budgets since 1976. This free market obsession is one key element in the Government's thinking. For the housing sector it means an uncontrolled blowout in interest rates and a neglectful cut-back in the public sector responsibilities. These are exactly the policies being followed. The other key obsession for Mr Howard and his friends is the money supply. High interest rates will restrict the amount of money floating around, thereby controlling the money supply. That is the theory. Public sector spending increases the deficit and, therefore, the money supply. So goes their obsession.

A policy of high interest rates and of a clamp down on public sector housing is the logical result, and that is enshrined in this Government's policies, which inevitably will mean a further increase of approximately 2 per cent in interest rates. The effects of these policies have been emphasised by the Australian Labor Party. Any compassionate political party would stress these effects. Only an uncaring government, which we now have, can neglect them in its zeal for a reduced money supply situation. As we know, interest rates have sky-rocketed in recent months. According to figures supplied by the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, the prevailing rate for mortgage repayments is about 13.5 per cent to 15 per cent. In my estimation, that is a generous calculation. The Association calculates that on a $30,000 25-year loan the monthly repayments, at the going rate of 14.5 per cent, are $373 per month. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a small table from the Association showing monthly repayments on a standard $30,000 25-year loan at various rates of interest.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MORTGAGE REPAYMENTS*
(Per cent)Interest Rate 12.25 12.5 13.0 13.5 14.25 14.5
*$30,000 loan, 25 year term. Interest at monthly rests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, this shows that the increase that has taken place in mortgage repayments in the recent period is something like $51. This sort of repayment excludes most wage and salary earners from housing finance. Already under this Government interest rates on savings bank loans have risen from 9.5 per cent to 12.5 per cent since February 1980. We know too that the finance company and building society interest rates are even higher. Yet the recommendation of the Campbell inquiry report is that interest rates should be deregulated altogether. On the Committee's own admission this will mean an average increase in rates of approximately another 2 per cent. When Mr Willis, our economic spokesman, referred to that he was spot on with what the estimation and assessment should be. The Housing Industry Association, which deals with the problems associated with the building industry, estimates that for each 0.5 per cent increase in home loan interest rates some 4,000 Australians are excluded from the home ownership market. The Campbell report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Those persons most likely to be affected by sizeable interest rate increases are those who have not yet acquired their first home or have borrowed recently and whose repayments are a high proportion of their income.

The Government had better make itself clear on the matter of interest rates because they are depressing the home market. Will the Government continue to use interest rates as a squeeze on the money supply or, more drastically, will it allow market forces to increase the rates across the board? The trouble signs are there. The trouble signs of high rates have already been seen in the depressed housing market, increased pressure on rentals, increasingly inadequate housing and homelessness.
