The facts are there to prove what I am saying. The facts show that there is a slump in the housing industry.

According to the most recent figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics the total number of new houses approved for building in both the private and public sectors has decreased in real terms by over 11 per cent in the year since September 1980. In public sector housing the decline is some 17 per cent. According to the Permanent Building Societies Association Ltd the reason is clear; finance for housing has contracted sharply in the months to September 1981. This is what has happened without deregulation. If we wish to contemplate that perhaps we should look at the experience overseas and at the United States housing boom. The business journal Business Review Weekly, in an article on 4 September, stated:

Soaring mortgage rates, now running at 17 per cent or more have put the lid on the American housing boom that began in the mid-70's . . . the recent surge in interest rates began in late 1979 when the Federal Reserve Board decided to concentrate its efforts on controlling the money supply. Interest rates were opened to market forces and quickly began to rise.

That could almost be a description of what is happening in Australia with all the disastrous consequences of the Fraser Government's policies. It is no wonder that even industry sources cannot support this Government's housing priorities. It is no wonder that the Government's housing committee has been expressing concern to the Government about the failure of the home savings grant legislation and its inability to have any appreciable impact. Is it any wonder that Liberal housing Ministers in the States are supercritical of the cut-backs that are taking place in the public housing sector? Is it any wonder that the people associated with this matter, such as the master builders and those in the housing industry, are concerned and that in the editorials of most of the responsible newspapers in Australia this Government is being slighted for its inept policies?

As conditions have worsened in the home ownership market more and more people face increased rental pressures. They are being forced to seek housing on the rental market. Interest rate charges and changes have hit hard in that area as well, with the vast burden being passed on to the tenant. For owners of private rental accommodation the increase in rates is forcing them to increase rents to achieve a good rate of return. The tenant pays and as the Sydney Daily Mirror noted on Monday, 23 November, this will continue well into 1983 unless government policies change. The Daily Mirror stated:

The reason, according to Mr Rowen Kelly, managing director of Kelly and Sons Real Estate Centres; 'there is still quite a big gap between the rent payable on a home and the mortgage repayments. And while that gap remains as wide as it is, fewer buyers will be around. As a result, home prices will remain stable. The only way the sales market will improve is for rents to catch up with mortgage repayments . . . and that's what I expect to happen in 1982'.

Therefore, clearly, the rental market will rise dramatically within the next year. A sensible government would respond by increasing the public housing stock to take up this need and to relieve the pressure. But not this Government; in real terms, it has cut funds available for public housing. Since 1975, in real terms, funds for public sector housing have fallen from $1,413m to $399m in 1981-82. This has put the States in an impossible position in this area of responsibility. The Federal Government has a concept of welfare housing only, yet today public housing should be promoted as a reasonable and viable alternative to the home ownership race, a race which the average wage and salary earner cannot now enter. This is an indisputable fact. We need rental housing for those who cannot enter that race. There is also a vital need for rental housing because of the growing mobility of the work force that has been evident in our economy in recent years.

I deal next with the subject of homelessness. Even in this area of welfare housing the Government fails miserably. The National Director of the Housing Industry Association recently stated that 280,000 families urgently needed housing. He said:
The Federal Government had to provide at least $450 million in the next year and State Governments had to do more to attack housing poverty . . .
Many are being forced to live in sub-standard housing because they just can't afford the rent for a decent home.

The Housing Industry Association estimated that in the past year the number of very needy families grew by well over 20,000. If we concede that in 1982 and 1983 the problem will increase by that same margin, what sort of drastic and dramatic situation will face an ever increasing number of Australian families? The Government has neglected its responsibilities and transferred them back to the States and to the individuals, who cannot solve the problem alone because it is a matter for government assistance, government intervention and government planning. The thousands of people living in substandard rental accommodation, in caravan parks or in temporary accommodation could tell us that loudly and clearly. Yet things are not all bad for all people on the interest rate or construction front. Some friends of this Government and potential benefactors of the Campbell Committee report are doing very well, thank you very much. For example, the large banks and finance companies do very nicely from the high interest rates that the ordinary Australians must pay. On 30 October an article in the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Two of Australia's largest finance companies-Australian Guarantee Corporation and Citicorp Australia-have reported hefty profit increases reflecting the strength of the finance industry amid high interest rates.

As Senator Chipp pointed out to the Senate yesterday, the banks are making huge profits from interest rate hikes. The profits of the ANZ Banking Group Ltd rose by 29 per cent to $175.4m while the profits of the Bank of New South Wales improved by 33.3 per cent to $165m. The National Bank of Australasia Ltd increased its profits by 33.8 per cent to $101.4m in the same period. So much for competition in interest rates. Plenty of building is also going on, but not to provide shelter for Australian families. The boom in resources, power and commercial construction has helped huge contractors such as John Holland (Constructions) Pty Ltd, Roberts Construction (Pacific) Pty Ltd and Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd find their way to record earnings this year. Leighton's profit has been $5.4m and Holland's surplus has been $3.3m. Such profits could provide shelter, in a properly governed society, for many Australian wage earners, but it lines the pockets of the wealthy fat cats. Finance company wits tell the story of asking all those requesting money for building finance: 'Oh yes; and where is your gold mine?'. Every day this joke becomes more and more a confirmed reality as the needs of people are being pushed aside. Mr Uren, the Oppositions spokesperson on housing matters, has outlined the need for a co-ordinated plan to respond to people's housing needs and to confront rising rates of interest and corporate carelessness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his usual way, Senator Gietzelt has sought to confuse all the issues which he has raised in the matter of public importance that he proposed for discussion by the Senate today. For the purposes of the exercise and to refresh the Opposition's memory, the matter of public importance is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to assist citizens to have adequate accommodation and contain interest rates.

In the earlier part of his debate on this matter, Senator Gietzelt would have us believe that, in fact, the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System which was presented in this chamber only a week ago, is implemented government policy. In fact, he has been seeking over the last week or so and particularly in this discussion today to misrepresent the Government's position on housing interest rates and in other areas. On that point, I refer to a remark that the Campbell Committee made in its report. It said:
The Committee has not sought to assess the appropriate level of assistance to particular groups . . .

The judgments involved extend well beyond questions of economic efficiency and are outside the Committee's terms of reference. The Committee has instead focused solely on the methods of assistance and their implications for the financial system.

The point is simply that the Government has received a report which is, as was stated by the Chairman of that Committee, a blueprint for the financial system in Australia and, in fact, puts down views of that Committee. It is for the Government to decide what policies it should implement in regard to the financial system and especially with regard to the effects of particular decisions upon sectoral policies for the provision of finance. In particular, Senator Gietzelt's point in relation to housing will be given great consideration by this Government in considering the Campbell Committee report. Again I make the point that the Campbell Committee report is not a fait accompli as such. It is wrong for Senator Gietzelt and other members of the Opposition to represent it consistently as being accomplished Government policy. Indeed, the Campbell Committee says quite clearly in its report that it is not seeking to see that kind of policy strictly in place in various parts of the economy but leaves those decisions to government.

In relation to the points which Senator Gietzelt raised in supporting his argument which touched, as I say, very briefly upon the actual point which was raised in the matter of public importance proposed for discussion, the fact is that his major differences with the Government relate to philosophy. He refuses consistently to accept the fact that we do not speak only of housing in terms of public housing or private housing. We talk of housing in terms of the total housing market in Australia. In fact, we have to acknowledge that, over the years since 1947, total private ownership of houses in Australia has risen from something like 53.4 per cent in 1947 during the Chifley Labor Government to a level of around 72 per cent in 1980. That figure has been consistent over the last decade or so, running approximately at a 70 per cent level. That indicates a very substantial commitment on the part of Australians, on the part of the Australian financial institutions and on the part of this Government to support private ownership in housing as distinct from the kind of welfare housing approach which Senator Gietzelt is seeking to make.

That does not deny that the Government does not have responsibilities to lower income groups. In fact, I refute very clearly the points which have been made by Senator Gietzelt in relation to the apparent non-concern of this Government for lower income groups in this area. Quite clearly, the Government has committed substantial resources to the lower income groups. In fact, if we look at the figures for applications for rental accommodation which are outstanding with State housing authorities at the present time, we see that in 1975, before this Government came to office, approximately 103,000 people were seeking rental accommodation through State housing authorities. In December 1980-five years later-that number had dropped to 86,000. There has been a consistent fall since this Government came to power. A fair catch-up was required because of the situation that existed in 1975 which related to the previous Government's efforts in trying to destroy this nation through wrong-headed economic policies. But in terms of achievement, this Government has also substantially reduced the backlog of cases of people seeking assistance through the State housing authorities, even in light of the fact that the total market might have been expected to grow in that period.

Another area of concern, to which Senator Gietzelt did not refer, is the provision, through the State housing authorities, of rental rebates for persons on low incomes. This system did not apply in 1975. In the time of the Whitlam Labor Government there was no provision of rental rebates through the State housing authorities. In the first year of this Government $12.3m was provided to low income earners. In the last year for which I have a full year's figures-that is, 1979-80-$75m was provided for rental rebates in the States. If this does not show concern for the lower income earners I do not know what does.

Clearly, this Government is committed to the provision of assistance to those who need it most. Clearly, the Opposition's policies are designed to create a greater number of people who are dependent rather than people who can look after themselves. That is the essential difference between the philosophy of the Opposition and the philosophy of this Government in relation to housing. Clearly, we seek to assist those in greatest need. Of course, Senator Gietzelt would not appreciate the point. The famous Minister responsible for housing in the Curtin Labor Government during war time, Mr Dedman, did not support private ownership of housing because it led to the establishment of more and more 'little capitalists' in the country. That seems to be Senator Gietzelt's point of view and, generally speaking, the point of view of the Opposition as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go back to the eighteenth century?

—I take it that Senator Gietzelt denies these remarks. Might I take the argument a little further to make the point that not only has the amount of money being provided to State housing authorities for rental rebates to those on lowest incomes grown substantially in the last five years, but also the numbers of people being assisted has grown enornously. In June 1975 the number of people receiving assistance was some 29,000. In fact, in December 1980 the number had risen to 95,000. That is an increase of some 300 per cent. Does that show a lack of concern by this Government for those who are in greatest need? Of course not. Clearly, this Government is committed to assisting those who are in greatest need. That is what the philosophy of this Government is about rather than putting resources into the hands of those who least need them, which seems to be the approach of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to some of the other issues which surround the general housing situation in Australia at the present time, Senator Gietzelt claimed that there has been a substantial fall in the number of building approvals and commencements. If we look back to the dark years of 1975-76, particularly 1975, we see that the number of dwellings commencement approvals was 121,323. In the last year for which we have figures-1980-81-the number of dwellings approved was 156,501, a growth of about 24 per cent over that period. Clearly that evidences continuing growth in the total housing market. Senator Gietzelt sought to make out, in terms of annual fluctuations, that somehow it is moving in other directions. But if one takes the long view, one sees a substantial improvement in the total number of dwellings being approved and commenced. This clearly evidences strength and vitality in the Australian economy. I would like to come to that point a little later.

I have spoken of the dwellings approved. I would like to mention now the actual commencements, for which the figures are slightly different. The number of houses commenced in 1974-75 was 118,109. Last year-an estimate only at this stage-the total number of commencements was 148,000, an increase of about 30 per cent over that six-year period. Does that substantially support Senator Gietzelt's argument that housing is slipping back into the Middle Ages or whenever as he is seeking to assert? Of course not. Clearly, there has been progress in housing at all levels in this country. Whether it is at the public housing level or at the private housing level, the fact is that more people are getting into houses and doing better from time to time.

Let us come to some of the more particular points which Senator Gietzelt sought to make with regard to interest rates. He made the point that people generally are being discouraged from home ownership by virtue of the higher interest rates which are present in the community at the moment. We know, of course, that that is substantially correct, that there have been increases in housing interest rates across the community. We have to look at the reasons why that has happened. Interest rates do register the price of money and consequently are a measure of the demand and supply situation for money in the community. Only a limited amount of money is available within the community and it is available for many things, such as the development of resource projects, the development of houses, the development of businesses and the provision of ordinary finance for consumer durable purchases, such as motor cars. Clearly, what we have to do is be able to ration as best we can finance to the various sectors of the community. It cannot be done by the stroke of a pen. Senator Gietzelt clearly knows that because he was a supporter of the Labor Government in 1974 when interest rates increased from 10 per cent to about 24 per cent in the short term money market, in the overnight money market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come off it. They never went over 20 per cent.
—The honourable senator should ask the Bank of New South Wales about that one.
—You are misleading the Parliament.

—That is something the honourable senator has been doing ever since he has been a member of this place. Interest rates measure the cost of money to the community and regulate the supply to the various sectors of the community. If we are to ensure that people have adequate housing finance, we must ensure that there is at least some relativity between housing interest rates and interest rates for any other form of borrowing. At the core of this Government's policy is the wish to ensure that there is adequate finance for housing throughout the community. The second point-I think this is the one that is most overlooked by the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, for that matter, in relation to housing-is that through the much maligned monetary policies of this Government we have been able to keep inflation under control and in fact have reduced it from Labor's 19 per cent in 1974 to 8 per cent or 9 per cent at the present time. By virtue of that change, the enormous benefit to the community of Australians who are seeking to buy their first homes must be obvious to all but those in the Opposition. The fact is that by virtue of being able to keep inflation under control we keep under control the cost of housing in this community which, as we know, went up absolutely astronomically during that period of the Whitlam Labor Government. In fact, in the period of two years- or was it three?-the average price of a house in Australia doubled. In that period it became almost impossible for people to buy houses. That must not be denied by honourable members opposite. The fact is that by controlling inflation we are seeking to put as many people into houses as we can.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the side effects of that is that in order to keep control of the money supply, which in fact has a very big impact upon the rate of inflation, we must ensure that the interest rates are kept at reasonable levels. That, of course, has been this Government's policy over the last five or six years. No one says that high interest rates are very popular. It is, however, at this time the only policy which happens to be right, and that is the significant thing which the Opposition will dismiss and make as much politics of as it possibly can. In fact it is seeking to do that at this very moment. What we are seeking to do is to ensure that the longer term interests of the Australian community are kept in mind. In terms of the question of inflation and the cost of housing I refer the Opposition to an article by Kenneth Davidson which appeared in this morning's Age. The headline reads: 'Home prices the culprit, not rates'. This, of course, is only what we have been saying in the last few minutes. It substantially supports the point that the effect of inflation on the average price of a home is the biggest deterrent to people obtaining a home. One has only to consider the effects on a person living in Sydney who needs to pay something like $60,000 for his first home. If inflation is running in the order of 10 per cent, we are talking about an increase in the price of that house over a 12-months period of some $6,000. How does that compare with a one per cent increase in interest rates which might apply to an average mortgage?

Obviously those figures are not comparable and the greatest disadvantage falls on that person who is seeking to buy his first home. That is a very substantial point which this Government believes is the reason for its policies and is the reason we are committed to ensuring that interest rates keep the money supply under control so that we can in fact keep inflation under control. By doing that and by achieving those things we will do more for housing in this community and for Australians in general, not only for tomorrow but also for the long term future, than the Opposition's policies will ever achieve. The Opposition knows that by its own experience in 1974 and 1975 it destroyed the Australian economy by its free money policies which made housing so expensive that the average person could not achieve it, and in that way it made sure that it created problems which had to be corrected by the fortunately right policies of this Government. (Quorum formed).

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, this morning I gave notice of motion in respect of establishing a select committee on electoral matters. I now seek leave of the Senate to withdraw General Business Notice of Motion No. 52 dealing with a similar matter, which notice was given on 28 October.

SPEECH.PARA: Notice of motion-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, I present a report of the Committee's reference on the development of the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The Committee has looked at the development of the bauxite, alumina and aluminium industries principally from a national perspective, with particular regard to the role of the national government in overseeing development and ensuring that industrial expansion will benefit the whole community.

The development of an export oriented industry engaged in further processing of minerals is welcome. The aluminium industry has the capacity to generate a significant growth in wealth throughout the community, stimulate growth in related industries and, as a result, expand employment. Of central importance to the debate on the expansion of the industry are the terms and conditions on which it is attracted to this country. The Committee believes that, in the context of the world aluminium industry, Australia is an attractive location for expansion of that industry. The advantages this country has include availability of raw materials, energy, a skilled work force and a stable political and economic system attractive to corporate investors. Thus the Committee believes that there is no justification for offering special concessions to the industry whether through undervaluing of resources, taxation concessions, watered down environmental controls or subsidised provision of infrastructure. There is evidence that the new projects have benefited from one or other of these types of concessions. This is particularly so for the supply of electricity to aluminium smelters where any subsidy to one user is a direct charge on the community as a whole.

The belief that Australia has a significant comparative advantage must be balanced by acknowledging that that advantage is neither absolute nor open-ended. It is limited by the availability of competing locations which will become increasingly attractive alternatives over time. Thus it is vitally important that, if Australia is to attract development in the medium term without offering subsidies or concessions, this country must provide a secure and predictable framework for investment. The potential investor in these highly capital intensive long term projects must know from the outset the terms and conditions applying to development and be reassured that they will not be subject to sudden or dramatic change. Perhaps the most glaring evidence of the absence of that 'secure and predictable' framework has been provided by the recent sharp rise in electricity prices in Victoria and the resulting inquiry into the supply of electricity to the proposed Alcoa smelter at Portland, Victoria. Other examples include the wide variation in local and State taxes and charges, the lack of co-ordination between State royalties and quasi-royalties and Commonwealth taxation and the varying policies on the provision of infrastructure. All these factors also provide great scope for corporate developers to 'play off' the various States with the object of minimising their costs. A co-ordinated approach by State and Federal governments should seek to maximise the community's return.

The Committee is concerned that various national Government departments have adopted a passive role in discharging their responsibilities. This is particularly true of the lack of information available to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in negotiations in the Loan Council when considering borrowing by electricity authorities, the failure of the Department of National Development and Energy to seek otherwise confidential information on electricity supply and pricing and the reduction of the role of the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in administering the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974.
Energy

The Committee does not view the energy demand of the aluminium industry as a problem in itself. However, it has serious reservations as to whether some State authorities can meet their contractual obligations to the industry without disadvantaging other consumers. It is essential that the cost of supplying energy to large industrial users covers the full costs of all factors of production, with one reservation-the Committee believes that export parity pricing, particularly of coal, is not necessarily the best approach to take in all circumstances. If export parity pricing will prevent investment taking place which would otherwise be of considerable net economic benefit, it may be justified to forego some measure of income to ensure that investment takes place.
Taxation

The function of the taxation system is to ensure that the Australian community as a whole receives a fair return on resources employed and profits generated within the aluminium industry. The present unco-ordinated range of State and Federal taxes and royalties do not achieve this. Taken in conjunction with the structure of the aluminium industry they provide many opportunities for tax minimisation and avoidance.
Ownership

A significant degree of foreign participation is inevitable to provide access to markets, technology and capital. This is not a cause for anxiety if the level of foreign ownership is kept under constant public scrutiny and if the taxation system operates effectively to ensure that foreign participation does not result in a loss of revenue to the community as a whole.
Labour

The aluminium industry will provide relatively few jobs directly. However, through the creation of wealth in the community and the development of related industries, it can be expected to have a significant positive effect. The Committee does not believe that jobs created per dollar invested is a valid criterion for evaluating the worth of an industry. The availability of skilled labour to meet the industry's needs remains a contentious issue. Given the lead time of these projects and the predictable nature of their demand for labour, it indicates a sad lack of foresight by government, educational institutions and industry that shortages of particular skills have emerged. The Committee notes the conclusion of the Department of Labour Advisory Committee report that there is no evidence to suggest that immigration can provide skilled labour in categories where shortages are apparent. Thus increased immigration on that basis should be discouraged.
Infrastructure

In remote areas such as the Mitchell Plateau of Western Australia corporate developers should be responsible for the provision of all physical infrastructure. In settled areas this policy is not equitable or appropriate. Thus it is essential that local rates, State taxes and other charges recover appropriate proportions of infrastructure costs incurred as a result of industrial development. Local authorities confronted with development must be provided with support by State and Commonwealth governments to ensure that they can negotiate effectively with developers. In addition, they must be put on a secure financial basis through the collection of an adequate level of rates and the provision of financial support when it is most needed-at an early stage of development. Reliance on negotiating one-off front end payments or the benevolence of project developers is not a suitable financial base for a local authority.
Environment

The Committee believes that a number of projects are being allowed to proceed despite unresolved and justifiable anxieties as to their impact on the environment. The Department of Home Affairs and Environment should take a more active role in evaluating the environmental impact of these projects. That Department must also develop procedures for the conduct of regional environmental assessment involving a number of projects and different industries.

The inquiry was probably the most interesting that we have undertaken. I pay a tribute to the Committee members for the immense amount of work that they devoted to this inquiry. It certainly generated considerable community interest. I must record our special appreciation to Ron Maunsell who retired from the Committee and the Senate during the latter stages of this inquiry. The Committee, like other Senate committees, has always been well served by its support staff. To Derek Abbott and Jenny Norberry I convey our special thanks for a job well done. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the usually moderate language of a Senate committee report, which one would expect from a group of six senators from each side of this chamber, one might miss the cumulative impact of its moderate words, chapter after chapter. But the cumulative message is clear. There is in this report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources a very damaging indictment of government in Australia-of national government, for its passivity and its reaction policy when confronted with the development plans of those who wish to use our natural resources, and of State governments for their competitive bidding, one against another, to ensure the presence of one or more stages of the aluminium industry within their borders.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is strongly of the view that the scope and the pace of development of the aluminium industry ought to be harnessed in order to secure social goals and national strategies. I do not say that the scope and pace of development should be unduly supervised or directed, but at least it should be harnessed in a way which achieves social goals. We found, to our great regret, that there was a lack of policy and competence at the national level and that left a vacuum which was filled by the States competitively bidding against one another in order to form alliances with the great project developers moving into Australia. It would not be too much to say that the Committee members were shocked at the lack of political will and competence displayed at the level of national bureaucracy. I lost faith in the national bureaucracy when the Committe had before it representatives of the Department of National Development and Energy. When Mr Monaghan gave evidence to the Committee I asked:

What formal request has the Department made, for example to the State Government of New South Wales or its Electricity Commission or any State government where relevant, to obtain the tariffs which you say are regarded by them as confidential?
Mr Monaghan replied:

I mentioned earlier arrangements for obtaining information which is not regarded as confidential by the authorities. We have not made a formal demand on the authorities for information which they consider to be confidential-
This is a reference to the electricity tariffs-
because we have not felt that we have the power to do so.
The transcript continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say 'formal demand'-I said 'formal request'.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Monaghan-I amend my response with the words 'formal request'.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference, is there not?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Monaghan-I suppose there is. We still have felt that we are not empowered to do it.

In other words, at the very highest level of bureaucracy within the national government-no doubt correctly interpreting the lack of political will within the Ministry-we find that there has been no attempt by the national government even to seek by request, let alone demand, from State governments or electricity commissions the electricity tariffs being charged to the consumers of electricity in, in this instance, the aluminium industry. That was one instance that made a big impact on my understanding of the role of national government in this regard. But, of course, one can generalise and say that that was only a sample of what the Committee was confronted with. On page 7 of the report, we say:

In the rush to promote investment and to attract development to particular States there has been a tendency to treat these projects as ends in themselves. Competitive bidding between various States may mean that the Australian community as a whole, and even the individual States concerned, will not get full benefit from the exploitation of resouces. In these circumstaneces it is of crucial importance that the national government has a clear policy on the pace, timing and cost of development.
The Committee looked in vain for such a policy. On page 10 the Committee concludes the preliminary part of its report by stating:
The Committee is concerned at the overall lack of clear policy on development at the Commonwealth level.

We provide chapter after chapter of evidence for that concern. Given the short amount of time that is available to me I will select two or three issues from each of those chapters and comment on them. This will necessarily be somewhat subjective but I hope that it will not be found to be in any way misplacing or distorting the report. In dealing with energy I note particularly that the Committee rejected the primary submission made by Treasury that coal into electricity generating facilities to service the aluminium smelters and, indeed, other major industrial projects, ought to be provided at an export parity price. We say that it is very important for Australia's development and for the creation of wealth within the Australian economy and community that all factors of production be brought into play. It is very important, for example, that coal and bauxite should not be exported separately overseas. It is much better for them to be brought into co-ordination for refining into alumina and then smelting into aluminium. I wish to give some figures to show why that is so important to the generation of wealth within the Australian economy. On page 5, in relation to the Tomago Aluminium smelter, the Committee notes:

The annual export income of that smelter is expected to be $330m at 1980 prices. This is 2.7 times the income which would be produced by exporting equivalent quantities of coal and alumina and more than 7 times the export value of equivalent quantities of bauxite and coal.

For those reasons we think that, in order to get that sevenfold increase in value for the Australian economy, it is very important that our coal resources-those great energy resources-be used in order to convert the bauxite to alumina and then to aluminium. Having said that, we make it very clear in our report that tariffs charged by electricity commissions to the smelters ought to cover the full costs of production and of transport of that energy to the smelter and include a very realistic rate of return to the generating authority appropriate to its status as a public authority. Whereas I think we found that some commissions were looking for a return of only about 3 per cent on the public capital that is tied up in these generating facilities, we say that a figure approaching 7 per cent would be much more realistic. In fact, we go further. In what I think is a very interesting comment in the report we say that perhaps some of these projects ought to look to providing electricity generating facilities themselves, whilst acknowledging that even the biggest smelters may not justify the creation of a generating plant just to service a particular smelter. Certainly, this would bring home to the manufacturers of aluminium or to those implementing any other major projects of that type the proper cost involved in producing aluminium.

I turn now to taxation. I think the most interesting point the Committee makes in that respect is a point it has made in previous reports. At the end of the section headed 'Commonwealth Taxation' at page 28 the Committee states:

The Committee believes that any review of the current taxation applying to resources based industries should include consideration of the use of a resource rent tax or other variable tax on profit. Where an industry's profitability provides a return on its investment significantly greater than that necessary to call forth the investment in the first place then there are valid reasons for considering a higher rate of tax on that 'excess' return on investment. This is particularly the case where, in the provision of services such as electricity to industry, there is some justification for believing that the full value of the resources used to provide that service are not being recovered from the purchaser.

I think it is most important that this Senate Committee has renewed that plea for the national government to look once again at the possibility of levying a resource rent tax. The fact is that Mr Stone, in a suitably qualified answer, said that he thought there might be an area where it could properly be considered. One finds it intolerable to continue reading, for example, that the Northern Territory Government is considering levying a profits-related royalty of some 35 per cent on a pre-tax net profit on various projects getting under way in the Northern Territory. I know that that proposition has been put on the back burner for a while. But it was reported only last Thursday in the Age that the Western Australian Government has established by agreement with the Ashton joint venturers a tax regime which will allow that Government to levy a 22 1/2 per cent profits related tax once profits reach a trigger level of $20m per annum. That is a resources rent tax. It is a tax on profits from these highly profitable industries which are using our great natural resources.

The tragedy is that insofar as the national Government hesitates, holds back and refuses to impose such a tax in order to capture the benefit of these projects for all Australians, the State and Territory governments will move in to fill the gap and will lock in the benefits and revenues being generated by these projects for themselves. May I say-the Committee found this to be so-that the unions will also move in and take some of the high profitability for those directly employed in or contracting to these great projects. We say that the Federal Government has a very real role in this field and should reconsider the question of national resources rent tax.

On the question of ownership, I think it is very important to note that the Committee-I do not know whether this is the first time that a Senate committee has said this-has pointed out on page 32 of its report:
Foreign ownership, particularly where the Australian branch is only part of a highly mobile transnational operation, carries with it a number of risks.
This is the view of a Senate committee which was composed of members from both sides of the chamber. The report continues:

First among these is that corporate interest in the exploitation and processing of resources does not necessarily coincide with national interest. The pace at which an industry may wish to develop a resource or to expand (or contract) its manufacturing capacity will often not coincide with national interest. That is the view of a Senate committee. I think it is most significant that we have said it in the context of this industry. This industry, with its international aspect is, I believe, good for Australia. It is necessary that great international operators within the aluminium industry come to Australia mainly to give us access to markets. But having said that, the Committee is firmly of the view that Australia's participation is sensible as a means of attempting to ensure arms length pricing for bauxite and alumina so that taxation strategies can be properly pursued by the Australian community.

I am not so concerned about Australia's participation in sharing the profits from these projects. Dividends form only a very small part of the wealth that is generated within the community by such activities. I state as a personal aside that I know Senator Watson disagrees with me on that. But the Committee as a whole is concerned that the Government should bring into harmony its Australian participation guidelines in relation to the mining and manufacturing sectors. In respect of mining, a 50 per cent target is set for Australian participation in these great projects whereas for the manufacturing sector-and aluminium smelting is regarded as manufacturing-Australian participation is not required if the overseas project developer can demonstrate that there will be significant economic benefits.

What we are saying is that the distinction between the manufacturing and the mining sectors for the purposes of the guidelines on Australian participation in these industries is extremely artificial because what we are talking about is the control, the disposal and the depletion of Australian natural resources, the provision of infrastructure, the bringing into play of all the factors of production, including employment, of course. We think the distinction between the manufacturing and mining sectors in this regard is entirely artificial.

As to employment, I think the main significant role of this Committee lies in its final scotching of the use of multipliers as a means of assessing the value to the Australian people of these types of projects or perhaps of any project. We do so on the basis that in their formulation one has a difficulty; there is also a difficulty on the part of commentators to draw socially useful conclusions from any multipliers that one might find to be valid. A variety of multipliers were presented to us. They were in a range which demonstrated that the flow on of jobs from the very small base of jobs actually involved in these industries is something that just cannot be properly gauged. One might also ask whether, in fact, any jobs will be created in the economy by these projects. I emphasise, to Senator Messner's amazement, the word 'created' because a lot of these jobs are simple transfers. This is most obvious in the construction stage where workers merely move from one construction site to another. There is not a creation of jobs; there is a continuity of jobs for several hundreds or thousands of construction workers moving from site to site.

One of the worries we had was that even in the production stage of these great projects the aluminium industry will be calling on persons already employed in the work force and taking them away from certain jobs with higher offers of wages thereby perhaps causing a breakdown in other areas of the economy presently using the skills of those attracted to these industries. There is not much evidence for even a direct creation of jobs within the economy and there is very little evidence that the multipliers sometimes used can be justified. What leads the Committee to welcome this industry within various regions and States within Australia is that the wealth generated is substantial. That wealth flows out into the economy as a whole and creates jobs.

Let us stop talking about direct job creation and let us stop talking about multipliers; let us start talking about the really beneficial impact of the presence of these industries within Australia as is demonstrated on page 5 of our report. We looked at the operations by Alcoa of Australia in 1980 and found that it made the following payments within Australia: Taxes and royalties, $100m; dividends, $23m; interest and other expenses, $7m; and materials, wages and services, $566m. That is where the benefit to Australia lies, and that is what ought to be emphasised rather than the illusory multipliers that are sometimes tossed around.

The Committee has some very interesting points to make about industrial infrastructure which Senator Thomas adequately dealt with. Social infrastructure is also vitally important. It was to the great regret of the Committee that at the very time when we were engaged in this inquiry the razor gang came down with its report and recommended-I believe the Government followed the recommendation-the abolition of the various regional assistance schemes established by the Commonwealth Government. For example, both in the Hunter Valley and Gladstone regions we believed that there was a strong case for implementing those regional development policies of the national government, particularly in view of the Commonwealth's enthusiastic promotion of the various industries contributing to the social problems being faced by those regions. I am speaking here of the Commonwealth's positive regional adjustment policies which include a range of schemes. We, as a Committee, recommend that the Commonwealth Government undo that razor gang recommendation and that the Commonwealth Government should, once again, undertake schemes and policies which help to allay some of the social disruption and disintegration which can occur as these great projects come into already settled communities.

Finally, we dealt with the matter of the environment. I will say, as briefly as I am able, that the Senate Committee was totally opposed to the use by West Australian conservation interests of the courts of a foreign nation in order to pursue their particular protests at the degradation, as they see it, of the Darling Ranges by the bauxite mining activities either undertaken or proposed. The Committee is very conscious of the fact that those conservationists felt they had to go outside the Australian jurisdiction because the legal and political processes within Australia are inadequate. Therefore, the Committee recommends very strongly that, when the Law Reform Commission brings down its report on locus standi, as soon as possible, as a matter of urgency, steps to be taken to liberalise the access of conservation groups to the courts so that they can, at least within the legal jurisdiction of this country, bring their point of view to bear.

As to the political processes of this country, we found that projects were going ahead, particularly in the Hunter Valley and in the Darling Ranges, where some of the facts have not been sufficiently established, including the effect of fluoride emassions on vines and the salinity problems in the Perth water supply, and, worse still, some of the environmental impact undertakings given by these project developers are not shown to be capable of realisation. I refer particularly to the Darling Ranges where one found from the Worsley joint venturers statements of pious hope that they can achieve certain objects; but the Commonwealth Department itself, in its assessment of the project developers report on the matter, says that it doubts whether those hopes can be realised. We recommend that those Commonwealth department reports be published in respect of all these developments and that the Commonwealth refuses to take the passive and secondary role to State environmental authorities which it is presently taking. There is a clear need for an independent national assessment of the environmental impact of these various projects.

The Committee concludes overall that the national Government has totally abdicated its proper and necessary role to harness the pace and the scope of the development of these particular industries within Australia in order to achieve desirable overall national social goals. The national Government has abdicated in favour of an alliance between State governments and these project developers. We believe that that alliance cannot secure overall national goals. For that reason, we hope that this report will be of benefit to the Australian community and will alert the national Government to its responsibilities. We will look forward to its response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the conclusion of this session of Parliament is imminent, I understand that there has been a gentleman's agreement between the two Whips that this debate be truncated. It is rather unfortunate that this report by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources has come in at this late stage. But I do not intend to upset that agreement. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted, debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will not take the time of the Senate unduly. As a long serving member of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, I feel that the time restrictions placed upon us at this late stage are most unwarranted. I did not want to intervene on Senator Watson. He has sought leave to continue his remarks and he will continue his remarks when this matter comes on for debate at some later stage. I join with the Chairman of the Committee in complimenting the staff for the fine work they have done, particularly the Secretary, Derek Abbott, who has been with this Committee on other inquiries. The members of the Committee know only too well the dedication of this man and the work that he and his staff do.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why I sought leave to speak was to refer to one specific part of this report which relates to taxation. The Chairman has already referred to this section, which states:

The function of the taxation system is to ensure that the Australian community as a whole receives a fair return on resources employed and profits generated within the aluminium industry. The present unco-ordinated range of State and Federal taxes and royalties do not achieve this. Taken in conjunction with the structure of the aluminium industry they povide many opportunities for tax minimisation and avoidance.

I recommend to those people who may be listening or who will read the fine remarks of my colleague, Senator Tate, that they avail themselves of a copy of the report to the then Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Rex Connor, by T. M. Fitzgerald published in April 1974, entitled 'The Contribution of the Mineral Industry to Australian Welfare'. If people who are interested to read the report on the development of the bauxite alumina and aluminium industries read this other report on taxation in the mining industry in conjunction with that report, they will then be able to understand what has been said in our report about taxation as it applies to the mining industry in this country and how the mining industry is not providing all of the things for this country which it leads the people of this country to believe that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As is obvious from the speech of the Chairman of the Committee, Senate Tate's learned speech and the concern of Senator Watson and Senator McLaren, this is a report of considerable importance, particularly to Tasmania and Queensland. Yesterday, on 24 November, we were greeted with two reports in the newspapers, one in the Australian Financial Review and the other in the Canberra Times, not only releasing the gist of what was in the report but also containing comments on it by the Chairman of the Committee and another Government member of the Committee. In the past when the pre-release, or leaking, of reports has occurred the person responsible-I note that one of them is present now-or at least inadvertently responsible for the release, has apologised to the Senate for what is legally, one would suspect, a breach of privilege. That has not occurred in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: Reports such as this are reports to the Senate. As such they should not be released until they are reported to the Senate. They should not be released until they are reported to the Senate. The reasons for this are obvious from the point of view of privilege but the established procedure also means that when a report is presented in this place we have a balanced debate from both sides of the House. In this case the gist of the report was released. Members of the Committee from one side of the House took it upon themselves to comment in the Press on what was in the report. One could, I suppose, refer this case to the Committee of Privileges. I have no intention of doing so. But if this procedure continues-it is not the first time it has happened-people on either side of the House will feel under no obligation to recognise the privilege of a report or the conventions of this place. I hope that the early release of Senate reports does not happen again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. I was one of the Government senators mentioned in the newspaper reports referred to by Senator Grimes. I completely reject the accusation, certainly on my part, about leaking parts of the report. I shall indicate the sequence of events. I was approached by a media person who said that he wished to flag the release of the report. I made two responses to him. Firstly I said I believed this report was one of the most significant to reach the Senate. I did not elaborate on that; it was a firm statement of fact. I then stated as a second point that significant events had occurred since the conclusion of the hearings for that report.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those significant events was that aluminium prices on the London metal exchange had reached a low. I said that this must have some sort of bearing on the outcome of the report. That was the extent of the statements that I made. I believe that neither of those statements reflected in any way the content of that report. Therefore, I must reject any imputation that I was involved in leaking details of the report. I am proud to have been a member of that Committee. It took a lot of time but, I believe, came out with some fairly momentous decisions. As such, I believe that we should acknowledge the fact that it is an important report but the contents of the article could not be attributable in any way to the two statements that I made.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Martin) agreed to:

That, for the purpose of the inquiry by the Senate House Committee into the organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department, referred to the Committee by Resolution of the Senate on 29 October 1981-
(1) The President shall not be a member of the Committee.
(2) The Committee shall consist of six Senators.
(3) The quorum of the Committee shall be three.
(4) The Committee shall elect a Government Senator as Chairman.

(5) The Chairman may from time to time appoint a member of the Committee to be Deputy Chairman and the member so appointed shall act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(6) In the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy-Chairman when acting as Chairman, shall have a casting vote.

(7) The Committee shall have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.
(8) The Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.

(9) The Committee shall be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it; and a daily Hansard shall be published of such proceedings of the Committee as take place in public.
(10) The Committee shall be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources with the approval of the President.
(11) The Committee shall present a final Report as soon as possible.
(12) If the Senate be not sitting when the Committee has completed its Report-
(a) the Committee may send the Report to the President of the Senate or, if the President is unable to act due to illness or other cause, to the Deputy-President of the Senate;
(b) the Report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate and the President or the Deputy-President is authorised to give directions for its printing and circulation; and
(c) in such event, the President or the Deputy-President shall lay the Report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(13) The foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES BILL 1981TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES BILL 1981

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it would probably meet the convenience of the Senate to discuss the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 and the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 in a cognate debate with separate questions being put at each stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree to that procedure being followed, Mr President. The Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 is a Bill which corrects a mistake made in the original Social Services Amendment Bill 1981 which came into this chamber a couple of weeks ago. It corrects a difficulty in the payment of double orphans pensions to people who care for refugee children. It is a sensible amendment and we do not oppose it. The Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 is a different matter. The aims of this Bill are to refuse payment of unemployment benefit and associated children's allowances to the spouses, in most cases the wives, of those trade unionists who are involved in industrial action or who, indirectly, have been stood down as a result of industrial action by their union, even though it be interstate or hundreds of miles away, although in every other way these spouses qualify in their own right for benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Its second aim is to refuse payments of unemployment benefits to the wives of those who fail the work test-those who, in the eyes of the Government, voluntarily and without good reason give up their jobs or are dismissed for misconduct, even though their spouses qualify in their own right for benefits. It also aims to refuse special benefit to all those groups unless they are in what the Government defines as extreme hardship. This legislation is wrong in principle and discriminatory in action. It is a wrong use of the Social Services Act in this country in that it attempts to use this Act to prevent or shorten industrial action by depriving innocent people of benefits they would otherwise have a right to. The Bill attempts to deprive of any assistance the utterly innocent wives and children of those whom the Government disapproves of and as such it is abhorrent.

The Bill will not achieve its stated intention of preventing unionists from taking industrial action, nor will it reduce the numbers who are affected by the Government's increasingly harsh regulations for the unemployed. So, it is a futile exercise. The Bill has no measurable effect on the Budget. No attempt has been made to quantify the expenditure likely to be saved, and it is not justified on any economic ground. The Bill is in fact an expression of the Government's prejudice against trade unionists and those it sees as voluntarily unemployed. It extends this prejudice to action against their wives and children. We oppose this Bill, as we opposed such clauses on a previous occasion when they were introduced in the original Social Services Amendment Bill.

I will deal, first of all, with those clauses of the Bill which affect the spouses of unionists involved in or affected by industrial disputes. It is worth recalling one of the most far reaching strikes in the past five years-the Victorian power dispute between 27 September and 19 October 1977, the La Trobe Valley dispute. At that time the Government had not passed the infamous amendments classifying as a striker anyone stood down who belonged to a union involved in an industrial dispute, whether he approved, disapproved or even had no knowledge of the strike or dispute in question. When that strike occurred a Commonwealth Government spokesman estimated that 500,000 people had been stood down though fewer than 60,000 had registered for unemployment benefits, 3,000 of them in other States. At that time the Government also dithered for some days while entertaining the suggestion that the stood-down workers as well as the strikers would be refused unemployment benefits. This proposed action was the source of much speculation in the Press and in this Parliament. It is interesting to look again at the opposition then to what was a possible policy change. The Victorian State Minister for Social Welfare, Mr Dixon, a member of the Liberal Party, said:
It's stupid to use unemployment benefits as a possible lever in an industrial dispute and such a move would be ill-advised and ill-considered.

Mr Dixon also warned of the possibility of family breakdowns if benefits were not paid. The Age reported that Mr Peter Falconer, then chairman of the Government's back bench industrial relations committee, had urged the Government to reconsider such proposals because they would affect a large number of rank and file members who would find their benefits cut. The same report stated that the present member for Boothby, then Senator Steele Hall, had said that the Government was making the innocent do its dirty work for it and that the proposal was unjust. These remarks made by three Liberal members of parliament four years ago are as valid now about this legislation as they were then and they represent part of the Opposition's case against this confrontationist legislation.

I think it is worth while quoting from some editorial comment on the same Government proposal from newspapers not noted for being in sympathy with workers in industrial disputes. The Melbourne Herald said:

. . . it would be outrageous to deny sustenance to stood-down unionists and their families not involved in the dispute. The Government should take care that no substance exists for such stories in future.
The Age said:
Unemployment benefits should be regarded as a right for people jobless through no fault of their own. They are not a privilege and they most certainly are not a plaything for politicians.
Finally, the Canberra Times called it:
. . . a threat to the right of freedom of opinion, a denial of justice to taxpayers, and a perversion of the conventional definition of what constitutes unemployment.

In this Bill the Government goes much further than it proposed to then and penalises more innocent and powerless people-the wives and children of those involved. How much more valid now is the criticism which was made at that time? The Government, in a disgraceful and dishonest manner, has in both the second reading speech and in the explanatory notes referred only to the application of this renewed Bill to the spouses of 'strikers'-as the Government calls them-or of 'persons involved in industrial action'. There is no indication from the Government that it includes as strikers people who may have been opposed to the dispute, as were the Geelong Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd workers who voted against joining the Broadmeadow Ford workers on strike, but who were stood down just the same. Likewise, it includes as strikers people in a union whose counterpart branch in another State has closed down the works, resulting in their being stood down because there is a shortage of essential parts. I feel sure that some unionists do not even know why they are so penalised when they are stood down through no actions of their own.

The Government has perverted the definition of 'striker'. In this legislation and particularly in the speech of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) the Government is trying to whip up an emotional climate of hostility to the union movement. This legislation, which could impoverish families, not because the wives are married to strikers but because they are married to trade unionists and they are in single income families, is unjust. The Minister is dishonest in pretending that the Bill will affect only strikers' wives. But he will not admit that dishonesty because it would affect the hysterical rhetoric, for that rhetoric, combined with the attempted intimidation of the trade union movement, forms the regrettable objectives of Senator Chaney and his colleagues on this issue. The Government pays lip service to the right of trade unions to exist and the right of trade unionists to take action in the interests of their members-a right which distinguishes free countries from totalitarian countries. The Government praises the development of an independent trade union movement in Poland but discriminates against our own. The Government's action in putting the wives and families of unionists in the firing line surely contradicts any commitment to a free trade union movement.

I think we should look at the facts of industrial disputes in Australia. The most recent statistical information I have is from an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey released last August which refers to 1980. In that year 65 per cent of all industrial disputes lasted two days or less, involving 79 per cent of all the workers in industrial disputes-that is, only 21 per cent of strikers were involved in disputes lasting longer than two days. Only 8.9 per cent of all strikers were involved in disputes that lasted 10 days or longer. It is worth remembering that unemployment benefits are payable only after a seven day waiting period. The major causes of disputes were directly attributable to management. In 39.7 per cent of the disputes managerial policy was given as the prime cause and in 19.6 per cent of the disputes physical working conditions were given as the cause. Only 21.5 per cent of the disputes were about wages. These facts make nonsense of the Minister's statement:
. . . trade unions can choose to strike, knowing that through the operations of the social security system, their members can be legally insulated from the financial effects of their action.
This is compounded further by the statement:

There have been numerous cases where the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the workforce themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them.

The figures show that the cases obviously have not been numerous. There has been no attempt by the Minister in his second reading speech to quantify this statement about numerous cases because to quantify it would be to contradict it. The statement is an expression of prejudice. It is not an expression of fact. I draw attention to another misleading section of Senator Chaney's speech and I quote a paragraph which demonstrates his contempt for Australian wage earners. He said:

Unless frivolously or maliciously entered into, the object of a strike is to obtain, by the exercise of economic pressure against the employer, a benefit for those who take such action. As a result, the benefit sought is itself economic, such as increased pay, a shorter working week, or special allowances. Not infrequently, strikes are settled on a basis that effectively compensates those who have gone on strike for pay lost during the duration of the strike.

The Minister stated as fact that workers taking industrial action for reasons other than to increase wages are motivated by malice, and frivolity. I draw to his attention the figures that I have just cited. The major cause of dispute was found by the ABS survey to be managerial policy. Physical conditions were stated to be the important factor in some 20 per cent of cases. Almost 60 per cent of cases were directly attributed to management and physical conditions; not to malice, frivolity or even economic gain. On the economic side, I suppose the 5.3 per cent of disputes involving hours of work, pensions, leave and compensation could be added to the 21.5 per cent of stoppages involving wages.

I do not necessarily share Senator Chaney's view that the economic factors behind these disputes resulted in great gain. Many would be desperate attempts to stop the erosion of wages and salaries which has occurred as a result of the Government's deliberate attempt to shift the economic burden to low income groups. Only a certain percentage of stoppages would have been successful and only a proportion of those would have financially compensated the workers for the pay lost during the strike. I believe Senator Chaney is making totally unwarranted assumptions about the purposes of industrial disputes, about the incidence and success of industrial disputes and about the economic effects of those disputes on strikers' families.

The Minister also referred to trade union members being largely insulated from the financial effects of their actions and in doing so tried not only to make a distinction between strikers and taxpayers but also to identify them as people with opposing interests. I will deal now with this attempt to set strikers and taxpayers at odds. Almost every person in the work force is a taxpayer. Certainly all full time workers pay tax on a pay-as-you-earn basis which does not lend itself to the tricks and devices of some of our wealthier citizens, who pay little tax but who are the most self-righteous in condemning unemployed people, welfare costs and workers. Taxes from wage and salary earners pay all Government services and subsidies. Why should the community pick up the bill for the support of hundreds of millions of dollars worth of assistance to primary and secondary industry yet not, as Senator Chaney wants it, for the family of a worker stood down as the result of a dispute when that family has no other means of support?

The cost of paying spouses of workers on strike or stood down is not even a significant part of the welfare bill, let alone of Government outlays. Only 111,000 people last year were involved in strikes lasting longer than five days and only 54,000 in strikes lasting longer than 10 days. Unemployment benefit is not paid for the first seven days after application; therefore, only between 60,000 and 70,000 workers were affected. The ABS survey does not give a breakdown as to how many were married or had dependants. However, we know that just over one-third of the work force is unmarried so we may suppose that perhaps 45,000 married workers last year were involved in industrial disputes at a time when their spouses might have been eligible for unemployment benefits. Of those 45,000 unionists with families, probably half have working spouses and would be ineligible for unemployment benefits on income grounds. Where a person from a two income family goes on strike or is stood down, that family goes from being a two-income to a one-income family over that period. The family is obviously in temporary trouble but is in no way a charge on the taxpayers. What happens to the one-income family is the point at issue. It is against the one-income family that this legislation is specifically aimed.

As I have demonstrated, I believe, not unfairly, probably no more than 20,000 such families each year could apply for the unemployment benefit or the special benefit for basic food and shelter for one or two days, or at the most for a few weeks. Experience shows that, if a strike looks as though it will be prolonged, the breadwinner goes out and seeks temporary or part time work. The breadwinner is then not entitled to unemployment benefit; neither is his spouse.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I was speaking of how the provisions of this Bill relating to industrial disputes are aimed particularly at single income families, at the innocent wives and children of those who are involved in a dispute and at those who are indirectly affected by a dispute of which they have no knowledge and in fact may oppose and which may be taking place many hundreds of kilometres away in another State. It takes away the rights of a group of women who, under our legislation at the moment, qualify under strict rules for unemployment benefits. I pointed out that these people are not insulated, as Senator Chaney has suggested, from the effects of industrial disputes by the social services legislation as it exists now. This legislation is also aimed at and will fall heavily upon another group, namely, the group of low income families involved in industrial disputes. It will fall heavily on the $200-a-week families with three children such as those who were involved in the recent Broadmeadows strike. Such families are already $8 a week below the Henderson poverty line. They are often in debt and often are struggling to survive. It is under these very conditions, of course, that we get industrial disputes frequently.
—They are always in debt. They are never out of debt.

—They are never out of debt, as Senator Chipp says. The $200-a-week family with three children will have its income reduced by $100 a week under the present legislation. That family can in no way be considered to be insulated from the effects of that dispute by the social services provisions. The Uniting Church Welfare Agency, CARE, which operates in the Broadmeadows area, has paid out $6,000 to families affected by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd strike and calculates that the amount would have been three times that figure if social services had not been available. Even then, that voluntary agency does not reach all affected families. Some do not know that such agencies exist and some are too proud to apply for relief.

SPEECH.PARA: Families under these conditions are under strain already. They will be placed under even more strain by this legislation. Senator Chaney referred in his speech to the absurdity that benefits should be paid to strikers or their families and that they should be paid by the community at large. I suggest that he read the Victorian Council of Social Service report 'Too little too late' on the Victorian power dispute of 1977. It said:

Who is or should be responsible for ensuring some basic level of income maintenance for people who, through no fault of their own, are left without income. During the strike this responsibility was borne, by default, by the relief organisations who were not geared to it either financially or administratively.

Those who were indirectly involved at the time will remember that the Salvation Army had to close its doors and the disputes and scuffles that broke out outside the Salvation Army office in Clayton, a Melbourne suburb, when up to 500 men and women lined up for very basic assistance.

This section of the Bill is an attack on trade unionists and their families. It is an attack on low income married people with children and on the single income families. These are the least insulated from the problems of our economic system, and for that reason I believe this section should be rejected by the Senate. I am not one of those who believe that unjustified industrial disputes do not sometimes occur. I am not one of those who say that all strikes are justified and that the prolongation of strikes is always justified. However, I am certainly not one of those who suggest that the way to overcome this problem is to use the social services legislation in this community instead of sensible and good industrial relations and instead of having trade union reform which will reduce this sort of dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if they are unjustified, you don't get at the wives and the kids.

—I am coming to that. Of course we do not hit at the innocent people, the wives and children who are involved. In fact, this sort of legislation will not reduce that militancy; it is likely to make it worse. It is likely to make worse the distinctions between them and us, as seen by more militant unionists, and in fact exacerbate the industrial situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to that section of the Bill which excludes from benefits those people whose spouses have failed the work test, who are deemed to be voluntarily unemployed, or who are deemed to have lost work through misconduct. Senator Chaney and his colleagues have a firm and final prejudice in respect of the people involved in this section of the legislation. In the final sentence of his second reading speech he said:
This Bill prevents them from manipulating the social security system to shift the consequence of their actions.

This succinct sentence sums up all the prejudices of the conservatives in this Government about the unemployed. Senator Chaney is talking about married umemployed people, many of whom have children. In particular, he is talking about a small group of wives of unemployed persons who have fallen foul of the Department of Social Security. He is painting them as cold-blooded manipulators of the system. The statement demonstrates more the blind prejudice of the Government. I suggest that the real manipulators in our community are the tax evaders, those who rort the subsidy and incentive systems, not the disadvantaged who are attacked in this Bill.

The married unemployed have very little opportunity to manipulate any aspect of their environment. They live below the poverty line.
