They suffer from the continual changes in government instructions to treat them more and more roughly, a policy which, for the Government, has two benefits; appearing to cut down the number of unemployed and then cutting down on the unemployment benefit payout. The Government's complaint in this case is that where a person is married and unemployed and has a suspension of between six weeks and 12 weeks without any payment, the spouse has been known to apply for unemployment benefit on his or her account with additional benefit if there are children. The Government's proposal is to stop this. I remind the Senate that, since 1979, the suspension of payment is mandatory on social security officers for alleged offences such as failing the work test, being dismissed for improper conduct, or being voluntarily unemployed. The financial penalties for these alleged breaches of the law are considerable-between $300 and $600 for a single person and between $600 and $1,200 for a family unemployed with dependants. These penalties are applied arbitrarily and, in fact, are heavier than most fines applied by magistrates or judges for serious offences such as drink-driving. These penalties are to be added to by this legislation.

There are other difficulties, as I pointed out earlier when this legislation was before the Senate. There are difficulties in interpretation of the regulations. A research paper produced by the Minister's Department in June of this year entitled 'Work Test Failure-A Sample Survey of Terminations of Unemployment Benefit' had this to say:

It is therefore desirable that administrative information systems should be designed or redesigned so as to enable more to be known of who is affected by policies and programs and what the effects are . . . we cannot say with confidence even how many work-test terminations occur.

If the Minister gets his way on this legislation we know that families will be very seriously affected. We know that the basis on which this legislation has been put forward is very vague and that there is insufficient information-a fact admitted by the Department itself. All the evidence from the Henderson report, from voluntary agencies, and now from the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat on the measurement of poverty, has named the unemployed 'amongst the poorest'. They have no reserves upon which to live. They already form, with single parent families, the most frequent attenders at agencies which dispense emergency relief. But this is not enough. The Government wants to add to their numbers. But it will not even add many to their numbers. The work test failure accounts for 1.6 per cent of the terminations of unemployment benefit. This is in no way a major problem to the Government, economically or socially. Each month there are 1,000 postponements of benefits of which 300 are married beneficiaries. This is a very small group and will continue to be a very small group.

On this subject many of those women and children who will be affected by this section of the legislation are married to persons who have psychological problems, drinking problems which may not be obvious, or emotional problems which put them in a situation where they are likely to be considered out of work through misconduct or voluntary action when they are seen by officers of the Department of Social Security-the sort of person who may abuse the foreman or boss in anger or who throws in his job on the spur of the moment in times of stress. Are we, as a Senate and as a Parliament, seriously suggesting that a wife and her children should suffer through the deprivation of being married to such a person? Are we saying to her that she should leave him to get social security benefits and thus worsen the situation for him and in many cases for her and her children? The Government has given no thought to the complex interpersonal relations which lie behind this group of the unemployed. To satisfy crude prejudices of the Government and its supporters, the Government will throw these people on the scrap heap. We believe very sincerely that the Government should think again about this matter and this is a further reason why we will oppose this Bill.

To say that the Bill provides, in cases of extreme hardship that the special benefit should be made available is, we believe, the final difficulty which the Government is going to put in the way of these people. Special benefit is not a large benefit; it is difficult to apply for and it is hedged about by definitions of hardship and need which are the strictest in our social security legislation. The inevitable result of this will be to add to the administrative difficulties of those who work in social security offices and add to the harassment that these people frequently feel. The whole basis of this legislation is the belief by the Government that the legislation can be massively represented by it to the people of this community as preventing the Government and the taxpayer from supporting people who do not deserve to be supported. The fact that the emphasis in the speech of the Minister for Social Security in this place, the speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) when the Bill went through another place and the frequent references of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on television is on the wives of strikers and no reference is made to the wives of those indirectly involved in industrial action-those stood down by industrial action with which they have no part-or those who are voluntarily unemployed demonstrates to us that what the Government is about is a massive misrepresentation for political purposes with very little concern being shown for the small groups of people who will be affected very badly and very severely by this legislation.

This legislation has been condemned not only by the Opposition but also by all voluntary agencies in the community which know that in times of industrial dispute they will suffer the fate that they suffered during the Latrobe Valley power strike a few years ago. Voluntary agencies will bear the burden of the Government's actions and they will be inadequately supported for taking over the Government's role in that situation. I repeat, that if the Government wants proper industrial relations in this community it should look at its own industrial relations policy and at trade union reform and not use a piece of legislation-the Social Services Act-which has been designed to help those who are in need through no fault of their own. Until the Government does that, we will oppose this discriminatory and divisive legislation. We will continue to oppose it because it has no place on the legislative books in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to Senator Grimes, I am convinced more than ever that the real argument is about who carries responsibility ulitmately for union decisions. The effect on wives and children rests with the striker. Most husbands, I believe, would take grave exception to the proposition that anyone else should be responsible for their wives and children. The bottom line of argument in this debate is whether trade unions or trade union members generally ought to be financially responsible for their actions or whether taxpayers should pay for the decisions and actions of the trade union movement. The question really is whether Australian taxpayers should pay the cost of not only industrial disruption, social disruption, loss of productivity, loss of wages, and the inevitable flow-on of costs and charges which follows strikes but also the wages of those who are party to the imposition which is cast upon the community. I say from the outset that I believe this legislation is eminently reasonable, eminently fair and eminently responsible. I have no hesitation in supporting it to the full. I believe this legislation will have wide appeal.
—It shows that you have not even read it.

—I believe that it will have wide appeal not only to the great majority of Australians but also to the great majority of the trade union movement. There are those amongst us who would seduce the community into the belief that government can and should provide for redemption of all sins and that the government should ultimately carry the responsibility for decisions which are made by the community. I believe that the great majority of the community, including trade union members, do not subscribe to that view. If this legislation is being opposed on the basis of some misguided compassion, perhaps we ought to direct our attention and concern to the people who are really unemployed; I refer to those who, for reasons quite beyond their control, are unable to secure jobs for themselves. Before we spread the jam a little more thinly, perhaps we ought to pause for a moment to reflect upon the statistics and the circumstances of those who are unemployed, who have dependants and who claim benefits not because their spouse has voluntarily gone on strike, in many cases to improve their wages and conditions, but simply because they just cannot find work.

SPEECH.PARA: For a moment, we ought to put aside the strikers and concern ourselves with those unemployed married bread earners who receive one-third of the average minimum wage and those unemployed single people over the age of 18 who survive on 20 per cent of the minimum average wage. There are presently approximately 168,000 people under the age of 25 years registered for unemployment benefits. In May this year, of those receiving unemployment benefits, 24,000 had been seeking work for more than one month. Without going through the whole detail, I point out that 44,500 had been seeking work for over three months and 13,000 had been seeking work for more than 12 months. Of those in the older work force category, 134,500 of those receiving unemployment benefits are above the age of 25. Of those, 20,000 have been without work in excess of two years and something like 75,000 of all recipients of unemployment benefits have some sort of family responsibility by way of a spouse or by way of children. Surely these are the sorts of people to whom we ought to be directing our energy, concern and compassion. These are the people who ought to be provided with 100 per cent of the funds allocated for unemployment benefit. These are the people who genuinely are unable to attract work and are required to live on the unemployment benefit.

Unlike the strikers, 93.5 per cent of these people have no other source of income. These are the people who do not have access to strike funds. These are the people who cannot mitigate their taxation by having a couple of weeks off. These are the people who cannot go back to work after a strike and work overtime to make up for every single cent that they have lost. These are the people who cannot do sweetheart deals with unions and get backpay for the time they were out of work. It seems thoroughly immoral to me that these people have to forgo their only means of income to allow strikers the luxury of having added benefits by way of unemployment benefits while they are on strike. The Government's record in the last two years in terms of employment is very commendable. The level of employment has increased by 348,000 or 5.7 per cent in that period. In the last full year alone, another 115,800 full time occupations were created. It is a great credit to the Government that, given the financial circumstances in which it finds itself, still suffering from the effects of the past Labor Government, it has been able to achieve this. But, at this time, that is cold comfort to those who are still required to live on unemployment benefits. They require every single dollar that they can get.

A great many strikes that occur in this country are thoroughly unrelated to industrial matters, that is, matters relating to employer-employee conditions. Many of these strikes, during which the Opposition wants wives of strikers to be paid are, as I said, quite unrelated to wage demands, hours of work or working conditions. In fact, in 1980 alone, 93,000 workers were involved in strikes which were totally unrelated to the normal industrial relations negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you include safety issues in those statistics?

—Yes, I certainly do, but not within that figure of 93,000. They are excluded by definition. The 93,000 includes unionism by definition. I am sure that Labor Party experts will know all about it. That figure includes strikes relating to other causes, including political strikes and sympathetic strikes for political causes. In addition, something like 400,000 working days and $22m in wages were lost through this category of strikes. Is anyone seriously suggesting that taxpayers should pay a striker because he decides to stay home because of some alleged political belief? Is anyone seriously suggesting, in this day and age, that a further burden should be placed upon the community to accommodate the irresponsible and delinquent actions and activities of some trade union members? I believe the great majority of the community do not support that proposition. Is it not enough that as a result of such actions $22m was lost in wages and millions of dollars more were lost in export earnings and productivity? Of course, there must be a point in time when accountability has to be accommodated.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer honourable senators to the iron ore industry in Western Australia. It is an industry of enormous potential and, as has been demonstrated, it provides enormous wealth to the people of Australia and particularly to Western Australia. The iron ore industry in Western Australia employs 8,250 employees in the wages section-1.75 per cent of the total work force in Western Australia. In 1980 that 1.75 per cent of the Western Australian work force was responsible for 46 per cent of all man days lost in Western Australia. Between 1976 and 1981 strikes by that percentage of the work force accounted for something in excess of $35m in lost wages. In one strike $85m was lost to Australian taxpayers through loss of revenue. One of the great tragedies of those strikes is that 35 per cent of them are unrelated to employee-employer relationships. They fall within the category of unionism, political strikes or others. These are the strikes which fall within the category of the Opposition's ambition to have funds made available to the wives of the spouses who go on strike. Is it not enough to recognise that the average worker in the iron ore industry receives in excess of $21,000 a year for a 45-hour week? Invariably, when one company goes on strike, if it is a dispute of common interest, employees of other companies stay on and quite properly and quite reasonably provide the strikers with a strike fund. Of course, the question of finance will inevitably be a consideration as to whether the strike goes on in the first place. It will certainly have a very strong bearing on whether such a strike will have any importance in the first place, and on its duration. I do not believe that it is the most responsible allocation of our resources to compound that great loss by adding potentially millions of dollars more to the cost of industrial anarchy by asking the taxpayers to contribute. Besides the strikes to which I have referred, of course the record in Australia is not too bright. In 1980, 3.3 million man days and $152m in wages were lost due to strikes. One million employees in Australia were involved in strikes last year. Of course, millions of dollars more were lost in productivity and export earnings. In fact, the latest figure I could get shows that in 1979 $2 billion was lost to our economy by loss of productivity.

The argument has been put that it is both unfair and improper to use the provisions of the Social Services Act to attack the trade union movement. I submit that that is a thoroughly misleading suggestion and that the truth of the matter is that existing conditions not only encourage strikes but also encourage longevity of strikes. Clearly, any unionists being asked to strike will carefully take into consideration the cost-benefit considerations. He will naturally weigh up what he will ultimately receive compared with what it is costing him. He will ask himself whether he can afford to go on strike and how long he can be on strike. These are very reasonable and very proper considerations and they are the same sorts of considerations that employers involve themselves in. The employer has to ask himself how long his company can afford to be without services, without wages and without labour. He has to weigh up what the long term effects will be upon his factory. I should have thought that for very many families the payment of unemployment benefit plus a tax free payment of $10 for each child courtesy of the Australian taxpayer would have a significant effect on how long a strike lasts or whether it commences at all. If the unionist happens to be a man working for a mining company in the north-west of Western Australia or in the northern part of Queensland he will in all likelihood be living in a fully air-conditioned brick veneer home at approximately $22 per week and he will get free power, free electricity and free water with modest charges for excesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does he get that?
—Because of the need to attract people to those places. Nobody condemns that.
—The employer has to give those conditions to get workers to work in that environment.

—That is right. There is nothing wrong with that. Of course, as I have said, whenever there is a strike in one company in the Pilbara the employees of the other companies very wisely stay on the job and provide their fellow workers with strike relief. That is a fairly standard practice. It is a reasonable and proper course of action to take in respect of those on strike.

SPEECH.PARA: During the 1980 strike by Queensland coalminers over notional rents the Pilbara employees were in exactly the same situation. They could have been subject to the same taxation assessments. But they very wisely and very intelligently remained on the job and provided tens of thousands of dollars to those on strike in Queensland. I have considerable sympathy for that strike and for the arguments that were put forward by the strikers. But I think it goes to show and demonstrates that that sort of assistance, together with unemployment benefit, makes it possible for the strikes to be prolonged and it certainly enables the workers to be well equipped for a cold winter. I think under those circumstances, one can reasonably conclude that the Social Services Act, as presently constructed, provides a very real incentive not only for people to strike but also for people to stay on strike.

If we are to subsidise one party to an industrial dispute, presumably we should subsidise the other. It ought to be remembered that the majority of strikes in Australia affect that category of business which might properly be called small business. Every time there is a stoppage relating to power, transport, communications and essential services it is the small employer, the man who employs perhaps three or four people, who goes bankrupt. There are countless cases year after year of small businesses which, in the interests of industrial relations, go to the wall and as a result further jobs are lost. What recourse has John Citizen, the employer? Is he able to seek government help and support? Is he able to go to his colleagues and ask them for some sort of subsistence, some sort of carry-over money? When he goes bankrupt he is not able to move on gaily to another position. His losses may well be his life savings. He is condemned to the category of those who are no longer able to raise credit or even write out a cheque. He is certainly not able to move on with gay abandon, leaving all that behind him, putting it down to experience and seeking new work. He may well lose his home, his car and his life savings. What is his redress? It is absolutely nothing. His reward will not be future increased benefits. His reward for short term loss is not long term gain-it is invariably failure and that failure will be absolute. I speak not of the small businessman who is directly involved in negotiations with a union.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better not speak about your business activities.

—I invite the honourable senator to jump to his feet at any time he likes and enlarge on that. I speak not only of the small businessman who is a party to a dispute but also who is financially crippled as a result of a strike in which he has no vote, no say and no negotiating power. Then, of course, we have the small businessman whose only involvement in a dispute is the fact that he employs a category of worker who fits into one union and who, for reasons quite beyond his control and in some cases the union's control, is required to go on strike. What can the small businessman do about it? What is his recourse? He can do absolutely nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: We talk of the great inequity of union members who find themselves unable to work because of decisions made by their colleagues or decisions made by the leaders of the union whom they freely and democratically elected. What is the result for the poor businessman? He steadily but inexorably goes bankrupt. A number of reports in the media have highlighted the attitude of the unions. In one report the unions are reported to have said that what happened in the case of Mainline 'could not have happened to a nicer pack of bastards'. I put it to honourable senators that these people have no course, no redress. Is it not fair to say what is good for one side is good for the other? Do we ladle out money for the employee and ladle out money for the employer, or do we suddenly plead justice for the worker and injustice for the employer?

Thirdly, the situation may arise in which there is some direct conflict between the employer and the employee. Do we say it is proper for the employee to be given financial strength to arm him for the battle and walk away from the employer while the employer goes bankrupt, in part because ammunition is provided by taxation from the employer's earnings for the employee to beat him to death? To me it is an immoral ignominy that the employer's taxes are going towards his own destruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you cannot pronounce the words someone else writes for you, you should not use them.

—Senator Walsh could not even spell them. We have the examples of Wran, Hayden, Whitlam, Cameron and so many other people condemning these strikes as being illegal and irresponsible. These are the sorts of strikes during which honourable senators opposite want to provide the wives of strikers with some sort of benefit so they can have the privilege of staying home for whatever spurious reason is put forward. Over many years the principle of this legislation has been supported by previous Labor governments, particularly the Chifley Government. I think it is legislation of excellent virtue and I find it remarkable that, at a time when the great majority of taxpayers are calling out daily for reduced taxes, the Opposition seeks to impose future taxes upon the community to subscribe to increased benefits for those who do not need them. I strongly recommend this legislation to the Senate and I have no doubt that those provided with common sense will ensure its successful passage through this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is said that it is practically impossible to render a member of parliament speechless but Senator Crichton-Browne has just about achieved that result as far as I am concerned. I am simply not able to reply to any of the points he made for fear of being ruled by you, Mr President, as using unparliamentary language. It may come as a surprise to anybody listening to this debate, and it will certainly come as a surprise to anybody reading it, that in fact we are debating cognately two Social Services Amendment Bills, one of which is totally uncontentious but which is connected, with not some small irony, to one facet of the second Bill. The Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 is designed to correct a small anomaly in relation to refugee children. The second reading speech reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The existing legislation defines 'refugee child' in terms of a child granted refugee status by the Australian Government. There are, however, children who are admitted into Australia as refugees who do not have the formal status of refugee granted to them. The Government intends these children to fall within the class of children in respect of whom double orphans' pensions are payable.

I do not think anybody in this chamber feels that these children, innocent as they are of the problems that have befallen them, should not be helped in some way by the Australian Government and hence by the Australian taxpayer. The second Bill, the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981, is the result of the defeat in the Senate on 29 October of clauses 18 and 21 of the Social Services Amendment Bill. The second reading speech to that Bill reads:

This Bill now proposes that, for so long as a person's spouse is disqualified from receiving unemployment benefit because of involvement in industrial action; or unwillingness to undertake suitable work; or failure to take reasonable steps to obtain such work, that person will also be ineligible for unemployment benefit. Additionally, a person will be ineligible for unemployment benefit for so long as payment of that benefit to the person's spouse is postponed because of their misconduct as a worker, because they have become voluntarily unemployed or because they have failed to accept an offer of suitable employment.
Consistent with this approach, special benefit will also be withheld from persons not eligible for unemployment benefit in these circumstances.
The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) then went on to say:
. . . in a case of extreme hardship and where there are no other means of support, their spouse may-
I repeat, may-
be eligible for special benefit at the single rate, with additional benefit for any children.
At the end of my speech in the debate on the original Bill on 29 October, having criticised the Government at some length for avoiding the real issue, I said:
The Australian Democrats intend to do whatever we can to prevent them-
That is, clauses 18 and 21-
from becoming nothing more nor less than instruments of welfare harassment in an industrial relations situation.

I think that in bringing forward those two clauses in a separate Bill the Government has gone beyond what it first appeared to be doing-using the welfare system as a sort of industrial stick-and intends to use this legislation as an extremely socially divisive measure. Before I go on to elaborate a little more on that matter I wish to make a couple of other points. To begin with, this legislation sets out only to end an already existing situation. As the second reading speech pointed out, for some years now it has been possible for the spouse of a person involved in industrial action to apply after one week for the single unemployment benefit and for an additional amount if there were children. The single unemployment benefit, I might add, is $58.10 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong!
—Am I wrong? I am speaking of the single unemployment benefit.
—That is for a single person with dependants.
—With a child, yes.
—But for just the spouse of a worker it is $58.10.
—You are right.
—You have to be pretty certain when you interject on Senator Haines, Minister.

—I am always ready to be corrected if the correction is necessary. I repeat that the single unemployment benefit is $58.10 a week. It is not available for the first week of the industrial action, nor is it available to people who do not meet the family income test. In other words, like the old age pension, the unemployment benefit is means tested. Special benefit eligibility is liquid-asset tested as well as means tested and to qualify for that a family has to be practically destitute. The Government's argument is an extremely emotive one. I imagine that if the Government took it to the electorate with all of the drama it could muster-
—And all the money.

—Yes, and all the money-it would probably be an extremely successful one. The Government's argument is that the taxpayer should not be forced to subsidise the wives and children of men on strike. The second reading speech stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are not here concerned to discuss the merits of strike action . . . What we are concerned with is how the cost of strike action is to be borne . . . we do not believe that Australian taxpayers should be asked to subsidise strike action through the social welfare system. Trade unions choosing to take such action make a free decision to strike . . .

The legislation as it stands at the moment permits a situation where trade unions can choose to strike knowing that through the operation of the social security system their members can be largely insulated from the financial effect of their actions.

I took the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) to task over that statement about a month ago. I argued that anybody who tries to live for any length of time on $58.10 a week, $69.70, or even $89.70 if a person has two children, will not be living in the lap of luxury; nor will such a person find himself largely insulated from the financial effects of his actions. The point that the Minister wanted to emphasise and, indeed, did emphasise, was that to strike is an exercise in freedom of choice, one for which frequently the community suffers. I am not stupid enough to put the thesis that the community is never in any way injured by strike action. It is frequently inconvenienced, sometimes for a number of days and even a number of weeks. It is also on occasions severely hurt by the action that is taken. I repeat the point that I made on 29 October. Simply because some unions are irresponsible and because some unionists are irresponsible, that is no reason for the Government to become as irresponsible, although in a different way. Simply because some people abuse the system, that is no justification for coming up with a system which abuses the people. As I said, the Government's argument that the taxpayers should not be forced to subsidise the wives and children of men on strike is an emotional one and the Government has been using it to good effect in the media in the last week or so. Leaving aside the doubtfulness of the Government's thesis that strikers do not have to go out on strike if they do not want to-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish.

—It is absolute rubbish. The Government seems to have forgotten that before people can go on strike they have to have a job. If they have a job they will be paying taxes. Therefore, in some way, however small, they have contributed to the revenue for the unemployment benefit that their spouse may be entitled to, after the first week of a strike, at the single rate plus a child subsidy. Yesterday in answer to a question which I suspect was a Dorothy Dixer and if it were it was probably from Senator Walters, but my memory may be failing me on that-I am only going on the odds on that one.
—It is something to bet on.

—It probably is. The Minister argued that views on a matter as sensitive as social welfare were not sufficient for the media or anybody else to play around with and that the facts were the only real criteria on which the public should be asked to make up their collective minds, particularly on something as emotional as in this case of some public servants misusing their working day. I suggest with respect that the dictum holds equally true in the case before us. As an earlier speaker pointed out-since I do not count Senator Crichton-Browne as an earlier speaker I suppose that leaves Senator Grimes-at no stage has it been shown empirically or anecdotically that under the present situation in which the spouse of a striker can after one week claim the single unemployment benefit the strike has gone on for longer than it would have if such a benefit were unavailable. No figures have been put before us to show how many people who apply for the unemployment benefit do so because they are married to a person who is on strike, although I understand-I may be wrong in this-that the Department of Social Security may have some figures on this, but certainly they are not readily available.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, no figures have been put before us to show how many people have applied for the unemployment benefit because they are married to somebody involved in industrial action. Nor are we able to get hold of any figures to show how long that person on the unemployment benefit for that reason remained on the unemployment benefit. The Government has given us no figures on the average length of strikes in Australia either generally or industry by industry to justify its claims although the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that at least for 1980 in the vicinity of 5 per cent of strikes across all industries lasted for more than 10 days. Instead of facts or discussion we are simply presented with the view that the payment of $58.10 for the spouse of a striker will encourage that striker to prolong his or her participation in a strike. The ABS figures also indicate that the largest group of people who go out on strike do so for increased wages. It is hardly likely that they will prolong, for any length of time, a wage dispute which puts them into an even more invidious position.

I suggest that the proponents of the view that unemployment benefits only serve to prolong strikes consider two points: The first is that, as far as some of the more militant unions are concerned, the question of choice for an individual as to whether he goes out on strike or how long he stays out is an academic matter. Choice, in fact, is non-existent in a lot of cases. The frequent photos of picket lines that we see in the newspapers and the accusations that we hear flung from one unionist to another about scab labour and other activities of some of the less reputable unions of a more or less violent nature are a clear indication of this. The second point is that regardless of whether or not the worker had a choice-this is the pertinent point-the wife and children of that person certainly had no say in the decision.

I have no choice but to repeat what I said in an earlier debate on the original Bill; that hitting out at innocent victims, the children in particular, is both churlish and unchristian. Whatever the actions of the father may have been, it is unfair to visit their sins on the heads, much less the stomachs, of their children. As I say, this Bill may well have biblical overtones but it certainly does not have charitable ones. That is in direct contrast-and a rather ironic contrast, as I foreshadowed earlier-with the other Bill that we are debating cognately, which takes a particularly Christian and charitable view of the way children in an invidious position, such as refugee children are placed, should be treated by the Australian taxpayer and the Australian Government.

I said earlier that I accept-I think we all accept-that some people will abuse a system. They will abuse any system. I stand by my earlier comment, too, that there is no reason, therefore, for concocting, at government level, a system which only reverses the situation. There is no reason, therefore, for reversing the stand that I took nearly a month ago when I said that I and the party are not prepared to see society divided on this matter merely because it is convenient for the Government, for some sort of electoral advantage in the long run; nor are we prepared to see social welfare being used as an industrial stick.

I can see only two reasons for the Government wanting to change the present system. Firstly, it is anticipating, in the very near future, that the increasing financial burdens falling on the average working person, because of high interest rates, high inflation and the spiralling cost of goods, will produce a rash of strikes which it will want to end relatively quickly-that is, in less than the 10 days which most strikes last-by applying some draconian economic sanctions. Secondly, I could adopt the more Machiavellian view; that at about the middle of next November, after the Government has brought down a fairly reasonable Budget in which the odd tax cut carrot has been handed out to the voter, it will somehow manage to engineer a strike in an area which will cause maximum inconvenience to the public. It will then take to the hustings, blaming the dreaded Australian Democrats and those rotten Labor people for depriving it of the use of some sort of heavy club with which to beat these people over the head. I suggest that if the Government does that it may very well be successful, human nature being what it is. However, it is a risk that I at least am prepared to take because an important principle is involved here; that is, that whatever one person in a family does, other members of the family, whether that person does it voluntarily or not-I still maintain that it is open to debate-should not be forced into penury, or worse, because of it. I can see no justification for this Bill, any more than I can see any justification for clauses 18 to 21 of the Bill that was defeated on 29 October. If it presents the Government with another one of its one to fifty Bills for double dissolution gun, well and good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to that aspect of the Social Services Amendment Bill which deals with the spouses of unionists affected by industrial disputes. In the main, most of the spouses would be women. This legislation is part of the Government's war against the trade union movement. That war has now been extended to the wives and children of trade unionists. The proposed changes to the social services legislation will stop a wife receiving social service payments for herself and her children if her husband is on strike or is stood down as a result of his union being on strike elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty obvious that that Government has a poor understanding of strikes and industrial relations in general. I think this lack of understanding was amply illustrated by Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution to the debate. My leader pointed out that, quite contrary to popular belief, about 25 per cent of disputes relate to wages, about 20 per cent relate to actual physical working conditions, and about 40 per cent stem from management policies and practices and victimisation of employees, for instance, retrenchments, short changing in wages, and so on. It is worth noting that of the total working hours lost to industry or to production only one-third can be attributed to industrial disputes and two-thirds occurs because of industrial accidents. One would assume that if the Government were genuinely concerned about loss of production and the welfare of people it would be exploring this badly neglected area of health, safety and welfare. But it is so obsessed, so hell bent on trying to thump the trade union movement, by fair means or foul, and it is usually by foul means, that it neglects this vast area of health, safety and welfare, an area that claims two-thirds of the total production hours lost.

Another point I should like to make quite clear is that there are 165,000 members of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. We are forever hearing complaints about the AMWSU being on strike, as though the entire 165,000 members of that union were on strike. If 1,000 members of the AMWSU were on strike it would equal three-fifths of one per cent of the total strength of that union. From the way people talk in this chamber, one would imagine that the whole union was out on strike on every occasion. Perhaps the Government wants the whole union to go on strike. Perhaps that is what it is aiming for. If the Government were really concerned about tradesmen and their welfare in this country, instead of trying to bring more tradesmen into the country it would have a look at the 1976 census. That census shows that 300,000 tradesmen in this country are not working at their trade. There is something very wrong when 300,000 tradesmen do not work at their trade and 39.4 per cent of apprentices fail to complete their apprenticeships. Why cannot the Government explore that area? Why does it not have a look at that area or at the areas of health, welfare and safety?

In relation to strikes, I recall an occasion when a drilling rig was being built near Kwinana by Transfield Pty Ltd. An area of ground was scooped out near the foreshore and the rig was built in the scooped out area. It was a good idea. It was intended that when the rig was completed channels would be cut and the rig would be floated out to sea. In order to build the rig, naturally there had to be electric cables running across the foreshore to the rig. These were necessary for the welding and drilling operations. Then the rainy season came on and many of those cables were submerged in water. So the men said: 'Look, we are not working in these conditions. We could be electrocuted. You do not know the condition of these cables.' The usual channels were pursued. The shop stewards approached management and asked it to do something about the problem. One day passed, two days passed. Nothing happened; so the men rang the office of the trade union. The union in turn tried to put pressure on the firm to do something about the situation, which was highly dangerous. Again, more time passed and nothing was done. The men went on strike. Can we blame them? Would we work in those conditions? The men cannot be blamed for going out on strike when their safety is at stake. They could have been electrocuted.

What this Government proposes to do to people who go on strike is beat them over the head with a big stick. It will do so not only to them, but also to their wives, to their children and to any other unionists who may have been affected by those who went on strike. Is that what this Government proposes to do? Is this how it handles industrial relations? It is an intimidatory tactic. The Government used these tactics in 1979 when it introduced the Social Services Amendment Bill. It was then that the Government refused unemployment benefit to trade unionists stood down as a result of an industrial dispute. It did not matter where or why a strike was held. A unionist was penalised when stood down as a result of an industrial dispute if he or she belonged to the union which was on strike. Many strikes occur over health, safety and welfare issues-a whole area completely neglected.

I have often heard honourable senators complaining about the unions. They have been doing it all day. It is a pity that Senator Crichton-Browne is not here because I am quite sure he does not know what half the strikes are about. However, through you, Mr President, I will ask any of the three remaining Government honourable senators in the chamber to tell me what are the wages of a fitter. What are the wages of a boilermaker? What are the wages of a toolmaker? They do not know. No doubt one of them could answer, but irrespective of what those wages are, the Government wants to keep them at the irreducible minimum. It does not matter why the men go out on strike. The fact is that they are out on strike. The reasons do not matter in the least. The Government has to find legislation in order to hold them down.

Senator Carrick often refers to Shakespeare. Let me quote my own bard. I will anglify the quotation slightly: 'The fear of hell is a hangman's whip to hold the wretch in order; but where you feel your honour grip, let that be your border.' I am quite sure that this Government is trying to push the trade union movement to the point where its honour will grip. It will not be a thousand men who will come out on strike. The Government may get 165,000 out on strike if it keeps on meddling. It has practically killed the arbitration system with its meddling. The Government is now trying to extend the same doctrine of collective responsibility. That is what it amounts to-collective responsibility. The unionist's wife and children are now to be held collectively responsible for whatever reason he is on strike or is stood down. Over the years the practice of collective responsibility has been constantly rejected by industrial courts throughout Australia. I will quote one such judgment-there are many of them; I have a whole swag-which was handed down from the Industrial Commission of New South Wales when the employers sought to apply the principle of collective responsibility. The Conciliation Commissioner said:

In my opinion the principle of collective responsibility as it has come to be enunciated . . . is inherently unreasonable. When stated as it is in the authorities, as a broad principle unrelated to the particular circumstances of any employment, industry or establishment, it extends to impose responsibility for lack of available work upon employees unconnected with the dispute who are ready and willing to work.

That judgment means that collective responsibility is inherently unreasonable and imposes responsibility on others. That is exactly what this legislation is aiming to do. Rather than give other examples of Industrial Commission judgments-there are plenty of them in which the commissioners have refuted the idea of collective responsibility-I will tell the Senate of a further frightening extension of the principle of collective responsibility.

During the Second World War Lidice in Czechoslovakia was the scene of a notorious German reprisal after the assassination of Heydrich, the Protector of Bohemia and Moravia. The partisans had assassinated Heydrich. The Germans alleged that the village had aided the men who killed Heydrich and, in consequence, on 10 June 1942 the male inhabitants, numbering 172, were shot; the women and children were either shot or sent to concentration camps. The village was systematically destroyed, the ground ploughed up and the name of Lidice erased from official records. This was collective responsibility at its worst. The very same principle applied by the Nazis in 1942 is being applied by this Government today.

These are the tactics of a government which is losing control, has lost the confidence of the electorate and has deep divisions within its own political ranks-I instance the Withers, the Peacocks and the so-called drys. These men no longer support the totalitarianism and facism that fuehrer Fraser has now adopted. The tactic of terror is the substitution of despotism for democracy and tyranny instead of leadership. In short, the thuggery of the German Third Reich is a replacement for parliamentary government when this collective responsibility is introduced. The thinking that has gone into this legislation is the thinking that destroyed Lidice. It attempts to turn wife against husband during a strike and to make the family collectively responsible as the Nazis made Lidice collectively responsible. If this legislation is passed this Government will have publicly advertised the fact that it now has one foot on the ladder of facism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981 and the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981. I will confine my remarks to the latter Bill. I congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for the steps he has taken in this Bill-I think the steps are overdue-where wives of men who are on strike will not automatically be able to receive social security benefits. When the Minister was preparing this matter and the Bill was on the table of the chamber I spoke to him in regard to whether there would be some hardship clause. I am very happy to see that there is.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government is doing is placing the responsibility right where it should be. Members of trade unions may desire to go on strike for all sorts of reasons such as demarcation, political and so on, but the responsibility for the care of a man's wife and children is his. If he decides he is going to withdraw his service, in other words to go on strike, he has the responsibility to ensure that he can afford to keep his wife and children fed and clothed. If there is a genuine case of hardship where a person with a wife and children will not be able to pay the rent, electric light bills or buy food, the Government in its wisdom has allowed for that.

I do not think that any honourable senator has spoken about what the Minister has prepared and distributed. The Minister has given the example of a family with two children. He has listed liquid resources and unavoidable financial commitments as conditions where special benefits will be payable. If a family with two children has no income and no liquid assets it will get $100. If it has unavoidable financial commitments totalling $100 it will get $89.70 a week. So it goes to the point where if such a family has liquid assets valued at $200 and has unavoidable financial commitments totalling up to $100 it will not get anything. I do not think honourable senators can ask for anything fairer than that.

First and foremost, it is the responsibility of the breadwinner to ensure that he provides for his family. Let me make this quite clear: I have been a working man all my life. I have done every labouring job known to man. Thank God I have never been a member of the Australian Labor Party. Nonetheless, I know what it is to have to raise a family. I raised seven children on a labourer's pay. But I always made sure, because it was my responsibility to do so, that I was able to provide for my family. If a person goes on strike and on a continued strike, it is his responsibility to ensure that his family is not deprived by his doing so. However, today the militant section of the trade union movement-I am not condemning the whole trade union movement-calls strikes at the drop of a hat. Trade unions have funds also.

What must the person who is continuously working, paying his taxes and not doing foolish things like going on strike think when he sees that a man on strike can get anything up to $30 a week from the trade union movement's strike fund and his wife can get social service benefits? A man on strike has 30 bucks. He can go down to the hotel and spend the day drinking beer with his pals. He does not care if he does not go back to work for another two or three weeks because the Government, or his fellow Australians, will ensure that his wife and children have an income. He does not have to be concerned about that because he has 30 bucks. He can have a couple of dollars on the gee-gees or he can go down to the local rubbidy-dub and have a few beers with his mates. If he knows he will not get that money and his wife and family will not be paid, he will go back to work as quickly as he jolly well can, and rightly so. If he does not do that immediately, maybe his wife and children will nag him and he will go back to work and do the right thing. I commend the Government for its action with this legislation. I totally support it because I believe it is time that members of militant trade unions started to wake up to themselves and to face the fact that they will not have a free ride at the expense of their fellow Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of whether dole payments should be made to spouses of strikers is one of some controversy in the community. If this debate has indicated anything it certainly has indicated that. It has exercised my mind to the extent that I have tried as much as possible to get the opinions of some of my constituents in New South Wales to see what they think of the matter. It was not a large sample-between 60 and 70 people-but it was interesting that only four of those people supported the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981. In other words, the great majority felt that in certain circumstances the wives and families of strikers should get the dole because they ought not to be penalised for the actions of their husbands and fathers. The view was even put to me by two or three people, in this case all women, that indeed the Government would be penalising them for being married.
—Did you put to them the availability of special benefit in the case of hardship?
—Indeed, I did put that to them. I will go on to that a little later.
—I am sorry I interrupted you.

—That is all right. It was a good point. In other words, the withdrawal of this provision, as a strike-breaking weapon, appears to be repugnant to most of the community. The people I canvassed were by no means all unionists; mostly they were people who were known to me. A few of them were unionists, but more of them were small business people than people of any other category I could think of. It is interesting that they should take this point of view. As I said, they believed that the dole should be available to the families of strikers in certain circumstances. The interesting point to me was that almost all of them felt that it was not right that funding from the community in the form of the dole should be available after only one week which, of course, is the case at present.

SPEECH.PARA: There was no general view among those people as to how much longer than one week it should be before the dole would apply, but the range of answers they gave varied between two weeks to six weeks. The most general view held by them appeared to be roughly organised around the idea of three weeks. It is for that reason that I have circulated in the Senate an amendment which would have the effect of retaining the dole payment to the wives of strikers but applying it after a qualifying period of three weeks. It is fair to say that this is a personal initiative on my part. It does not have the support of even all my own party. But I felt it desirable to put it forward because it seemed to me necessary for the community that there should be the opportunity of some discussion of a reasonable middle-ground compromise in the matter, something between the whole thing being thrown out and it being retained as it is at present. I believe the way this is going now it will continue to be a divisive issue in the community. Whatever vote is taken in the Senate today, it will not settle this matter. We all know that very well.

The point is that I believe that in a protracted strike, when family resources are more likely to have been exhausted and other forms of aid may also be exhausted, it is necessary to have the means by which families do not suffer unduly. Of course, there is the other point of view. I remind honourable senators that I see myself as representing Sydney as part of New South Wales where we have had a very bad time indeed with petrol strikes whereby a great deal of suffering occurred. Some of the stories about suffering that have come to my knowledge will remain with me for some considerable time. I have heard of cases of many people, besides the families of strikers, suffering seriously. I have heard of cases of old people without the transport to go to buy food at some distance away-some new areas do not allow people to shop within walking distance of where they live-having to ask for food supplies from the neighbours; in effect, begging from them. Others have been placed under a disadvantage because they cannot get needed medications. Such people naturally feel resentful if they feel they are being compelled to subsidise, through their taxes, the very people they see as causing their suffering. It may not be that that is the case. It may be that the wrongs are on the other side.

Nevertheless, I think this makes it evident that there should be, between the two extremes we have heard in this chamber today, some middle ground which perhaps would be more acceptable to the community at large and which would take some sort of heat out of this situation. It seems to me that if it is known that an effective payment to families can be made after only one week, it is rather easier for frivolous strikes-there are frivolous strikes from time to time without very good reason-to get off the ground. If it were known that the provisions would not apply for three weeks, I suggest that unions would then have to consider the need to ensure themselves that their members could be sustained for that period. I do not see that as an unreasonable obligation on them. If in some cases some of the strikers' families were in severe trouble inside three weeks, the provisions for special benefits would apply. I have a copy of the guidelines of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), for which I thank him. They refer to the provision of benefits of up to $89.70 a week for a family with two children. So, as I understand it, a fail-safe mechanism would apply in this case.

I put the suggestion before the Senate yesterday with an appeal that it be seriously considered as a compromise position acceptable to all parties. It is something I thought the Government might have considered. Had it any desire whatsoever to avoid anything other than a direct confrontation on this issue, I would have thought it something it might have said it would negotiate on. But that has not been the case. As a result, I have been induced to the belief that the Government is raising this matter at this stage not because it wants this legislation or because it wants a solution to this problem but purely in a spirit of mischief to cause political trouble and dissension and perhaps also as a sop to its extreme right wing supporters in the community who regularly scream for strikers to be starved out. Also I tend to support my colleague Senator Haines who has said that the Government is probably now pathologically looking for its trigger mechanisms, as it calls them-its means of trying to abuse section 57 of the Constitution of this country. It is pushing out little boats in various directions to see how it can get something which it might conveniently at a time to suit it use as the means for a double dissolution.

I was most impressed with something I heard Senator Carrick saying on the media last night-that the first trigger, the education Bills, was there and that this would be a lesson to those who sought to frustrate. I suggest that in that single word we see a world of attitudes in which the Executive believes that although it does not have the confidence of both Houses of this Parliament it has the right, regardless of that, to push through whatever it wishes; and it sees anything less than that as a frustration. The initiative which I have put forward and which is cast in the form of a fairly complicated amendment was reasonably put and ought to have been reasonably considered. It is evident to me at this stage that it will not be reasonably considered. I have no evidence that it will be. All I will say is that sooner or later in this place we must evolve legislation by negotiation or by compromise with an ear to what the community wants. It seems to me that that day has yet to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on that section of the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) that relates to unemployment benefit being denied to people because of industrial action. This Bill seeks, in the confrontationist style of the Fraser Government, to divide further the Australian community. The Government is using a social services Bill to impose a penalty on wage and salary earners and their families. This social security legislation is designed as strike-breaking legislation. This legislation has to be seen as a penal clause against wage and salary earners, a penal clause against the family and an invasion of the civil liberties of the spouse of a trade unionist, female or male. The vast majority of people disadvantaged by this proposed legislation will be innocent victims. They will be people who are married to a trade unionist or children who are dependants of a trade unionist. The individual entitlement of the wife or husband-their civil liberty to benefit from social services in their own right-is to be denied to them.

SPEECH.PARA: As this Government is setting out to starve these families into submission, we need to have an idea of the size of this problem. Only 16 per cent of the disputes go for longer than five days. Only 8.9 per cent of all strikers were involved in disputes that lasted 10 days or longer and one per cent of all industrial disputes last longer than 20 days. This is the reason I oppose Senator Mason's proposal. It would apply only to one per cent of industrial disputes. My colleague Senator Grimes has pointed out that of the 60,000 people who are involved in industrial disputes which last longer than seven days one-third are probably single and one-third have working spouses. So 20,000 people of a total work force of 6.6 million people will be affected. They are the facts on which this whole legislation is based.

Who are the employers involved in the longer disputes? They are invariably the largest employers, usually with a high percentage of foreign ownership. Let us look at a few of them. The mining industry is 59 per cent foreign-owned. The motor vehicle and spare parts industry is 75 per cent foreign-owned. The petroleum refining industry, which has just been mentioned, is 91 per cent foreign-owned. The position of wage and salary earners under this Government is that 80 per cent of them are, at this moment, $20 worse off. If we consider what might be called the social wage-health services, housing, education and the social welfare system-we have a reduced standard of living of approximately $18 a week. People are a total of $38 a week worse off under this Government and this is one of the reasons why there is industrial unrest.

We must examine the real position of this Government. Since 1975 this Government has engaged in a massive transfer of wealth through the taxation system. The Government has taken over $17 billion in higher taxes from the average wage and salary earners. It has given $15 billion to wealthy individuals and companies through tax cuts. That has to be compared with the $5m that is involved in any reference to the spouses of trade unionists. Senator Crichton-Browne, who cried crocodile tears for the trade unionists and the people in the mining companies of Western Australia, should look at his Government's record on the main money issue, and that is tax avoidance. Last year the level of tax avoidance rose by 30 per cent. Since 1975-76 tax avoidance has increased by 26 times. They are the facts. That is where the money is. Indeed, the figure announced as to tax avoidance this year is $973m. Individually, that means each tax avoider owes $43,500. Contrast those figures with the $5m that this Government claims is involved in this legislation affecting 20,000 people. The interesting fact is that the number of people involved in tax avoidance is 22,366, with each owing $43,500. That equates with the 20,000-odd people who would be affected by this legislation.

The comparison does not stop there. Industry has been given $2,278m by a massive system of tax concessions, hand-outs and infrastructure. The Government is not satisfied with giving this money to big business. It now intervenes to help in the struggle against labour. One might well ask: Why is the Government so bloody-minded in pressing such a biased Bill in this chamber? At least one consideration must have to do with collective bargaining because at the moment every other major employer organisation is giving lip service to it. The Government's industrial relations policy is in tatters. Rising from the ashes is the gimmick that we have before us today. One significant aspect in any consideration of collective bargaining is the power of the relative forces. Another, of course, axiomatically, is the length of industrial disputes. If we compare the situation in the United States of America with that in Australia, we find that in that country industrial disputes are more than eight times longer. Indeed, in Australia the median duration of strikes is 1.25 days. In the United States it is 16.25 days. The effect of this legislation in favouring large companies-the same multinational companies that are in both America and Australia at the moment-is similar to its effect on people involved in industrial disputes. That may well be the reason for the Government's action, in this area. As some of my colleagues have pointed out, the Government deliberately in everything that has been said has failed to recognise that managerial policy decisions are the main cause of industrial disputes. As my colleague Senator McIntosh pointed out, only 21 per cent of industrial disputes are based on wages. Managerial policy decisions are the cause of 42 per cent of disputes and working conditions are the cause of 21.4 per cent. This is the key to the issue. This is the issue that the Government is soft on. It is the thing that the Minister has not mentioned. In the area of management inspired disputes some of the most intense industrial disputes occur.

I would like to give a few examples and perhaps start with one that might be close to Senator Crichton-Browne's heart. As he cried his crocodile tears for some of the iron companies, I was reminded of the Tom Price mine in Western Australia, which is owned by Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd, the company which engaged in provocation by unilaterally changing shifts when it had a stockpile of iron ore. It can be relied on every six months to engage in such action. Hamersley Iron was a prominent case study in the Fitzgerald report on the contribution of the mineral industry to Australian welfare. The Hamersley Iron company paid less than one per cent income tax on profits of $264m. The Fitzgerald report documented the massive tax rip-off by Hamersley and concluded by stating:
Practically no internal redistributive benefits for Australia as a whole . . . have so far emerged from these profitable mining operations.

That is one typical example of the type of management inspired dispute. When the price of gold dropped at the Telfer gold mine management created a long industrial dispute. It was settled when the price of gold rose again. And what of Qantam House? The construction company, Dillingham Australia Ltd, provoked many disputes because the method of payment to Dillingham meant that it profited by disputes. Rise and fall clause payments were made when disputes occurred. Dillingham was making $50,000 a week when disputes occurred. There are many examples in the mining and construction industries of these actions being taken by these giant organisations.

Recently the Murdoch newspaper group was involved in a typical dispute that illustrates management-caused industrial disputes. These are the sorts of disputes which, if this Government is successful with this legislation, will mean strikers-the victims-will be punished through their spouses not receiving the unemployment benefit. The Bill does not discriminate. All strikers are treated the same regardless of who causes the dispute. In the Murdoch newspaper dispute, Ita Buttrose, the editor-in-chief with the Murdoch newspaper group, decided, on a whim, to replace a journalist. She decided to sack a person whom she had originally recruited. In the typical arrogant, elite manner of management in such companies, the journalist was in no way warned or in any way informed that there was criticism of her work. No common-sense industrial relations procedures were followed. The capricious action of Ita Buttrose caused a stoppage of eight days. The dispute spread from Sydney to Melbourne and from Brisbane to Perth. Similar disputes have lasted longer in the newspaper industry.

The effect of this Bill will be that the wives and husbands of journalists or printers in those States will be ineligible for unemployment benefits unless they beg under the special provisions of the Bill to which the Minister has referred. Last year, an industrial dispute over new technology and rates of pay for journalists operating video display terminals in the newspaper industry lasted a month. This type of dispute determined by management and affecting people in the printing industry is another typical example of the operations of this Bill in practice. If the Government wants an election on this issue then it can have it. The simple fact is that it cannot make scapegoats of people who cannot afford it. It implements this legislation to save the payment of $5m to simple, ordinary people, yet it allows 22,366 tax bludgers to owe $973m. Indeed, each one of those tax bludgers could pay enough to give 740-odd ordinary people unemployment relief. That is the extent of the difference between the two sides of this argument. I would be very happy to fight against this Bill throughout Australia. The trade union movement will take issue with it because it is a biased deliberate attack on the trade union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the limited time, I will confine my remarks to the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981, which deals with matters to which most honourable senators participating in this debate have directed their remarks. I have read carefully the material that has been presented to us by the Government in respect of this matter. I have listened to all the debate and have been present in the chamber for 95 per cent of it. I have also read, with interest, the second reading speech of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick). Might I add that I am surprised that this legislation does come from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who has a record of being very perceptive. All that I can say about the Bill has been said about a number of other things over a long period. It is a bit like the head of a bullock. There are a couple of points in it but there is a lot of bull between them.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the points, of course, which was mentioned by the Minister in his second reading speech was that the taxpayer should not pay for industrial action taken by the decision of strikers. I suppose most of us would agree with that principle. But then we have to start defining what we mean by that. Nowhere in this Bill is an attempt made to define the question of industrial action. It does not go to the question of what is legitimate industrial action and what is not. If, for example, action is taken by a group of workers pursuant to a secret strike ballot under the amendments made by this Government to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, those people and their families are not exempted from the penal provisions of this Bill.

I turn now to a number of other points that have been raised during the debate to which the mind of the Government obviously has not been substantially addressed. Those questions include the following: Against whom is this piece of legislation directed? An argument has been put forward that it is against the married wife of the one income family. Statistics have been laid before the Senate today which indicate that possibly 60,000 to 70,000 workers were affected last year of whom approximately 45,000 had spouses. Half of these were working and, therefore, were ineligible anyhow for the unemployment benefit. That reduces the number to a possible 20,000 applicants for very short periods indeed. No figures have been presented to the Parliament as to the cost to the taxpayer about which the Government is concerned. The Minister stated in his second reading speech:

There have been numerous cases where the wives of strikers, who have appeared to have no genuine intention of joining the work force themselves, have registered for work in places such as mining and construction towns where there is no real possibility of employment for them.

It is time that the Government came clean and told us how many of these cases there are; what has been the cost over the last 12 months or even over the last three years; the duration of the strike involved; whether the granting of the unemployment benefit has, in fact, prolonged the strike action; and whether the percentage of strikers who have wives would be stretching the longest bow of eligibility to apply for the unemployment or special benefit. These are the sorts of things that ought to be clarified. As far as the Senate is concerned I believe that it cannot make up its mind until these matters are clarified and until the Government comes clean and gives us all of the information. If it does not, it appears, on the face of it, that this measure is, in fact, directed at the one income family. That is why I expressed my surprise to the Minister that he, of all people, would take action or support a measure which would further undermine the one income family.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has no compassion.

—I disagree with that. With respect, I think the Minister does have compassion but his previous statements relating to the need to support one-income families are not borne out. I also point out some inconsistencies in the Minister's speech. He talks about strike settlements involving make up for pay lost during the strike. From my experience there are not a great number of such strike settlements. I also remind the Minister-he has been reminded during the debate-that the causes of strikes are not always wages causes. In his second reading speech, the Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Not infrequently, strikes are settled on a basis that effectively compensates those who have gone on strike for pay lost during the duration of the strike.

I remind the Senate, and Senator Chaney, that the figures put forward by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that only some 20 per cent of strikes were over wages and salaries. So on the face of it the Minister's statement does not bear examination by comparison with the official figures that have been put forward by the Bureau of Statistics. As has been mentioned in the debate by a number of honourable senators, there are a number of other causes of strikes within Australia, such as managerial policy and physical working conditions. The question of safety arises as well. For example, if there is a strike regarding safety then, of course, under this provision the wives of those strikers, who are striking on a matter of principle, could be affected.

I also believe that the Minister has not considered whether the action taken is legitimate, whether it is within the bounds of a State Act or State award, or, as I have mentioned previously, whether it is within the bounds of the amended provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Why penalise wives of men who are acting within those bounds? For example, why penalise workers who are acting precisely within the guidelines for the conduct and control of industrial disputes? I assume that that is what was meant. But this question was raised when the words 'trade union reform' were mentioned earlier in the debate. There is a growing recognition amongst a growing section of the trade union movement that the fundamental rule for the conduct and control of industrial disputes should be observed by a unionist before he takes strike action. This was adverted to broadly by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Dolan, in his opening address to the recently held congress of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. He referred, of course, to the provisions of ACTU rules Nos. 13 and 14, which are long-standing rules. He referred to the fundamental principle for the conduct and control of industrial disputes, which, as we all know, means that if someone goes out on strike and puts me out of work he has a responsibility to consult me through my union, through the central trade union organisation. If, for example, a union and unionists satisfy all the criteria and wgrk within all the guidelines for the conduct and control of industrial disputes, are we to put them and their wives in the same boat as those who are not engaging in industrial activity pursuant to those guidelines? That is what the Government is doing in this Bill. I suggest, frankly, that these questions may not even have occurred to the Government, let alone proper examination having been given to them.

I now refer to a matter that has been raised previously, the matter of the one-income family. This legislation seems to be directed at the one-income family. In a mining district, for example, are we to impose this penalty on the spouse-that is, the married spouse-of a striker and not on the de facto spouse of a striker? I suggest that the Government has not even though of that. I know of a number of cases in mining areas of a couple who live together and have kids. Under this piece of legislation we will discriminate not only against the single income--

TALK.START.PARA: —No. It would apply equally to a married or a de facto relationship.
—I am talking about people who are living together.
—Yes.
—How can it apply?
—Because the rules apply in those circumstances. De facto marriage is treated as a marriage in those circumstances.
—For the purpose of this clause?
—Yes.

—I understand that. I am glad that the Minister has thought of something along those lines, but I guarantee that he has not thought of the other proposition I put forward to him: That is, those workers who are engaging in industrial action pursuant to the proper rules for the conduct and control of industrial disputes and those who are not. I feel quite strongly that the Government is not pursuing a proper course on this matter. This is an attempt to involve and include industrial relations measures in social security legislation, and I do not think that will work. Quite frankly, I believe it is an extension of the Government's policy, which has not worked in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I point out to the Senate that a rejection of this measure will again load for the Government another barrel of the section 57 gun. Last night Australian Labor Party and Australian Democrat senators loaded the section 57 gun barrel for the Government. They laid themselves and the Senate open to allegations of avoidable obstructionism by their actions relating to the tertiary education Bill. By voting against the motion for the second reading of the Bill they prevented consideration of my foreshadowed motion which provided the opportunity for the Senate to exercise its audit, control and scrutiny powers in a palatable manner. As honourable senators know, my amendment then would have given the best of both worlds. I think the amendment I will propose shortly in this matter will also give time for the Senate to reconsider its position, but more particularly for the Government to reconsider its position. My proposal last night was for an amendment at the Committee stage of the Bill to make any ministerial instrument as to fees subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament. Of course, as we all know, it is not unusual for such ministerial determinations to be subject to the scrutiny of Parliament in this way. As the numbers stand in the Senate, any unacceptable determination bq the Minister would be disallowed.
