I say to the Senate now, as I could have said last night: Why give the Government an excuse to pave the way for a double dissolution? Why not make a stand when there are other procedural avenues open to exercise our audit and control functions other than to defeat a measure outright? We will, of course, find ourselves in such a situation when the sales tax measure comes before the Senate. That can only be dealt with by outright defeat of those clauses which attempt to impose sales tax on necessity items. In the current circumstances, a procedural avenue is available to the Senate which will provide the opportunity for the Senate but, as I say, more particularly for the Government, to review the situation. I foreshadow that after this Bill has been disposed of, I will move to the motion for the second reading of the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'this Bill be referred to a select committee for inquiry and report upon the provisions of the Bill and matters relating thereto, including matters raised during the debate in the Senate on the Bill'.

I feel that this will give the opportunity for the Senate to exercise its review and control functions. I feel that if we pass up this opportunity we will be providing the Government with an unnecessary basis for obstructionist allegations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I close the debate only on the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. With the leave of the Senate, although we are dealing with a cognate debate, I propose to address myself in a matter of seconds to that Bill only so that we may then deal separately with the motion that has just been foreshadowed by Senator Harradine. Accordingly, in the absence of some indication from honourable senators that they object to that procedure, may I thank the Senate for its support of the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. As I expected, there is unanimity that the informal refugee child, as well as the formal refugee child, should be covered by the legislation which was earlier introduced. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 November, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed in the second reading debate on the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'this Bill be referred to a select committee for inquiry and report upon the provisions of the Bill and matters relating thereto, including matters raised during the debate in the Senate on the Bill'.

I move that proposition on the basis that, of course, the composition of the select committee would be, in the normal course of events, the subject of a subsequent motion. I point out to the Senate the importance of all the matters that were raised being considered at length. In the obvious situation where the Government has not considered at least one of the major points that have been raised in the debate and may not have considered the others, this arrangement would give the Government the opportunity of doing so and also give us the opportunity of reviewing this important piece of legislation which could have a disastrous effect on certain one-income families which are finding it difficult enough at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded? There being no seconder, the amendment lapses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some sympathy for Senator Harradine's amendment. However, I wish to explain why the Opposition cannot accept it. It is no secret in this place that the Opposition considered a similar amendment. Senator Harradine made the point that the Government is obviously intent on loading the gun in respect of legislation which has been rejected more than once by the Senate. The Government considers that legislation dealt with in this way is appropriate legislation to provide the reason for calling a double dissolution. According to legal opinion I have been able to obtain the reference of a matter to a committee, which Senator Harradine has suggested, would also be considered a failure to pass legislation. In fact the gun would still be loaded even if Senator Harradine's amendment were agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to raise is that by opposing this legislation we will give the Government three months to reconsider its position and to reconsider the points raised by myself, Senator Haines, Senator Harradine and the other speakers in this debate. I do not believe that the Government, from its attitude on the previous social services legislation during debate in another place and in this place so far, has any intention of reconsidering this legislation. I agree with previous speakers that this Bill panders to the prejudices of those on the Government side and the Government's supporters who believe that it is appropriate that a government of their persuasion should do what it can to thump the trade unions as often as possible and, if it is necessary to attack the wives and children of the unionists in order to do that, they will continue to do so.

This Bill to us presents a matter of principle. It presents the principle that the Social Services Act is designed to assist those in the community who are disadvantaged, who have insufficient funds or insufficient resources through no fault of their own. Provisions which go against that principle should not be introduced into this Act. Clearly this legislation contains such provisions. I believe that our principled stand on this matter is such that, even with a committee of inquiry such as Senator Harradine suggested, it would not change; it would only be strengthened. I believe the feelings of the people on the other side of the chamber are such that a committee would make no difference to them.

The only reason I can see for supporting such a committee-I believe this is one of the reasons that Senator Harradine put forward-is that it would enable further debate on the matters about which he spoke, including the matter whether people taking legitimate industrial action are excluded from this legislation. Quite clearly they are not. There is no distinction in this legislation or in the 1979 legislation between what may be called a legitimate strike and a legal strike; there is no distinction between a strike conducted for the purpose of improving safety or working conditions and any other strike. It is a blanket amendment, a blanket change to the legislation to cover all those involved in industrial action. It is blanket legislation to cover all those who fall foul of the Department of Social Security and who lose their unemployment benefits because of that.

It is interesting that the two speakers on the Government side did not mention the latter part of the Bill; this is further indication that the Government wishes to concentrate on the industrial aspects of the legislation. Senator Harradine's amendment will not prevent this Bill being used as a double dissolution Bill. It will not mean that there has not been a refusal to pass the legislation and it will not prevent a government, which is hell bent on doing so, introducing legislation like this to create division and prejudice in the community. Therefore we believe we should stand on our principles in this matter and debate the issues with a community which I believe is far more intelligent and perceptive than obviously the Government believes. We do not wish to cloud the issue and introduce into the debate further argument on whether we have refused supply or have backed down on this principle. We wish to stand where we are and, therefore, with some reluctance we did not second and could not have supported Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I wonder whether I might have the same indulgence that Senator Grimes was just allowed and speak either twice to the second reading of a Bill or once to an amendment that was lost because it was not seconded. I am not quite sure which is the case.
—Senator Haines, you are speaking once to each Bill.

—I see; I understand that because it is a cognate debate we get to have two goes. I am sure that the Senate will forgive my confusion. I understand that we are splitting the two Bills. Whatever the reason for our doing this strange thing, I fail to see why the Australian Democrats should have Senator Grimes speak for them.
—I wouldn't presume to do so.

—I am sure that Senator Grimes would not presume to do such a thing without our permission. I turn my attention to the proposition put forward by Sentor Harradine; that is, that referral of this matter to a Senate select committee would be a good way of resolving differences, a good way of having the issues thrashed out between political parties and amongst members of the community. There was some speculation in the media recently that both the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats were in favour of a reference of this matter to a Senate select or standing committee. Nobody at any stage asked me, as the Democrats spokesperson on the matter, whether I thought it ought to be referred to a committee, select or standing. While I am prepared to accept that Senate select and standing committees serve a very valuable purpose, I cannot see that anything would be gained in this instance by such a reference. To begin with, I am not particularly afraid of guns, whether loaded or unloaded, and I am certainly not afraid of a double dissolution gun on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whether the issue ought to be referred to a Senate committee, select or otherwise, I make the point that these committees are usually valuable when dealing with matters that are non-contentious, that are not particularly political in nature or at least do not appear to be. I suppose that one could say that there is not much point in referring the matter of South-West Tasmania to a committee when clearly it would be politically dealt with, but I think there is a chance, since submissions and so on would be taken by that committee, that that matter would be looked at more neutrally than the contents of this piece of legislation would be. We certainly supported Senator Hamer's amendment to Senator Missen's motion that a Senate committee should be set up or used to look at any infringements of civil liberties contained in legislation brought before this chamber. That in itself is a good thing. It can be seen in 99 cases out of 100 as being a non-political issue.

We are not dealing with a question of civil liberties in any readily identifiable sense; the issue is an entirely political one. It was for this reason, when some people were discussing in the corridors and in their offices whether this matter should be referred to a committee, that at no stage did I indicate in any way at all that I was in favour of that course. I can see no point in it. It would drag the thing on for another three months in which some Government members, if they wished, could whip some members of the public into a frenzy of disapproval about these poor women and children getting some money out of the Government when they really should not do so. In the long run two reports would be brought down-one from the Government members and one from non-Government members. That statement might indicate a certain cynicism in me, but I am afraid that this place makes that sort of attitude unavoidable. I can see no point in referring the matter to a Senate committee, select or otherwise. I do not think it would achieve anything. I do not think we would solve the central moral dilemma-it is a moral dilemma; it is a matter of viewpoint, assessment of the situation-in that way. I cannot see how five senators, four senators or whatever the number would be would get any closer to a solution after three months hassle than we have done in the last few hours of debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might ape the honourable senators opposite at least insofar as I explain why the Government does not support a reference to a committee. I think it will be quite clear that the Government has put forward this legislation because it believes that it is an appropriate amendment to the Social Services Act. It has put it forward in the belief that it should be passed by the Parliament. For that reason it does not-I do not think it would have been expected to do so-support a reference to a committee.

SPEECH.PARA: There seems to me to be one common thread running through the debate on the Social Services Amendment Bill (No. 3), and that is that strikes cause hardship. On this side of the chamber there was emphasis on the broad hardship which is caused to the community by strikes. I believe that within the Australian community there is a very clear view that strike action is something which affects not merely the strikers directly involved and the companies or businesses directly involved but also the community, and that is sometimes brought home with great strength by the fact that essential services are interfered with and so on. That has received more emphasis on this side of the chamber, whereas on the other side of the chamber there has been emphasis on the hardship which is caused to the strikers themselves and those who are not responsible directly, the families of the strikers and other members of the same union who might be affected under this legislation by the actions of their fellow unionists. But it is common ground that hardship is caused.

The debate about this legislation is, I think, properly a debate about where, in the main, the hardship ought to be carried and who is responsible for meeting the losses which are caused by this sort of activity. One thing that was notably absent from the contributions from the other side of the chamber was reference to the fact that there is a basic provision in this legislation which says that those who are in extreme hardship will get assistance from the State, from their fellow Australians, notwithstanding the fact that their spouses are involved in strike action. That is a matter on which I will go into more detail in a moment. Essentially, the debate is about who shall carry the burden which is imposed by strike action.

There were some fairly emotional contributions, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I do not think I offend the Chair in saying that not the least of which was your contribution because you went so far as to compare the collective responsibility approach of this legislation to the actions of the Third Reich in respect of the village of Lidice. You picked an example with which I am very familiar. Indeed, for many years I had on my wall a poster which said 'Remember Lidice'. You told the story of the responsibility that was sheeted home in such a dreadful way to that village. But I think that was a great overstatement of the situation. In fact, a more dispassionate examination of the situation makes it quite clear that there is a judgment to be made here and the Government has simply chosen to make the judgment, which I believe would have the support of the majority of Australians, that when people take strike action they ought to carry the burden of it. I commend the more reasoned approach put forward by Senator Harradine in which he raised matters of concern to him about the possible operation of this legislation.

I shall refer the Senate very brieflq to some of the history of this matter. I refer to a book which I think is regarded as a fairly non-partisan view of the social security system. The book is entitled Australian Social Security Today and was written by Mr T. H. Kewley. I refer to the information at pages 132 and 133. It is interesting that Mr Kewley quotes a letter to the Director of Social Services dated May 1948 in which Senator McKenna, the Minister for Social Services in the Chifley Government, said:
All unions represented at the Conference with me in Sydney on 23rd April accepted the principle that the Commonwealth could not permit unemployment benefit to be used for financing strikes.

I wanted to give that quote because it is a very big difference in emphasis from the emphasis that has been put on it by the other side of the chamber; that is, that in some way the Government is seeking to use the social security system for industrial purposes. The fact of the matter is that the Government is trying to prevent the social security system from being used for industrial purposes by those who are in the industrial sphere.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is referring to strikers.

—I believe that that is the true emphasis which is to be put on this legislation. Senator Grimes interjects in his usual way by saying that that is referring to strikers. But the principle is this: Those strikers are people who are perhaps without income and who are, in a hardship sense, in need of assistance but the policy decision is taken that unemployment benefit is not to be used for financing their strike. That is the principle behind what Senator McKenna is saying. That was laid down by Mr Chifley who, in that year, made a statement with respect to unemployment benefit in Queensland. On 25 February 1948 Mr Chifley, a Labor Prime Minister, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with the payment of unemployment benefit to persons involved in or affected by the present Queensland industrial dispute, the Social Services Consolidation Act provides that benefit is not payable to an applicant whose unemployment is due to him being a direct participant in a strike.

In relation to other persons involved in or affected by an industrial dispute, the Minister for Social Services has issued instructions which are being observed by the Department of Social Services in Queensland at present and throughout the Commonwealth. These instructions are the outcome of a full consideration of the relevant parts of the Act of a Cabinet sub-committee early in 1947.
In brief, the instructions embody the following principles: In respect of unions on strike and unions sponsoring a strike of its members in key positions, members of these unions-
I emphasise these words-
whether directly participating in the strike, or unemployed as a direct or indirect consequence of the strike, are not to be regarded as eligible to receive unemployment benefit.
In respect of unions not on strike, or apparently having no members on strike, members of these unions are to be regarded as eligible to receive unemployment benefit.
A person is not to be disqualified for unemployment benefit by reason only of his refusal to undertake work available through a strike or lockout.

The important principle contained there is that not just those who are directly concerned in the strike are to be removed from entitlement to unemployment benefit. I mention that in the context of those who complain and say that only those who are directly and immediately involved and responsible should be deprived. As Mr Kewley points out those rules were changed in March 1973 when Mr Hayden was Minister for Social Security. In fact, those rules in general, apart from a very brief period, have applied as laid down by the Labor Government. Those honourable senators, and even those less honourable senators who persist in interjecting and who are concerned about the situation of those who are indirectly involved because they are the spouses of strikers, are-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what Chifley said and you know it.
—I have directly quoted Mr Chifley.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite clear from the number of interjections from the other side of the chamber that the Labor Party does not like to be reminded of the days when it could be relied upon to do the right thing by the people of Australia. There would be no Australian who would not look back to the Chifley days with great regret and wish that men of the calibre of Mr Chifley were still in the Opposition now. In any event, the concern which is put forward by the Opposition relates to the fact that the wives and children are to be left without protection.

SPEECH.PARA: My friend and colleague Senator Bonner made a very good speech in which he pointed out that the basic responsibility for a man's wife and children in general may be put at the feet of that man because that is the responsibility he bears. In any event, the legislation which we have put forward provides that in the case where a wife and children are going to suffer hardship there can be intervention by way of special benefit. I have had no inquiry from the Opposition at all as to how that might operate. To do the Australian Democrats justice, they did seek information as to how that would work. In fact, there has been a total lack of interest on the part of the Opposition about what might be made available under that legislation.

I will outline to the Senate the position with respect to the grant of that special benefit. Administrative guidelines have been prepared covering the test of extreme hardship which is the test required by the legislation and which is a precondition to the grant of special benefit under the amendment. These guidelines indicate that extreme hardship may be accepted if the current income and available liquid assets of a couple, for example, money in the bank and cash, are less than the equivalent of unemployment benefit at the single rate plus, where appropriate, additional benefit for children, after unavoidable financial commitments other than general living costs have been deducted from the income and available liquid assets. In such cases, special benefit will be paid at a rate sufficient to bring the total income of the couple up to the level of employment benefit at the single rate plus any additional benefit for children. Where an applicant is ineligible for special benefit because income and available liquid assets are sufficient to cover unavoidable financial commitments and the relevant rate of unemployment benefit, the position will be reviewed each fortnight.

By way of example, let me take a family with two children and outline a number of situations in which special benefit would not be payable and a number in which it would be payable. If a family had no liquid resources and unavoidable financial commitments, it would get the special benefit at the single unemployed rate with the addition for the two children. In other words, the family's position would be the same as if it were in receipt of the unemployment benefit. It would get an amount of $89.70. If a family had liquid resources of, say, $50 a week but unavoidable financial commitments in excess of that amount, it would get $89.70. If it had liquid resources equal to its unavoidable financial commitments, it would get $89.70. If it had liquid resources $50 a week in excess of its unavoidable financial commitments, it would get $39.70. If it had liquid resources in excess of the amount of its unavoidable financial commitments, the single unemployment rate and the amount for children, it would get nothing.

The simple fact of the matter is that the choice one is really debating with respect to this legislation is this: At the moment the wife of a man who goes on strike or whose union goes on strike and thereby puts him out of work may claim unemployment benefit even if that man has large savings in the bank. In other words, he is entitled to conserve his own liquid resources and to call upon the taxpayer for contributions. Under this legislation the change will be this: If a man goes on strike or his union goes on strike and thereby puts him out of work, he will get assistance only if his liquid resources are not sufficient to cover his unavoidable financial commitments plus the current rate of single unemployment benefit for the woman and the children. That is the simple fact of the matter. That is what we are debating. The real issue is whether people who are out of work because of industrial action are entitled not to run down their assets during that period but to turn automatically to the taxpayer for sustenance. That is the simple question, and I think the answer to that question is one which to most Australians would be apparent. Most Australians, I think, would find it offensive that one can automatically turn to the taxpayer in those circumstances and demand sustenance.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they have paid tax all their life.

—May I move on. If I get fewer interjections, I will get to the stage where I can respond to the points raised by Senator Harradine. I am moving to that. But first I must touch quickly on Senator Haines's and Senator Mason's argument. Senator Haines suggested that it was extremely unchristian to be denying people assistance in the circumstances that this Bill does. I have just tried to illustrate that in fact those people who do not have liquid assets will be able to seek assistance by way of special benefit from the Department. I point out to the Senate that Senator Mason indicated that he would have moved an amendment to this Bill in the Committee stage had he thought he would get any support. The effect of that amendment would have been to apply the Bill exactly as it is drafted for the first three weeks of the strike, and thereafter the present position-that is, the unamended position whereby one is entitled to unemployment benefit-would have applied. So apparently, if we adopt the words of Senator Haines, Senator Mason is suggesting that it is all right to be unchristian for three weeks but it is no good if it goes on any longer. I suggest that Senator Mason's contribution, which did concede that there is community concern about this matter and that extremes of view are to be avoided, takes us some of the way along the track along which the Government is leading us. I believe that it would be consistent with what the Democrats had been saying so loudly in their lead-up to getting elected if the difference of opinion within their ranks-if indeed there is one-were evidenced in their voting pattern and if they stopped caucusing as seriously as the Labor Party ever caucused in the history of this place. I await the vote of the Democrats on this Bill and I have little doubt that they will caucus as successfully on this occasion as they have in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the serious point which Senator McIntosh made in opening his speech and which he has made often in this place about the importance of other factors such as losses of productivity and wealth in this country. He referred to industrial health and safety and so on. Of course, I accept and the government accepts that they also are important matters for consideration by government. It remains true that matters of industrial health and safety are largely outside the direct responsibility of the Commonwalth Government as Senator McIntosh would be very well aware with his trade union background. This is not an argument about health and safety not being relevant to these matters it is a quite separate argument and I believe it stands on its own. I have dealt with the points Senator McIntosh made about Lidice. With respect, I suggest that was a very extreme view to take of this legislation. I believe that when one looks at the history of this matter and the balance which has to be struck between the public responsibility of taxpayers generally to support people against hardship and the trade unionists and unions which take industrial action, often to the detriment of their fellow citizens, one sees that the decision which the Government has taken in putting forward this legislation is based on reason.

There was a request that there be some indication of the figures we are talking about in this area. No exhaustive figures are available but I have asked my Department to extract some examples from situations where it could be clearly seen that there were applications for benefit by wives during strikes. I refer to a series of strikes over the period 1980 to 1981, which give an indication of the amount of money which can be involved in some strikes. I refer firstly to the strike from June to September 1980 at Blackwater in Queensland. The reason for the strike was a dispute about subsidised housing. There were 4,500 people on strike. In that town 411 wives were granted unemployment benefit at a cost of $30,800 per week and 112 wives were granted special benefit at a cost of $8,400 per week. The total cost was $431,475. From 19 January 1981 to 19 March 1981 in Gladstone, Queensland, 176 people were on strike. Forty-seven wives were granted unemployment benefit at a cost of just under $4,000 per week. In Broken Hill from 18 February 1981 to 15 March 1981 2,000 to 2,500 people were on strike and 1,167 wives claimed unemployment benefit at a cost of $99,195 per week. Special benefit of $340 per week was granted making a total cost of $369,274.

From 15 July 1981 to 28 September 1981 a strike took place at the Utah Development Co. mine in Central Queensland. The use of apprentices in industrial action was central to the dispute. There were 600 people on strike. Four hundred and seventy-one wives claimed unemployment benefit at a cost of $40,000 per week, making a total cost of $444,934. At Port Kembla in New South Wales from 19 August, 1981 to 27 September 1981 550 people were on strike. Seventy-five wives claimed unemployment benefit at a cost of $6,375 per week. The total cost was $41,740, including $935 for special benefit. The last example I give is a strike at Gove in the Northern Territory from 14 August 1981 to 28 October 1981. Five hundred and fifty people were on strike. Only six wives claimed unemployment benefit and 99 wives claimed special benefit-the very benefit that will still be available to them. The total cost for that strike was $96,925. The total cost for that group of samples which I asked my Department to extract amounted to $1.422m.

The question is where the social cost of the action taken by the unions should lie. I believe it is reasonable that it should lie at the feet of those who are members of the unions. A great deal of concern was expressed about the ambit of this legislation and how wide it could spread. I simply indicate to the Senate that the legislation affects only those people who are members of unions who are engaged in the strike activity.

A series of points was raised by Senator Harradine who, I think, was seriously directing his attention to the legislation. He raised matters which I know are of real concern to him. He mentioned the fact that there is no definition of industrial action. In fact, there is a definition in section 107 of the Social Services Act. I will not read it to him but there is a definition contained in sub-section (7) of that section. He has also raised the question of cases. I have given a sample of cases which indicate the sort of problem which has given rise to both public and government concern.

More centrally, I think, he raised the fact that this is a measure which by definition can apply only to a one-income family. Quite clearly, if the spouse is employed the is no question of the spouse being eligible for either unemployment benefit or special benefit. By definition this measure could only be a measure which affects one income families. It is an extraordinary proposition to suggest that one could in some way attack the earnings of a spouse who is herself in employment. The question is: Who is responsible for that family? Is the taxpayer primarily and instantly responsible for that family when the trade union of which that man is a member immediately goes on strike, with or without his consent? Again I believe that the judgment is one which has to be that the burden initially is to be borne by that family, with the safeguard that we have given in respect of the grant of special benefit.

Senator Harradine also raised the question of de facto spouses. I refer him to the definitions in section 106 of the Act which clearly indicate that the provision applies to people in a de facto state as well as a formal married state. In respect of whether the action might be legitimate, I say to the Senate that I do not believe that the question of whether a strike is legitimate or illegitimate, on some definition, is the question which is fundamental to the decision in this matter. Surely, if trade unions are to have available to them the strike weapon-I believe there are many people in this country who believe it is a weapon that should not be available to them--
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The devotion of honourable senators opposite to strikes may be a very fine thing. I simply make the point that to very many Australians strikes are becoming thoroughly offensive. There is no point in ignoring that fact. The question is not whether a strike is legitimate or illegitimate but whether the strike action, if a union determines on it, is an action which it can take at a cost to the taxpayer or an action it takes at its own cost. I believe that in that balance which has to be found in this area-which I believe would have been more readily found in the days of a Labor Party led by Mr Chifley than we have any chance of finding today-the Government has made the right decision in bringing forward this legislation. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point or order. I rise to make the point that the Minister has completely ignored the second half of the legislation which refers to the wives of the unemployed who have been taken off relief by the action of the Minister. One assumes that that means the Minister cannot defend those actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point of order.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The provisions of the Census and Statistics Bill (No. 2) before the Senate embody the results of a very thorough re-examination of the Census and Statistics Act, much of which stands as it was drafted in 1905. Successive amendments over the years have resulted in a patchwork of provisions which badly need pulling together. I invite the attention of the Senate to the following aspects of the Bill. Preservation of the confidentiality of information provided to the Bureau of Statistics is regarded by the Government as of the utmost importance. Moreover, it is central to the relationship of confidence and trust that exists between the Bureau and those businesses and households who are asked to provide information for statistical purposes. Therefore section 19 would make it an offence for the Statistician or an officer, present or past, to divulge or communicate information furnished in pursuance of the Act, except to the person from whom the information was obtained. Section 12 would ensure that statistics issued by the Statistician shall not be likely to enable the identification of information relating to a particular person or organisation.

It has, however, emerged from the re-examination to which I referred earlier that literal adherence in all circumstances to those provisions is regarded by respondents to statistical collections as unnecessary and would in a number of respects curtail severely the statistical service which the Statistician can provide. For example, many businesses make publicly available figures on their monthly or annual production, as well as providing them to the Statistician. If they are the sole, or by far the largest, producer of a particular commodity in a particular area, release by the Statistician of production statistics in the desired detail would show a figure which would be identifiable as necessarily relating to, or as a close approximation to, the production of that business. The Act ought to provide a mechanism authorising the Statistician to publish such figures collected under the Act, with the consent of the business involved.

Some information of this nature relating to businesses or government bodies is in fact currently released by the Statistician and the Government has taken the view that the precise categories of such releases and the safeguards by which they are accompanied should be spelled out. Because the intention is that there should be no weakening of the general principle of confidentiality of information provided to the Statistician, information which the Statistician is to be authorised to release needs to be specified in considerable detail. That degree of detail would be inappropriate in legislation.

Section 13 would therefore provide that the minister may, by means of a written determination, authorise the Statistician to release information of a specific kind under specific conditions. It should be noted that no determination may authorise the release of information of a personal or domestic nature in a manner that is likely to enable the identification of any person. It is also important to note that it remains the responsibility of the Statistician, within the specific authorisations, to decide whether or not to release particular figures. In making those decisions he will continue to be guided by an overriding concern to maintain the confidence and trust of respondents to statistical collections. A determination made under section 13 would be tabled in the Parliament, published in the Gazette and be subject to disallowance.

I turn now to the other provisions of the Bill. These do not alter the substance of the powers, functions and duties of the Statistician or the method of operation of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They retain the Minister's power to give general directions to the Australian Statistician to collect statistical information on prescribed matters. Instead of the present separate provisions for the population census and other statistical collections, the Bill substitutes one set of machinery provisions relating to both. Operational detail of the kind now included in the Act regarding the population censuses will in respect of future censuses be set out in regulations. Topics to be included in each population census will be prescribed in one regulation, rather than set out partly in the Act and partly in a regulation.

Maximum penalties incorporated in the Bill are similar to those enacted by Parliament in the autumn session. However, the provision for imposing a sentence of imprisonment for the offence of knowingly providing false information has been omitted. Also, with the redrafting of the secrecy provision, the maximum penalty provided for breaches by officers of that provision has been brought into line with the penalties for similar offences in other Acts to act as a deterrent and as an affirmation of the importance of the principle of confidentiality. Detailed explanations of the amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November on motion by Senator Peter Baume:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill, which authorises the payment of capital grants to the States for the present financial year and for the first six months of the next financial year-that is, for the last six months of calendar year 1982-is a decadent product of the Fraser Government's new federalism policy. New federalism, as expounded by the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) from Opposition in 1975 and from government in 1976, centred on a devolution of power and of responsibility: A reduction in tied Commonwealth payments to the States, an overall reduction in Commonwealth payments to the States and the right of the States to reimpose their own income taxes and to fund a greater proportion of their expenditure from their own revenue sources, including the newly-restored revenue source of a State income tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I say that it is a decadent product of that because at no stage has the Prime Minister made a serious attempt to have that policy actually implemented. This Government has consistently followed a policy of squeezing the States little by little each year but never at any stage to the extent which would have actually forced the States to impose a State income tax, which was supposed to be a central component of the new federalism as originally propounded. Despite the existence of a large majority in both Houses of Parliament for five years, the Prime Minister at no stage made a serious attempt to implement this policy. The reason, as observed by the more astute of his back benchers, is that he is fundamentally a political coward. It is a decadent hybrid because it has squeezed the States enough to hurt them and, of course, to hurt even more the citizens of the States, but never enough actually to force them to impose the alternative policy. In other words, we have fallen between two stools and the consequential situation is worse than either of the two would have been if they had been properly implemented. The squeeze on the States has been made more pernicious and in the long term more damaging because the major squeeze has come on the capital works programs rather than the recurrent expenditure programs. That is again related to political cowardice. It is politically more expedient to force cuts in the capital works programs than in recurrent expenditure programs. The consequences of capital starvation take a number of years to become fully apparent.

When the Bill was debated in the House of Representatives Ralph Willis incorporated in Hansard a table showing in real terms the progressive squeeze on capital expenditure as authorised by the grants under this Bill and including borrowings by the States authorised by the Loan Council. It showed that in every year the capital squeeze on the States has been intensified. From 1975-76 to the current year there has, in fact, been a fall of almost 45 per cent in real terms in State capital expenditure authorised by this Act and by Loan Council borrowings. The macroeconomic effects of that progressive and continuing reduction in State capital expenditure will be more serious in the current financial year than it has been in most years for the simple reason that on the Government's optimistic estimates non-farm real gross domestic product will increase by 3 per cent in this year. Such an extremely low level of growth inevitably entails a rise in unemployment even if that 3 per cent target is realised. As time goes by it becomes more and more doubtful that it will be realised. For these reasons, at this stage, I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill, by further sharply reducing the real level of funds for State government capital works, is-
(a) making it impossible for the States to provide an adequate capital expenditure program;
(b) reducing the extent and standard of community services;
(c) undermining the efficiency and productive capacity of many industries, especially the building industry;
(d) producing unbalanced development by facilitating expansion of infrastructure for the resource industries while severely contracting expenditure on the social infrastructure;
(e) increasing unemployment; and
(f) intensifying pressure on the States to introduce a second income tax'.

In respect of the last point, the Bill certainly intensifies the pressure on the States to introduce a second income tax but it does not go actually far enough to force the States into a position where they really have no alternative but to impose a second income tax, which was an essential component of the Fraser federalism package. If the States will not make a serious attempt to raise enough revenue to compensate for the loss of Commonwealth grants, the outcome of this policy will be a reduction in State capital investments with the damaging short term macroeconomic effect of increasing unemployment and the more serious, but less easily perceived, long term damage resulting from a progressive rundown in the nation's public capital stock and social infrastructure.

The rationale for this policy of squeezing the States, in particular in recent years, is the belief of the Government that lower levels of Commonwealth Government spending will lead to lower government or public sector borrowing requirements and, therefore, to a fall in interest rates. That, as the empirical record shows, is one of the many exercises in self-delusion by this Government. In fact, since 1977-78, public sector borrowing as a percentage of gross domestic product has fallen from 5.3 per cent to an estimated 3.6 per cent this year. That continuous and very substantial fall in public sector borrowing has been accompanied not by falling interest rates, as the Government's massive self-delusion leads it to believe, but by a continuing increase in interest rates. I hasten to add that I am not arguing that because those two things have happened-that is, a falling public sector borrowing requirement and rising interest rates-the increase in interest rates is caused by the falling public sector borrowing requirement. Of course, to argue that would be as absurd as to believe the Government's rationale.

I make that point to illustrate that the situation is very much more complex than the simplistic dogma of this Government recognises. Interest rates have risen continuously since 1977-78 while the public sector borrowing requirement has fallen. Interest rates have risen notwithstanding the promise of the Prime Minister in the 1977 election campaign that: 'Interest rates will fall by 2 per cent over the coming year. It is a target that can and will be met.' In fact, since that promise of a 2 per cent fall in interest rates was given, interest rates have risen by between 3 and 4 per cent, depending on which type of interest rate one likes to examine. Indeed, in the unregulated market they have probably risen by a great deal more than 4 per cent.

Of course, interest rates have not gone up for everyone because, as we know, there are a number of privileged people with access to the levers of political and administrative power in this country who have ensured that they pay interest rates of 4 1/2 per cent and 6 1/4 per cent. Senior Ministers of this Government, who granted themselves housing loans at those interest rates in 1964 and 1970, still have those loans, have made negligible repayments of the principal in each case and, 11 and 17 years respectively after they granted themselves the loans, still have them and still pay interest rates of 4 1/2 per cent and 6 1/4 per cent. Mr Anthony pays 4 1/2 per cent interest and Mr Nixon pays 6 1/4 per cent. If this Government is to have any moral credibility in the area of interest rates, if the Prime Minister had any sense of decency, the Government would demand at the very least that these interest rate bludgers-senior Ministers Anthony and Nixon, who are bludging on the rest of the community and on their fellow taxpayers-repay those loans immediately. Indeed, I suggest that given the high incomes and other privileges of these two senior Ministers a very strong case could be made for the Prime Minister going much further and instructing these interest bludgers to return the properties, the houses, to the taxpayers from whom they have been filched.

The deteriorating economic situation, which was flagged in the Budget and which appears to have deteriorated further since that time, and which has caused to a substantial degree this squeeze on funds to the States for capital purposes included in this legislation, has apparently caused the Government to reassess its position and to start looking around for some new policies to cope with the intensifying slow-down-if the rate is not actually negative-in the present rate of growth. The response which the Government has come up with is to go out on the Arab loan market in an attempt to borrow funds. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) yesterday tried to pass off this entry into the Arab loan market as 'a courtesy call', to use his words. He said it was simply a courtesy call by a senior official of the Australian Treasury on Saudi financial officials while he was passing through Riyadh on his way back from Switzerland. A courtesy call, if that is all it is, does not require Cabinet approval, as the Treasurer also acknowledged this visit had received. Nor, if it was simply a courtesy call, would there be any need for the extreme secrecy which has surrounded the whole operation. Nor would there be any need for the Treasury Secretary's reference, in his now famous letter, to the political sensitivity of this attempt to enter the Arab loan market.

The claim is simply not credible when one looks at the evidence produced by the Government. The evidence is that Cabinet approved this contact, that negotiations were conducted in secret-or at least the intention was that they be conducted in secret-and that the Treasury's Secretary referred to it as a matter of great political sensitivity. That situation is consistent not with a courtesy call; it is consistent with the behaviour of a government which is actually serious about raising money from Saudi Arabia.

There are valid reasons for secrecy and, of course, for Cabinet approval if a government is actually trying to borrow. There are no valid reasons for secrecy and there is no need for Cabinet approval if a government is simply sending a Treasury official to pay a courtesy call on officials of a foreign country for general discussions about the state of the world. Des Moore, Mr Williams, or whatever his name is, is quite clearly attempting to secure a chaffbag full of Saudi petro-dollars on behalf of this Government. There is other objective evidence that the Government could well be considering substantial overseas borrowings. The balance of trade is sick; it has been for several months. There is no indication that that is likely to change in the short term. Any realistic government would have, by now, revised downwards its expectations of capital inflow for this financial year.

As a result of those two factors, it is quite clear that intensifying pressure is emerging for a devaluation of the Australian dollar. It is more than conceivable that the Government would resist that by borrowing overseas. The state of the external account is fully consistent with an attempt to borrow substantial amounts overseas by a government which wanted to resist devaluation of the dollar. So, for all those reasons and in spite of the protestations of innocence of the Treasurer yesterday, the only reasonable conclusion is that the Government is making a serious attempt to borrow Saudi petro-dollars.

If the Minister seeks to deny that, I invite her to tell the Senate whether it is standard practice for information about any Treasury official going to pay a courtesy call on a treasury official of another country, whether information about such a courtesy call has ever gone to Cabinet, and whether an attempt to maintain secrecy is consistent with a government which is serious about borrowing overseas or consistent with a government which is just going to have informal discussions with treasury officials from a foreign country.

Before closing, I want to make one point regarding the Premier of my State in respect of this legislation. When new federalism was first expounded by the present Prime Minister one of his strongest supporters was the Premier of Western Australia. Mr Fraser said that it entailed a devolution of power and greater responsibility. Sir Charles Court heard and heeded the reference to more power and either did not hear, or chose to ignore, the reference to greater responsibility. Sir Charles Court's interpretation of new federalism was that it would be a device to increase the power of the States without imposing any additional responsibility on the States. On that basis, Sir Charles Court, who is a devout believer in gaining more power but who consistently rejects the notion that he should accept any more responsibility to go with the power, was a strong supporter of Mr Fraser. He was deaf also to the advice of those among us which, of course, included me, who attempted to tell him as far back as 1975 and 1976 that if this policy were actually implemented it would have particularly severe financial consequences for Western Australia. Eventually, he woke up. He woke up last year. He said that if he had known that this was what new federalism was all about when it was first talked about in 1975 he would not have had a bar of it. Although the Senate has no realistic option but to support this legislation as the alternative to supporting the legislation is no capital grants to the States, I hope that the Senate also decides that it is time to tell the Fraser Government that it does not want any more of this degenerate, hybridised version of new federalism and shows its opinion by voting for the amendment that I have moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill deals with one-third of the States' Loan Council borrowing programs for 1981-82. Perhaps honourable senators ought to recall that the Loan Council, at its June meeting, approved a program for the State governments of $1,307.25m for 1981-82, of which borrowings comprised two-thirds, $871.5m, and one-third, $435.75m, is to be provided as capital grants to the States. These amounts are the same as those approved in 1980-81. Funds to the States from the Commonwealth Budget are estimated to total $12,791m in 1980-81, an increase of 8.5 per cent. This represents nearly one-third of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays this year. Payments to or for the States, in addition to the general purpose capital funds and borrowings, are expected to total $11,484m in 1981-82. It is interesting to note that all but $4,477m of this amount involves general purpose funds which may, of course, be spent by the States however they see fit, including on capital works projects.

SPEECH.PARA: The Loan Council at its June meeting approved an increase in the larger State semi-government authorities borrowing programs of 11.2 per cent to $2,098.3m for 1981-82. This included infrastructure borrowings for such authorities of $806.7m. We are talking about sizeable figures-about one-third of the estimated Commonwealth budget outlays-when we are talking about grants to the States and Loan Council approvals relating to the States. In 1981-82 the package of funds to the States, including the Loan Council borrowing programs, has been carefully designed both within the constraints of the Commonwealth's continuing policy of responsible restraint on public sector spending and with a view to giving the States further flexibility in determining their own priorities. I note there is no opposition to the Bills in the Senate. I note also the amendment to this Bill that has been moved by the Opposition. The Government does not support the amendment but it thanks the Senate for the speedy passage of the States Grants (Capital Assistance) Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) in her normal fashion, was far too quick for me in replying to the second reading debate. I do not want to be contentious on this issue; I just want to make a point. I do not know whether the Australian Labor Party proposes to divide on this issue.
—Probably.

—Having read the Labor amendment moved by Senator Walsh, my first reaction is that I do not disagree with most of it. I am not adopting this attitude out of any personal petulance, but as a senator elected to this chamber I am not going to sit here for this entire debate, which I have done, have put on my desk an amendment which neither any member of my party nor I have been paid the courtesy of being warned that the Labor Party would move, and then be asked to support it on the run. I do not believe that that is the way in which a responsible senator ought to approach amendments to legislation in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: After quickly looking at the wording of Senator Walsh's amendment, which has been approved by the Labor Party and of which we had no notice, I do not disagree with most of it. But on sheer principle, if there is a division on this matter-I am now informed there will be-I for one, and I am sure I speak for most of my colleagues, will not take a piece of paper being thrust in front of me by the Labor Party with the words: 'This condemns the Government. Will you support it?' We were not even asked that. We were not even told an amendment would be moved. That is not good enough. The same thing occurred earlier this afternoon when Senator Harradine moved an amendment to another Bill. No member of my Party, including me, received any notice of it. I do not think any member of the Labor Party received notice of his amendment. That is just not the way to go about getting co-operation in this chamber and proper consideration of the important business that is before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Australian Labor Party I accept Senator Chipp's rebuke and take responsibility for it. I should have notified the Australian Democrats that the amendment would be moved. However, an identical amendment, save only for a change in words that was required because this amendment was moved in the Senate, was moved in the House of Representatives by Ralph Willis on 17 November. I thought that Senator Chipp at least would have known that it is customary, indeed almost invariable, for Labor Party amendments such as those moved in the House of Representatives to be moved in the Senate. Nevertheless, I apologise for not giving the Democrats direct notice earlier and accept the responsibility for it.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation. Senator Chipp indicated a moment ago that the action taken by Senator Walsh in regard to the amendment moved was similar to the one that I had taken previously in the afternoon in regard to an amendment to a previous Bill. I mention to Senator Chipp that I had advised the Australian Democrats senator who was in charge of that Bill that I was considering moving an amendment to refer the Bill to a select committee. I had also notified the Australian Labor Party senator in charge of the Bill that I was considering doing that. I feel that there was nothing further that I could do. There was no motion I could move or notice that I could give. I could only move the amendment, which I did in the terms that I had advised of on both occasions. Again, last night there was some suggestion that advice had not been received about my proposed amendment, but it was exactly the same amendment as I had proposed previously on the fees Bill. It was precisely the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, it seems to be the fashion to seek leave to make personal explanations on this somewhat contentious matter.
—Is leave granted for Senator Haines to make a personal explanation?
—We made a ruling earlier that we would have some indication of what personal explanations were to be about. Could we have an indication of what the personal explanation is about?
—I assumed that Senator Robertson would have collected that it was on the same matter as Senator Walsh spoke on.
—I would not assume that at all; I never assume anything. You explain what you want leave for.
—I want to add some remarks to what Senator Harradine and Senator Walsh have just spoken on.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been some difficulty over this amendment of Senator Harradine and, I gather, with Senator Walsh, in not being able to get amendments in front of people in time. Senator Chipp mentioned he was in the same position as Senator Walsh in not getting Senator Harradine's amendment before us. Senator Harradine quite rightly pointed out that he mentioned it to me. In fact the Australian Labor Party, Senator Harradine and a number of us discussed over the last week or so whether it would be a good idea to refer the Bill to a committee. Therefore, as Senator Walsh accepted responsibility on behalf of his party, I think I ought to accept the responsibility for not making that point clear to Senator Chipp. I do not wish to cause any problems.

That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walsh's amendment) be added.
