SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Queensland Grant (Special Assistance) Bill 1981. The Australian Labor Party does not oppose this Bill but I intend to use this debate to outline some of the less satisfactory aspects of the disbursement of grants that have been made under previous legislation of a similar nature. I have outlined before in this chamber that I took a special interest in reports of the Commonwealth Grants Commission after I become associated with the Commission as a public servant in Queensland. When I was working with one Queensland department I assisted in the preparation of documents which were submitted to the Grants Commission. These submissions, in addition to submissions from other Queensland government departments, were considered by the Commission when it was deciding what, if any, financial assistance should be made available to Queensland. On one occasion I appeared as a departmental witness and this gave me an even greater insight into the day to day workings of the Commission. That experience boosted my interest in the Commission's activities and I became even more interested in those reports of the Commission which specifically refer to Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of the Bill before the Senate is to authorise special grants totalling $58.5m to Queensland. These grants are the consequences of the recommendations of the Grants Commission's forty-eighth report. It is worth recalling that the Grants Commission was appointed in 1933. It made its first report in July the following year, mentioning applications made by South Australia, Western Australia, and Tasmania. The fact that the Commission has been in existence for about 50 years made the record of Parliament's total acceptance of its recommendations quite remarkable. Since being a member of the Senate I have been interested to hear every time a report of the Grants Commission is debated in relation to special grants to one or more States the following words in the Minister's second reading speech: 'The Commission's recommendations in relation to the special grants arrangements have been adopted by the Parliament since the Commission's inception and the Government considers that they should be accepted on this occasion'. This practice should continue to be followed unless there are some exceptional circumstances which have not yet arisen in the 48 years of the Commission's existence.

As a senator for Queensland, I wholeheartedly support the payment of $58.5m to Queensland, but I do have some reservations about the way in which previous grants have been used. I shall elaborate on those reservations at a later stage. The existence of the Commonwealth Grants Commission acknowledges that some States suffer financial disabilities in comparison with New South Wales and Victoria, often referred to in this context as the two standard States. In other words, it acknowledges the fact that within our federal system there is a financial inequality between the States. One of the tasks of the Commonwealth Grants Commission has been to investigate this financial inequality when a request has been made for it to do so. It has structured its recommendations in such a way as to ensure that residents in the State investigated are able to enjoy services similar to those provided to their fellow Australians in the standard States of New South Wales and Victoria. One of the strengths of our federation is that we can minimise inequalities between the States by using, amongst other measures, the Commonwealth Grants Commission. On the other hand, it is difficult for the Commonwealth to minimise inequalities within States. Some progress in this area has been made by way of funds payable under the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act. Nevertheless, a great deal remains to be done in this regard. In general, given the provisions of the constitutional constraints under which the Federal Government operates, the States themselves are required to minimise the inequalities within their boundaries.

It is easy to understand why Queensland is at a disadvantage in relation to the two standard States. I shall outline some of those reasons. An examination of the populations of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria immediately reveals the disadvantage which confronts Queensland. In March this year the population of Queensland was 2.3 million, the population of Victoria was 3.9 million, and that of New South Wales was 5.2 million. One disadvantage that occurs as a consequence of the lower population of Queensland in comparison with Victoria and New South Wales is that Queensland has access to less taxation revenue. This is exacerbated by the relatively lower income per head of population in Queensland. For example, the household income per head of mean population in Queensland in 1979-80 was $6,328. In New South Wales the figure was $6,851 and in Victoria it was $6,798. It is interesting to note that the income per head in Queensland is lower than the total Australian average.

Not only has Queensland a smaller population and a smaller per capita income, it also has a larger area than the two standard States. It is the second largest State in the Commonwealth. The area of Queensland is 1.7 million square kilometres, whereas Victoria has an area of only 0.2 million square kilometres and New South Wales 0.8 million square kilometres. When other factors are equal it is easier to provide services for a smaller population, but when that population is distributed over a large area the cost of providing those services becomes greater. In this regard it is well to recognise that Queensland is a highly decentralised State. Major areas of population extend from Brisbane to Cairns. There are large coastal or near coastal centres such as the cities of Gympie, Maryborough, Bundaberg, Gladstone, Rockhampton, Mackay and Townsville. It is also worthwhile to note that there are some reasonable centres of population north of Cairns. Additionally, two major cities, Toowoomba and Mount Isa, are situated in inland Queensland.

The vast distances in Queensland are a function of the State's large area. To travel by air from Brisbane to the northern city of Cairns one covers a distance of 1,435 kilometres. That is a long way when compared with the distances in the standard States of New South Wales and Victoria. One can go from Brisbane to another major city and travel even further than the Brisbane to Cairns distance I have mentioned. The distance by air between Brisbane and Mount Isa is 1,580 kilometres. To travel from Brisbane to Boigu Island, which is close to the Papua New Guinea border, one covers 2,315 kilometres-a distance far in excess of that from Brisbane to Melbourne. The fact that such vast distances separate the major centres of population puts Queensland at a disadvantage in providing services equivalent to those provided in the standard States. When the Commonwealth Grants Commission examines the case made by a claimant State it directs its attention to what are termed 'revenue needs' and 'expenditure needs'. Part of the forty-eighth report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission referred to these two types of needs. In part, paragraph 1.7 reads:

. . . the Commission has compared the fiscal capacity of Queensland with that of New South Wales and Victoria, which are referred to as the standard States, taking into account differences in the revenue-raising capacity and differences in the cost of providing comparable services. Separate calculations are thus made from what the Comission refers to as revenue needs and expenditure needs respectively.

In determining these revenue and expenditure needs the Commonwealth Grants Commission conducts hearings at which it is able to elicit information about relevant disabilities which confront those who administer a claimant State. Naturally the Commission also uses any statistical data which are available to it. On 30 September 1971 Queensland applied for a special grant for the year 1971-72. Until recently it was the only claimant State to the Grants Commission. Queensland has withdrawn its application for special assistance for 1981-82 and now there are no claimant States. It is relevant to mention the other non-standard States and to indicate when they ceased to be claimant States. South Australia ceased to be a claimant State on 1 July 1975. This was a result of an agreement between the Commonwealth and South Australian Governments in relation to the transfer of the non-metropolitan South Australian railway system. Tasmania made, but later withdrew, applications for special grants for the years 1974-75, 1975-76 and 1977-78. In reality Tasmania ceased to be a claimant State in 1974. Tasmania's withdrawal as a claimant State was the result of other additional finances being made available to it. Western Australia was last a claimant State in 1968-69.

I mentioned earlier that the Grants Commission determines revenue and expenditure needs for a claimant State. What the Grants Commission assessed to be the revenue needs for Queensland for 1979-80 are shown in its forty-eighth report. Queensland's revenue needs were grouped under two main headings-'Taxation' and 'Territorial Revenue'. Under the heading of 'Taxation' the Grants Commission assessed the revenue need for Queensland as being $86.077m. I refer those honourable senators who are interested in how this figure was determined to chapter 4 of the forty-eighth report. When territorial revenue was considered, however, there was a significant difference. The Grants Commission considered that in this case there was a negative need. In other words, Queensland had above standard revenue capacity in this area, due in part to royalties from black coal.
Its capacity to raise finance in this area was higher than that of the standard States of New South Wales and Victoria. For territorial revenue the negative need was assessed at $38.72m.

The expenditure needs for Queensland were grouped under a number of headings. These were: 'Social services', 'Business Undertakings' and a group of miscellaneous expenditure items. these assessed expenditure needs were all positive. That is, Queensland was at a disadvantage in relation to the two standard States. Page 49 of the forty-eighth report outlines how the Commission arrived at a sum of $44.5m, which is the Commission's assessed grant for 1979-80. From this figure is subtracted $11m which was advanced earlier, but $25m is added as an advance for 1980-81. This provides a total grant of $58.5m, the amount being authorised by this Bill. Although I am pleased to see a sum of $58.5m being made available to the State which I represent I am concerned at the way that the Queensland Government has deliberately withheld from previous grants some funding which should have, morally at least, gone to the Brisbane City Council. I have outlined before in this chamber how the Queensland Government has behaved in an unbelievably immoral way in relation to the funds which it has received over recent years by way of various Queensland Grant (Special Assistance) Acts. In some respects a more precise comment about the Queensland Government's actions would be that it is guilty of grand larceny. Even though I have mentioned this matter in this place before, I intend to outline some aspects of this action again today as the sorry tale bears repeating.

In making the assessment of expenditure needs for business undertakings the Commonwealth Grants Commission takes into account metropolitan road transport. Metropolitan transport in the Brisbane area is not a responsibility of the Queensland Government. It is a service provided by the Brisbane City Council. When Queensland became a claimant State in 1971 the Commonwealth Grants Commission took note of the fact that the Queensland Government did not provide public road transport in the Brisbane area. The two standard States, New South Wales and Victoria, are, however, responsible for public transport in their respective capital cities. The Commonwealth Grants Commission therefore recorded that in this area Queensland had a negative need. For instance, in 1973-74 the expenditure per capita for metropolitan road transport in the standard States was calculated at $5.23. The Grants Commission therefore determined that in relation to metropolitan road transport Queensland had a negative need of $5.23 per capita or a total of $10.171m. This latter amount was taken from the assessed needs of Queensland in determining the amount of grant which should be payable to that State. Naturally this meant that the Queensland grant suffered because metropolitan road transport was not a Queensland Government responsibility.

Late in 1975 at the request of the then Treasurer of Queensland, Sir Gordon Chalk, the Brisbane City Council made a submission to the Commonwealth Grants Commission. This submission requested that the Commission take into account the cost of the Council's transport undertaking in determining the State's grants allocation. The Commission agreed with the view that it would be consistent with its principles to take account of the costs incurred by the Brisbane City Council in assessing Queensland's needs. On page 74 of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's forty-third report the Commission states:
Such an approach would more adequately show the financial consequences of a notional application of the metropolitan transport policies of the standard States.

It is worth noting that the road transport provided by the Brisbane City Council is quite significant. It carries about 150,000 passengers each normal working day. Over a whole year approximately 42 million passengers use the Brisbane City Council bus service. The service extends over 646 kilometres and travels about 20 million kilometres a year. The Brisbane City Council transport department has 537 buses, 829 drivers and a total staff of 1,438. The bus service operated by the Brisbane City Council carries 35 per cent more passengers than the suburban railway system, including rail passengers to and from the nearby city of Ipswich. The service, therefore, is a significant part of Brisbane's public transport system.

In 1975 as a result of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's taking into account the Brisbane City Council bus service, Queensland's grant was increased by $7.085m on account of the 1974-75 deficit of the Council's transport undertaking. This occurred because Queensland's assessed negative need per capita in relation to metropolitan road transport was no longer equated to the expenditure per capita in the standard States, as was the case prior to the time when costs incurred by the Brisbane City Council were not taken into account. I am informed that, at the time when Sir Gordon Chalk made his initial request for Council assistance in providing a submission to the Grants Commission, he undertook that, if the State was successful in extending its claim into this new field, it would be in a much better position to assist the Council with its urban transport losses. Unfortunately for the Counicl, Sir Gordon Chalk retired in August 1976. Nevertheless, in late 1976, when advice of the Grants Commission determination was received, the Council looked expectantly to the State for the promised assistance. No assistance was forthcoming and the incoming Treasurer, Mr Knox, now Sir William Knox, refused to acknowledge that these considerations by the Grants Commission had, in any way, increased Queensland's grant. Instead, the State Government pocketed the whole $7.085m.

In mid-1977, the Brisbane City Council became so exasperated with the Treasurer's repudiation of its claims that it sought some answers from Federal parliamentary sources in relation to the Grants Commission's funding. Answers were supplied by the then Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Withers. The questions and answers established beyond doubt the validity of the Council's claim and the legitimacy of its expectations in regard to the $7.085m. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of Senator Withers's letter to the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Alderman Sleeman, and the questions and answers in relation to the Commonwealth Grants Commission's funding.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Appendix A
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA
Minister for Administrative Services 12 July 1977
My dear Lord Mayor,

I refer to a recent telex message that you sent to the Acting Minister for Transport, Mr Macphee, concerning the allocation of funds related to the Brisbane City Council's public transport undertaking. Mr Macphee has asked me to reply to you directly.
I am pleased to provide the information as set out in the attached papers.
I am sending copies of this letter and the attached papers to the Minister for Transport.
Yours sincerely, (R. G. WITHERS)
The Rt Hon. Alderman F. N. Sleeman,
Lord Mayor of Brisbane,
Lord Mayor's Office,
Brisbane, Qld 4000
Did the Grants Commission take account of the loss incurred by the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking in assessing Queensland's expenditure needs?
Yes.

Was this the first occasion on which the Grants Commission has taken account of the loss incurred by the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking in assessing Queensland's expenditure needs?

Yes. Queensland first applied for a special grant for the year 1971-72. Prior to 1974-75, however, the Commission did not have access to data which would have allowed it to take losses incurred by the Brisbane City Council's Transport Undertaking into account in assessing Queensland's needs for Metropolitan Transport.

Was the assessed special grant for Queensland 1974-75 increased over what it would otherwise have been because the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking deficit in that year, modified for the relevant policy differences, was taken into account?
Yes.

Was the amount of Queensland's assessed needs met from other Commonwealth Grants for 1974-75 increased over what it would otherwise have been because the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking deficit in that year, modified for the policy differences, was taken into account?

No. The amount of Queensland's assessed needs met from other Commonwealth Grants was $113.6 million in respect of the year 1974-75. This amount was not affected by the Commission's treatment of the losses incurred by the Brisbane City Council's Transport Undertaking.
By what amount was Queensland's assessed special grant for 1974-75 increased on account of the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking modified deficit, being taken into account?

$7,085,000. The special grant paid to Queensland for the year 1974-75 was $24 million. The amount of this special grant would have been $16,915,000 had the losses on the Brisbane City Council's Transport Undertaking for that year not been taken into account. It should be noted, however, that the Commission still assessed negative needs of $7,596,000 in respect of Queensland's Metropolitan Road Transport for the year 1974-75.

By what amount was Queensland's assessed needs met from other Commonwealth Grants for 1974-75, increased on account of the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking modified deficit, being taken into account?
See answer to Question 3(B).

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. All the information provided by Senator Withers is of importance. In particular, I shall quote from question and answer 4 (A). Question 4 (A) states:

SPEECH.PARA: By what amount was Queensland's assessed special grant for 1974-75 increased on account of the Brisbane City Council's Street Public Transport Undertaking modified deficit, being taken into account?

In part, the answer to question 4 (A) was: '$7,085,000'. In each of the years subsequent to 1975, the Commonwealth Grants Commission has taken into account the Brisbane City Council's transport undertaking. On each occasion, significant sums have been included in the grant to the State due to this bus service. As supporting evidence of my assertion, I refer honourable senators to the answer by the then Minister for Transport, Mr Nixon, in reply to a question in the House of Representatives asked by the honourable member for Griffith, Mr Humphreys. The answer appears in the House of Representatives Hansard for 9 May 1979 at page 2047. In part, the answer refers to losses made by the Brisbane City Council Transport Department. It states:

If the Commission had not taken these losses into account the special grants recommended for payment would have been reduced as follows: 1974-75, $24m to $16.915m; 1975-76, $35.8m to $29.178m; and, 1976-77, $23.7m to $14.048m.

In other words, in each of the years mentioned in the answer to the question raised by the honourable member for Griffith, Mr Humphreys, Queensland would have received a significantly lower grant if the losses of the Brisbane City Council transport undertaking had not been taken into account.

It must be noted that some funding has been made available to the Brisbane City Council transport service from the State Government since 1975-76. In 1975-76 and the following year, some funds were made available to assist in providing fare concessions for students. In 1977-78, a State Government scheme was introduced whereby a subsidy amounting to 50 per cent of fare collections was paid to the Council. Nevertheless, the subsidy in that and subsequent years fell far below the funds which the State Government received from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. I have outlined, in tabular form, the amounts which the Queensland Government has received by way of Commonwealth Grants Commission grants due to the inclusion of metropolitan road transport in the assessment of Queensland's financial needs. Also listed in the table are amounts which have been paid by the Queensland Government to the Brisbane City Council. The table is based on Commonwealth Grants Commission reports, Mr Nixon's answer, to which I referred a few moments ago, and information provided by the Parliamentary Library and the Brisbane City Council. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table reveals that in 1974-75 the Queensland Government received $7.085m because of the inclusion of metropolitan road transport in the assessment of Queensland's needs. In that year the Queensland Government passed nothing on to the Brisbane City Council. In 1975-76 and 1976-77 amounts of $6.622m and $9.652m respectively were included in the Queensland Government's assessed needs because of the metropolitan road transport factor. In those two years $900,000 and $1m respectively were passed on to the Brisbane City Council for fare subsidies for students. In 1977-78 $12.274m were paid to the State Government because of metropolitan road transport undertakings in Brisbane but only $4.886m were passed on to the Brisbane City Council. In 1978-79 the figures were $13.927m and $5.17m respectively. Finally, in 1979-80, the year discussed in the 48th report, which is the basis of the Bill before us, $16.3m were paid to the State Government because of the metropolitan road transport undertakings of the Brisbane City Council, but only $6.405m were passed on to the Council. I should mention at this stage that for 1979-80 a slightly different methodology was used by the Grants Commission. The figure of $16.3m which I mentioned for that particular year did not appear in the 48th report but was provided to me by the Grants Commission through the Parliamentary Library.

SPEECH.PARA: If one examines the table it is possible to see that between 1974-75 and 1979-80 Commonwealth funds made available to the State Government because of Brisbane City Council metropolitan transport undertakings totalled $65.86m. In the same period the State Government funded the Brisbane City Council for its transport undertakings to the tune of $18.361m; that is, about $47m stayed in the coffers of the Queensland Government. What this means is that the Commonwealth Grants Commission has recommended that funds be paid to the Queensland Government for metropolitan road transport but that those funds have not been passed on to the operators of the metropolitan transport, namely, the Brisbane City Council. Whilst there is no legal basis under the legislation we are now debating for certain funds to be passed on to the Brisbane City Council, there is certainly a moral obligation on the Queensland Government to do so. Many political observers would understand that sometimes in the current government in Queensland-one which owes its present majority to a severely malapportioned system of electorates-almost anything goes. It is, of course, noteworthy that the major party in the coalition Government in Queensland, the National Party, does not have one seat in the Brisbane metropolitan area.

This account that I have given in relation to the way the Queensland Government has withheld funds from the Brisbane City Council is just one more example of the way the Queensland Government operates. It must feel very smug when it reflects on how, in the last six years, it has received $65.86m because of the Brisbane City Council's bus operations but it has passed on only $18.361m to the bus operators. A cool $47.499m has been socked away because of a clear disregard of a moral obligation of the Queensland Government. I have brought this information before the Senate to make it possible for honourable senators to see the way in which Commonwealth funds are being misapplied by the Government of Queensland. I do not oppose the passage of this legislation because I am anxious to see the recommended funds go to the State which I represent. I do, however, strongly condemn the Queensland Government for withholding funds which rightfully belong to the Brisbane City Council or, to put it another way, to the citizens and ratepayers of Brisbane.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Queensland Grant (Special Assistance) Bill 1981, which gives $58.5m in 1981-82 as special grants in respect of 1979-80 and 1980-81 on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. It is my pleasure to make some comments in this debate on behalf of Queensland. As has already been established in the debate, the basis of the grant is established by the Grants Commission. Factors taken into account in assessing the grant are the tax raising capacity of Queensland and the cost of providing government services throughout Queensland. There have been previous debates in the Senate-I must admit not this debate-in which it has been suggested that Queensland receives too much from Federal Government revenues and there ought to be some equalising process.
—Hear, hear!

—I do not intend to canvass all those issues tonight. I shall if invited, of course, but it was not my intention when I rose to speak to canvass all those issues. The simple fact is that Queensland has some special grounds for claiming special assistance via the Grants Commission. The amount provided in this Bill is the amount recommended by that independent body. Of the two bases for the grant, the cost of providing government services in Queensland is, of course, very large. Two factors are involved, the size of the State and the distribution of the population. Size in itself is not the total factor. The fact that we have a population of approximately two and a half million spread throughout our State, which is one-fifth the area of Australia, makes it very difficult for government to provide services.

SPEECH.PARA: Decentralisation of industry and population is something that we all claim to espouse in Australia today. We need to face the fact that certain costs come with it. Queensland is a highly decentralised State. It has significant townships spread throughout its area. Those townships are growing as Queensland develops. That means that certain extra provisions must be sought. The State Government does its own bit in the development of Queensland in providing some of the costs of that development.

There have been some criticisms, particularly from certain industries, about the fact that industries are required to pay infrastructure costs and high royalties as they develop in Queensland. Nevertheless, they obviously find it very profitable to develop those industries in Queensland or they would not be there. It is reasonable to expect that certain infrastructure costs should be borne by industries and not by government, either State or Federal, because those industries go to certain parts of Queensland in order to develop profitable prospects.

The tax raising capacity of Queensland is also limited. In a previous debate on the subject in the Senate I drew the attention of honourable senators to some of these factors. Queensland has been in receipt of a special grant from the Commonwealth on the recommendation of the Commonwealth Grants Commission in every year since 1971-72. These special grants are assessed only after comprehensive inquiry, with evidence under oath, by this expert independent body. They are based on a direct comparison between Queensland and the standard States of New South Wales and Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Western Australia?

—Western Australians speak very well for themselves. Queensland has been assessed as being entitled to supplementary assistance because of its relative fiscal position compared with New South Wales and Victoria. Further, whilst it is true that Queensland has no statutory corporation payments, no petrol tax, no tobacco tax and no probate duty whatsoever, the Grants Commission through its procedures calculates the notional revenue for Queensland based on the taxation rate applicable in the standard States. In other words, it assesses what Queensland would raise if it had those taxes and incorporates this in the assessment it makes of Queensland's revenue and expenditure needs. It even calculates the revenue that Queensland would raise if it had poker machines-perish the thought.

SPEECH.PARA: Queensland has over the past decade received no more than its just entitlement from tax sharing. It has been able to achieve this only through constant application for grants and special assistance which entail a great deal of extra work and submission to searching inquiry from the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Of course, the matter of taxation assessment is not the whole story of Queensland and its claim to certain consideration under Commonwealth Government financial arrangements. The contribution of Queensland to the Australian economy as a whole is very great. It is because of the contribution that States such as Queensland and Western Australia make that all Australians enjoy a high standard of living. It is a pity that credit is not given to that fact by other States. I think the claims that some other States have to special consideration in matters relating to things such as tariffs would have more credibility if they would take a national view of the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not bringing up that old chestnut again, surely?

—I point out to Senator Missen that it is Victoria that is complaining. While States receive a percentage of personal income tax back from the Commonwealth, their contribution to Commonwealth revenues to the economy generally can be far greater than personal income tax alone. In this regard profits from unsubsidised industries in Queensland and Western Australia add significantly to national economic wealth, as do the substantial export earnings generated again by both Queensland and Western Australia. Indeed, if it were not for the export surpluses that Queensland and Western Australia earn, we could not afford the tariffs which presently obtain so advantageously for Victoria. Overall, Queensland is not a favoured State. As has been pointed out in debates since 1971-72 it has been claiming special consideration from the Commonwealth Grants Commission and has been receiving special grants. As I have pointed out these are assessed on an objective basis which has no disadvantage at all for any of the other non-claimant States. In fact there are certain inherent disadvantages for Queensland in that taxes which do not normally apply in all States in Australia are taken into account in assessment of the amount of money Queensland should receive.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of specific purpose payments and borrowing programs Queensland does not receive an advantage. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard a table contained in the Budget Papers which sets out the specific purpose payments, works and borrowings programs for 1980-81 for all States.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That table shows that under the heading 'Population share' Queensland ranks third with 15.6 per cent of the population. Under 'Recurrent specific purpose payments' it ranks third with 14.5 per cent-well behind New South Wales and Victoria. Under 'Works and borrowing programs' Queensland again ranks third with 17.3 per cent. So, there is no inherent advantage for Queensland in those areas either. I take the opportunity to make a couple of comments in general terms about the economic position in which Queensland finds itself relative to other States. In fact, the subject to which I particularly refer, a subject about which I have not had an opportunity to say anything since Senator Siddons became a member of this chamber, is the subject of tariffs which has been raised in the Senate in a number of ways in recent times. I will refer to tariffs only briefly. Nevertheless, it is a subject of quite some active debate. I think it is relevant in this context because the subsidies to States and to individuals within States, in the form of tariffs, are not factors which are taken into account in assessing the relative economic positions of States, in particular Queensland.
—And give State governments no benefit whatsoever.

—The fact that they give State governments no benefit whatsoever is a minor interjection but a major question raised by Senator Missen. I refer Senator Missen to the Senate Hansard of 9 June 1981 in which I detailed figures showing the benefit for Victoria of tariffs.
—I have it by my bedside every night.

—I should be cheered but in fact I am dejected because, whilst the honourable senator may have it by his bedside every night, he does not read it every night. If he did he would know that in pure dollar terms industry in Victoria is subsidised through tariff protection to the extent of over $750m annually. The Bill we are debating tonight about Queensland concerns a grant of only $58.5m and that is for two separate amounts of assistance. Looked at in another way, Victoria receives tariff assistance estimated in 1977-78 at $430 a head, compared with the Australian average of $289 a head, Queensland, receives only $123 a head. Again, Victoria has 27 per cent of the population but receives 41 per cent of total tariff assistance. Queensland has 16 per cent of the population but receives only 7 per cent of total tariff assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I point that out just briefly to show that many Government policies can favour States. Queensland is not favoured in the grant made in this legislation or in any of the other programs to which I have referred. Other States are favoured in certain ways. Other States can argue their case. Nobody would debate the right of Senator Missen or Senator Siddons to put forward Victoria's case in this chamber; in fact, we would welcome their using the Senate, the States House, as a forum. However, I think they have to realise that when they do that they will meet a reply from honourable senators from other States. Senator Missen and Senator Siddons and people in their States ought to recognise that it is States such as Queensland that enable the workers in their States to enjoy the high incomes and high standard of living that they do enjoy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good State to die in.

—Melbournians and Victorians generally are proving that in their tens of thousands. We used to call them immigrants; these days we call them refugees. Of course, usually refugees flee to escape dying; Victorians come to Queensland in order to die in comfort.
—There would not be a better place to die in.

—It is a good place to die in the sun. I finish on a general point on the subject of tariffs. In a certain sense this country is living in a fool's paradise with tariffs. It would suit Queensland if tariffs were lifted, not only because certain goods would be cheaper, but also because Queensland industries could employ more people. We would then have that broader tax base that Victoria so earnestly seeks in its submissions to government and we would be given special consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The point ought to be made that Queensland is not being given special consideration in this grants legislation, as the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, pointed out in her second reading speech. She pointed out that the total amount of $58.5m consists of a completion payment for 1979-80 and an advance payment of $25m in respect of 1980-81 and that Queensland requested an advance grant only towards the end of 1980-81 after the Commonwealth Grants Commission's methodology for its review on tax sharing relativities and the processes surrounding the review became known. The completion payment in respect of 1980-81 will be assessed by the Commission in 1982-83. I do not wish to be unduly charitable to my colleagues on both sides of the chamber from that very worthy State of Victoria. I know that they came into the chamber because they thought they might learn something. I hope my speech has assisted them a little further in their understanding of what this country needs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — (Victoria-Minister for Finance) (8.13)-I thank the Senate for the debate on the Queensland Grant (Special Assistance) Bill 1981, which followed the recommendation made in the forty-eighth report of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

It is surely something of an irony that the contents of this Bill were originally drafted by the Fraser Government. Before the last election the Government, in consultation with employers and unions, agreed on a program according to which the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act would be amended to more easily facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions where there was a community of interest. That was a course of action which had been worked out over some years. It was acceptable to trade unions. It was acceptable to employers. It was accepted widely in the community as one of the very few constructive proposals by this Government, in the industrial relations area.
Accordingly it became part of the Fraser Government's bold new program for re-election in 1980. This is what Mr Street said in the House of Representatives on 18 September last year:
If elected the Government would move to facilitate the amalgamation of trade unions.
Mr Street went on to say:

The new amalgamation provisions are yet another demonstration of how the Government is meeting its responsibility to provide an industrial relations framework which takes account of the views of the parties and meets their needs, while paying due regard to the public interest.
The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in his policy speech for that election last year, said this:
The Government proposes to . . . legislate to facilitate the amalgamation of unions where there is a 'community of interest'.

The Bill I am moving is a Bill which seeks mainly to give effect to a report of the National Labour Consultative Council. The National Labour Consultative Council is a creature of the Fraser Government. That Government created it. Over a year ago the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Street, speaking of the National Labour Consultative Council and its work on union amalgamations said:
This achievement shows that government, employers, unions can work together and produce tangible results for the benefit of each other and the community.

I began by commenting on the irony of a situation where it was left to the Opposition to introduce legislation into this Parliament which the Government has promised. There is an irony also in the fact that the Government has, in the past year, done many things which it either did not mention, or specifically promised not to do. The Government has, for example, amended the Broadcasting and Television Act to accommodate large corporate interests. It has sought to introduce fees for education. It has dramatically increased indirect taxes. The Government did all those things without any promises before an election. Here it has a commitment, a promise, but we get no action.

That irony is compounded by the fact that just six years ago the Liberal-National Country Party Opposition blocked legislation to facilitate union amalgamation-legislation prepared by the then Labor Government. Only five years after that it had the hide to tell the electorate about its 'constructive' approach to trade union amalgamation. It has long been recognised that Australia has too many trade unions. As a result of the sheer number of trade unions and as a result of the sometimes uneasy demarcations between their responsibilities, a number of unfortunate consequences have flowed. Many industrial disputes arise between rival unions about demarcation issues. Rational approaches to wage fixation are often frustrated or made more difficult by union demarcation disputes and the number of unions. In December 1976 there were 282 trade unions in Australia. The nine largest unions accounted for 39 per cent of total union membership and 51 unions accounted for 87 per cent of the membership.

A reduction in the number of unions through amalgamations and the reorganisation of unions on an industrial basis will have advantages for union members and for the community in general including, in many cases, employers. These advantages will include the following: Firstly, the greater resources of the amalgamated union will allow the provision of a wider and an improved range of services to the members as well as more effective representation in the conciliation and arbitration system. Secondly, fewer unions will mean easier lines of communications between employers and employees. Instead of having to negotiate with several bodies representing employees, employers will only have to deal with one body. This may lead to better relations and greater understanding between employers and unions. Thirdly, employers and the community will benefit from union amalgamations as a reduction in the number of unions will mean fewer demarcation disputes.

At present, Part VIIIA of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides a code dealing with amalgamation of registered organisations. When two or more organisations propose to amalgamate, they must submit a detailed scheme to the Industrial Registrar setting out the particulars of the proposed amalgamation. This scheme is catered for by certain sections of the Act and by regulations made under it. The Registrar examines the scheme and, upon being satisfied that it is in conformity with the Act and the regulations and that any valid ground of objection to the amalgamation has been removed, approves the submission of the scheme of amalgamation to a ballot of the members of each of the organisations involved. Unless an exemption from the ballot requirement has been granted, the amalgamation may proceed only if it has been approved at the ballots. The amalgamation is not taken to have been approved unless, in each ballot, firstly, ballot papers are returned, on or before the closing date, by at least one half of the members on the roll of voters and, secondly, more than one half of the members who record formal votes vote in favour of the amalgamation.

Those provisions have created a number of serious practical difficulties. The main difficulties arise out of the requirement in section 158N that at least one half of the eligible members must vote in an amalgamation ballot before the proposed amalgamation will be taken to have been approved. This is an unreasonable requirement for two reasons. Firstly, it encourages the opponents of a proposed amalgamation not to vote in the amalgamation ballot, as not voting may be a more effective way of blocking the amalgamation than in fact voting against it. In this way the desire of the majority of union members who have formed a view on the issue of amalgamation may be frustrated by a well-organised minority, something about which I understood this Government to be very concerned.

The second objection to the section 158N requirement is that it calls for a higher return rate of ballot papers in amalgamation ballots than is achieved in many ordinary union elections. For example, in 42 per cent of the elections conducted by the Industrial Registrar or the Electoral Office under section 170, less than one half of the members entitled to vote did so. In recent years the return rate has declined. In other words, section 158N requires a higher return rate in amalgamation ballots than is achieved in more than 40 per cent of ordinary union elections.

If unions are required to obtain at least a 50 per cent return in amalgamation ballots, they must conduct an expensive and time-consuming campaign, not aimed at how a member votes but merely to get a vote returned. Many unions simply do not have the financial and physical resources to risk on such a venture. Obviously that is a particularly bad problem for unions with a high turnover of members. Where members leave employment and consequently lose interest in the affairs of the union, they are very unlikely to vote in an amalgamation ballot, although they will be counted for the purposes of the 50 per cent return of ballot papers threshold requirement of section 158N.

In addition to the above problems, the present legislation fails to deal adequately with the situation where more than two unions propose to amalgamate. Where a scheme of amalgamation between, say, three unions is submitted to ballots of the members of those unions, the whole scheme will fail should any one of the unions fail to secure the required membership 'approval'; for example, if the requirements of section 158N are not met. The effect is to frustrate the efforts of the unions which have obtained the necessary membership support for amalgamation, and to require them once again to go through the long, expensive and complicated process laid down by the Act in order to bring about an amalgamation. Further, the present position of the law discourages and delays attempts to form industry based unions by adding another pitfall in the procedure which must be followed to effect an amalgamation between more than two unions.

The present Bill seeks to give effect to the National Labour Consultative Council recommendations in the following ways. Firstly, clause 7 provides for a proposed new section 158FA under which the Full Bench would declare a proposed scheme of amalgamation to be in the public interest. That is the first requirement. It shall do so if substantial numbers of members of one union are eligible for membership of another, or they are engaged in similar work and/or bound by the same awards. Secondly, when such a declaration of public interest is made a proposed new section 158N will apply. Thirdly, section 158K of the principal Act is amended by clause 11 of the Bill to provide that the roll of voters for an amalgamation ballot would be those persons who were eligible to vote in accordance with the rules of the union as at one month before the opening date of the ballot.

The old sub-sections 158 (4) and (5) which have caused considerable problems in the past are repealed. Clauses 11 and 14 add proposed new sub-section 158K (1A) and section 158PA. Those sections will help facilitate arrangements in the case of proposed amalgamations of more than two unions. The amended act will provide that where three or more unions propose to amalgamate, members would be able to vote on alternative forms of amalgamation, and so avoid the need, where the members of one union fail to approve the amalgamation, for the entire amalgamation process to be gone through again by the remaining unions. In addition, clause 11, paragraphs (G), (H) and (J), changes the present requirement concerning exemption from amalgamation ballots.

Under the existing arrangements as outlined in the sections referred to, if a small union seeks to amalgamate with a union which is approximately 20 or more times larger than itself, the Registrar may permit an amalgamation upon a successful ballot being held in the small union-that is, the Registrar may exempt the larger union from the requirements of a ballot. That provision is a legislative recognition of the need to encourage small unions to amalgamate. It has been necessary to invoke it in every successful amalgamation since the present regime on amalgamations was established.

The Government has seen fit to add a further requirement that the smaller union have less than 5,000 members. It did not take that proposal to the National Labour Consultative Council. So much for the attitude of this Government to consultation. Nevertheless, the Opposition has included the provision of the Bill as drafted by the Government because it wishes the Government to pass its own Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are being very magnanimous, senator, I think.

—Yes, I thank Senator Mulvihill. I could not agree with him more. As I have said, the Opposition has included the provision because it wishes the Government to pass its own Bill. We include it in the Bill with some reservations, in a spirit of compromise. Obviously, if the Opposition had drafted the Bill from the start, it would have been somewhat different. However, I have introduced the Bill, and the Opposition supports it, because we believe that the changes proposed in the Bill will create conditions which can genuinely improve industrial relations in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The advantages of fewer unions and industry based unions are legion. I have had occasion to mention them on previous occasions in the Senate. Not only are demarcation disputes greatly reduced but the climate is created for much more rational wage fixation negotiations. The result is fewer strikes, and often higher wages and greater profits. The results which have been achieved with the industrial unionism of Western European countries are a spectacular example to the failings of our own system as it exists at present. I seek leave to have a table incorporated in Hansard which sets out days lost due to industrial disputes in various countries.
Leave granted.
