TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Working from that table we can get the following result: If we average the days lost per thousand employees in Australia, the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom-countries with craft-based unionism-we find that in 1979 there were 750 man days lost per 1,000 employees. In the same year, the average number of days lost per 1,000 employees in West Germany, Austria, Denmark, the Netherlands, Norway and Sweden was 30. Those countries all have much larger and many fewer unions than Australia. They have 4 per cent of the industrial disputation rate of countries with industrial structures like Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government opposes or equivocates on this Bill, it will not only be guilty of yet another breach of its election commitments. It will not only disappoint unions and employer groups in Australia, both of whom have expended a great deal of effort over this legislation. In abandoning its only constructive, thoughtful and conciliatory measure in industrial relations in six years of government, this Government will serve notice on the electorate that it has abandoned the field of industrial relations to the same barren methods of confrontation which it has pursued in the past.
Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the resumption of the debate be made an order of the day for a later hour this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make mention of the fact that it is not a usual procedure for Bills of such a substantive nature to be discussed and to go through all of the stages of debate in the one day. It is normal for Bills to be adjourned to the next day of sitting so that the Senate and, indeed more particularly the public, can give consideration to the proposals that are before them. In most cases matters of this character are adjourned for a number of days so that the persons or organisations that are interested in the particular piece of legislation can make their comments.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not making the point simply on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. I make the point as a matter of principle on any Bill. I do not care whether it is this Bill or any other Bill. However, I have been told by the Government Whip that there are occasions after a second reading speech when a motion is moved for the debate to be adjourned until a later hour of the day. I confess that that must have gone through to the keeper; I have not heard it. But I accept what the Government Whip says. However, as a matter of principle I suggest that the Senate recognise that it is in the best interests of public consideration that when any measure comes before the Parliament it should lay on the table at least for one day so that organisations and interested individuals can consider it and make representations to various honourable senators. I support the proposition that debate be adjourned to a later hour of this day only on the basis that it is expected that it certainly will not come on tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Button introduced his very important piece of legislation on union amalgamations, the Senate discussed and agreed to pass the Queensland State grant legislation which was the product of consideration by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Commonwealth Grants Commission Amendment Bill seeks to amend the composition of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. It was interesting to hear Government senators in that earlier debate refer to the Senate as a States House. That is an admission that we have not had from Government senators for a considerable period. I make it clear that the Opposition does not oppose this Bill. However, we do have a number of comments to make on the Commonwealth Grants Commission Amendment Bill relating to the tasks of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. This Bill allows the Commission to carry out those tasks. I will refer also to the delay that the Government has caused to the ability of the Commission to perform these tasks. The presentation of this legislation has been an on and off affair, like the working of an automatic refrigerator. In fact this on-off situation existed this evening. After almost a month, this legislation, which is designed to provide processes by which the Commmonwealth Grants Commission can carry out the tasks allocated to it by the Government, has finally reached a stage where it will be given consideration by the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, the Bill amends the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act which was passed in 1973 by the Government of which you were a member. The Commission is an important process in our system by which the problems associated with Commonwealth-State relations are properly arbitrated and properly determined. One thought that continually comes to my mind about the Commonwealth Grants Commission, particularly concerning the years 1975 to 1980, is that we were constantly regaled in this chamber by Senator Carrick about the virtues of the new co-operative federalism which was to be the answer to all of the problems of the Commonwealth-State financial relationship. I think I would be correct in saying that since the last election in 1980, more than a year ago, I have not heard Senator Carrick mention the words 'co-operative federalism' in this place. This shows how much it has faded from the consciousness of the Government. That is indicated by the way in which this legislation has been on the Notice Paper for the past month. It is an indication that the States are put in a mendicant position, from which they have to rely on the Commonwealth and its good graces to get adequate funds to carry out their proper functions. It is very pleasing to hear Government senators talk about the Senate being a States House, a point that this side of the Parliament has constantly attempted to make over the last 10 or 12 years.

The Bill seeks to amend the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act to increase the number of members on the Commission. To that extent, it is not a Bill that has any great significance, except that it provides the machinery base for the Commission to work more effectively. It removes the upper limit on the number of commissioners so that the Commission can now be comprised of sufficient members to enable it to conduct an inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances and review its report on State tax sharing entitlements for use by the Premiers Conference when it meets in June 1982. I remind the Senate that, when we talked about Australian Capital Territory finances in the early part of this session-we are now just one day from the end of the session-we criticised the Government's failure to take the essential steps to have the Australian Capital Territory finances properly examined by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. That just shows that we could go through a whole session before the Government acts. It is such an inept and lazy Government that I got to the stage, as the shadow Minister in charge of this legislation, of wondering whether we would deal with the legislation at all. In the second reading speech on this Bill we were told very little about the background to which I referred. As members of this Senate would be aware, the States have varying capacities to raise revenue and the cost of providing services also varies widely between the States. We had some indication of that in the debate on the previous legislation this evening.

Therefore the Commonwealth Grants Commission has an important function because the Commonwealth allocates its tax sharing payments to the States in a way which takes account of these variables I have referred to which are important from the point of view of the allocation of funds. The Grants Commission in the past has been given the task of determining these State tax sharing relativities. In 1978 the Commission was asked to determine whether any change was desirable in the factors which are used to adjust State population as the first step in the process of calculating the percentage distribution among the States of the total tax sharing entitlements. The Grants Commission, after careful analysis, submitted a comprehensive report to the Government on 9 June this year. That is almost five months ago, just before that important 1981 Premiers Conference.

The effect of the changes in the tax sharing relativities proposed by the Commission would have been to increase the proportion received by New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland and to reduce the proportions received by the smaller States-South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania. I surely do not have to remind the Senate of the hullabaloo that occurred and the concern that was expressed by the governments of those smaller States. The task, of course, was such that the Government reacted to the criticisms by the State Premiers and sent the issue back to the Commission. In other words now what the Commission will be required to do as one of its tasks, as a result of the carrying of this amendment, is to review its own report which, I suppose, is just another way of saying that we pass the buck back to the Commission. By neglecting to describe the background of the Bill the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) also managed to neglect to refer to the fact that the Bill is long overdue. The Treasurer, Mr Howard, for example, announced on 21 June-that is quite some time ago considering the number of sitting days we have had in this spring session-that the Grants Commission would be asked to produce a further report on its assessment of State relativities and to present this report early in 1982. However, the matter has only now been referred to the Grant's Commission, four months after the Treasurer's announcement.

This totally unexplained delay in making the references will now make it impossible for the Commission, having regard to this time lag I referred to, to report early in 1982, unless it will be working over the Christmas period. That was an agreement reached between the Commonwealth and the States. The Commission is now being asked, as a result of this slowness by the Government, to report by 31 May 1982. I believe, and the Opposition believes, that the Commission will need every day of the next seven months adequately to prepare its report by that date. The States and the Commonwealth will have too little time after receiving the report to evaluate it carefully before it has to be discussed at the June 1982 Premiers Conference. One can imagine the state of disarray and confrontation. The States and the Commonwealth will be locked in conflict. As a result, conflict between the States and the Commonwealth is as inevitable as night following day.

On the matter of the review of the Australian Capital Territory finances, there has been the delay I referred to. On many matters that have been before us-the Australian Capital Territory stamp duty legislation and the like-the Opposition has sought to take the matter of finances in the Australian Capital Territory to the Grants Commission. Yet every time we have raised the matter in the Parliament the Government has said nothing and done nothing; that is until now, when we have this legislation before us. There is no question-no one denies it-that the Australian Capital Territory's finances are in a state of disarray and do require the assistance of a Commonwealth Grants Commission inquiry. Residents of the Australian Capital Territory have no influence whatsoever over these chaotic finances. They have no system of self-government like that of residents of all the Australian States. So all that Australian Capital Territory residents can do is to pay the same sorts of taxes as those in the States and hope that they will be used effectively and efficiently. There is a need for the Australian Capital Territory to move towards a system of self-government and the findings of the Commission on the finances of the Australian Capital Territory would be very important in this regard. However, the Government keeps hedging around the issues because of the failure of the Australian Capital Territory to resolve this matter itself when it had it on the agenda a year or two ago. I understand that the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, has been referring for some time to the possibility of a Commission inquiry; yet to date no terms of reference have been set up. At least the intention to go ahead with the inquiry has now been made public by the moving of the amendment before us.
The matter of self-government is even further off than it should be. In October last the Minister had this to say at a seminar on self-government for the Australian Capital Territory:

I have said it before, but let me say it again today. Some form of 'self-government' will be developed for the Territory. I cannot say when, nor should I speculate upon the degree and type of devolution...
I want the financial issues clearly understood before any decisions are taken. This is the reason I have placed such importance on the Grants Commission Inquiry into Territorial Finances.

This dilly-dallying, this delay, has in fact impeded the development of devolution of power in the Australian Capital Territory. I am sure that that sort of explanation is just not good enough for the residents of the Australian Capital Territory.

Why has the Government dilly-dallied, why has it delayed the passage of this legislation when it knew that it had the support of the Opposition, when it knew that it had only to bring the Bill forward and allow a very short debate on the matter? The Commission could have been organised in such a way as to have been carrying out its function in respect of the Australian Capital Territory. The people in the Australian Capital Territory believe they have been disadvantaged. Whether that is so, of course, has to be established. The reconstituted Commonwealth Grants Commission will have that responsibility to do so given to it once this Bill receives the assent of the Senate this evening. So all the Opposition can say is that it regrets the delay in the Government bringing this Bill to the Senate. Nevertheless, we will continue to give it our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Gietzelt for his remarks on behalf of the Opposition. As he has said, it is not the intention to oppose this Bill. I now simply commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Haines:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a proposal brought foward by Senator Haines to amend the Banking Act 1959. On behalf of the Government I say that whilst the objectives of this Bill are most worthy in themselves, the Bill would be ineffective in achieving those objectives. Indeed, the amendment proposed to the Banking Act 1959 would have the effect of disrupting the provision of finance for housing through the banking system and harming those it seeks to help. The amendment would be intended essentially to contain increases in all bank interest rates to 0.5 per cent in any six-monthly period unless both Houses of Parliament otherwise decided and, for new first home buyers, to rule out any increase in the rate of interest for at least five years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before the Senate seeks to impose in the housing area additional rigid, arbitrary interest rate controls which would exacerbate those problems which were recently identified by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I am sure that that is not the intention of the proponents of the Bill but it would be its inevitable effect. No government, including this Government, welcomes increases in interest rates, particularly where they affect people buying their own homes or where the operations of small business are affected. However, because there are certain market realities that have to be faced, governments that pretend that they can achieve the utopia of unrealistically low interest rates through pursuing easy options only cause much greater economic difficulty for the people they are elected to serve and in the long run only stimulate much higher inflation and much higher interest rates. Nothing that I have said implies that there is not at times some balance to be sought between maintaining a reasonably flexible and efficient financial system and the particular needs and problems of certain participants in the system. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) highlighted the need for such a balance in his statement when he tabled the Campbell report. My remarks have been directed towards a Bill which I believe would dramatically upset the balance to the cost of all concerned.

I should make some reference to the assertion in Senator Haines's second reading speech that banks would be to some extent compensated for the cost of the lending interest rate controls by a proposed amendment to the Income tax Assessment Act. Whilst that amendment, if passed, would no doubt attract some funds to banks and buildings societies, it would also create a number of important problems. Some of these would be that the effective benefits of the scheme would relate, inequitably, to savers' marginal rates of tax with higher income earners receiving the greater benefits. There is no guarantee that lenders would apply all or most of any resulting increases in deposits to low or pegged interest housing lending if they had more attractive alternative investments. Yet another incentive for income splitting would be opened up. It would distort flows of funds in financial markets and resource allocation to the detriment of overall economic efficiency.

The Government does not see this Bill as being consistent with its economic strategy, with fundamental economic logic or with recent practical experience. Indeed, it would very likely prove counterproductive for those it purports to assist. The Government therefore cannot support this Bill that has been brought forward by Senator Haines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill which was introduced by Senator Haines some three months ago seeks to transfer the regulation making power, which includes the power over certain interest rates which is currently contained in section 50 of the Banking Act, from the Reserve Bank of Australia to the Parliament or, in the jargon which is used in these cases, to the Governor-General. It seeks to add to existing section 50 of section 50A which requires that regulations be made to ensure, firstly, that no increase in interest rates for housing loans for first home buyers be allowed for the first five years of the duration of a loan and, secondly, that no increase in any interest rate for a housing loan may be greater than one-half of one per cent in any six month period without the permission of Parliament. The area of housing loan finance, to which this Bill would have application, involves much less than half of the total housing finance market. I will say more about that later.

SPEECH.PARA: I want firstly to say something about the technical aspects of the Bill. Sub-clause (2) of clause 4 of the Bill states that if regulations are not made within 90 days section 50 and the proposed new section 50A of the Banking Act is repealed. The legal advice which I have been given regarding the sub-clause states:

This sub-clause tends to take away the obligatory tones of sub-clause 4 (1), by saying that if the Governor-General does not make regulations then section 50 is repealed anyway. By inserting this provision, the Bill has the effect of also repealing its own amendment to section 50 in clause 5, which is the clause that gives the Governor-General his regulation-making power.
Returning to the Bill itself, I refer to sub-clause 4 (1), which states:

Within 90 days after the commencement of this Act, regulations shall be made under section 50 of the Principal Act as amended by this Act in accordance with section 50A of the Principal Act as amended by this Act.

As a layman, I would have thought that if a clause said that regulations shall be made within 90 days, it would be mandatory that such regulations be made. However, a legal opinion has been provided to me and, as a layman, I do not feel inclined to take issue with lawyers on technical matters such as that. If the opinion which has been given is correct and if this Bill becomes law, a government could remove from the Banking Act the power to regulate interest rates at all simply by doing nothing for more than 90 days. In other words, it would provide a mechanism for enacting by inertia the recommendations of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. Certainly the Australian Labor Party does not want to see that happen.

Apart from the legal problem which has been identified for me, the whole issue of interest rate regulation is now very uncertain. It is in a state of flux following the presentation of the Campbell report last week. To the extent that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony), in characteristic Country Party style, has been running around Australia pre-empting Cabinet decisions-as the Country Party normally does-in regard to what action the Government will take on the recommendations of the Campbell Committee, and given that we have a closet Country Party Prime Minister, certain decisions have already been made prior to Cabinet even having considered the Campbell report. But not all decisions have yet been pre-empted by Mr Anthony and it would be inappropriate to make one small adjustment to the finance policy area when massive upheavals might well be in the pipeline if the Government is to adopt any number of the more substantial recommendations of the Campbell Committee.

Another point is that according to page 633 of the Campbell report the area of housing finance to which this Bill applies, which includes savings banks and trading banks-I add that the State Savings Bank would be excluded-accounts for only 46.8 per cent of total lending for housing finance. That comes from a table in the Campbell report. It could be argued that the figure is considerably less than that because the Campbell Committee estimated that $5 billion-I must say I was astounded by that figure-is at present on loan from solicitors' trust accounts for housing finance. When account is taken of that figure the proportion of the total housing finance market to which this Bill would have application is less than 40 per cent. That obviously raises the question of whether it is sensible to bind less than 40 per cent of the total housing finance market in the way proposed by this Bill if more than 60 per cent is not regulated at all. It could cripple the 40 per cent which is controlled.

There is a particular problem in the provision in the Bill which seeks to fix for a five-year term the interest rate on loans to first home buyers. If a substantial part of any financial institution's total business were to be tied up in five-year fixed interest loans it would be essential for those institutions to match their lending and borrowing requirements, with the requirement that borrowing also at a fixed interest rate, otherwise the institution would be running a grave risk of becoming insolvent. Perhaps I should expand just briefly on that proposition. Let us suppose that an institution had 50 per cent of its total lending funds on loan to first home buyers within the first five years of the loan and therefore at a fixed interest rate. Let us then suppose that the general market interest rates lifted by 3 per cent or 4 per cent, as they have done in the last 18 months or two years. Presumably, if the deposits with that institution were held on short term or even at call, as they normally are, there would be a flight of depositors' funds out of that institution, which would then lead very quickly to insolvency by the institution. It would not be able to pay out the depositors' funds because its finances would be tied up. It could not redeem the loans that it had made and it could not increase to a significant extent the interest rate on depositors' funds because it could not increase the interest rate on the money that it had out on loan.

As we see it the Bill, at best, is a palliative and not an answer to the present record interest rates which, as Senator Haines correctly pointed out, are both crippling a substantial proportion of existing home buyers and preventing a very large proportion of potential home buyers from entering the market at all. This, Bill however, does not answer that problem. Even if all the difficulties to which I have drawn attention could be overcome, at best it provides a palliative for something that gnaws away at the fringes. The only answer to the problem is, of course, the removal of the Fraser Government, which has presided over this unprecedented increase in interest rates to record levels.

I suppose that all of the points I have raised could be seen to suggest that the Bill should be rejected at the second reading stage, but the Opposition sees some merit in some of the propositions which are canvassed-with or without a Fraser Government. We have some interest in further exploring the proposal that interest rates be fixed to the borrower, although recognising that if a loan represents a significant proportion of a building society's total business, the deposits held by that society will have to be matched both in interest rates and in the term of deposit with the society's lending policies. I understand that some building societies are interested in experimenting in some innovation in this area. We of the Opposition believe that such innovation ought to be encouraged.

In my view, although this matter goes beyond the scope of this Bill, a proposition worthy of serious consideration is that the interest rate charged to a borrower and the interest rate paid to a lender by a financial institution could be fixed at a very much lower level, perhaps as low as around 2 per cent, provided that the outstanding principle or the deposit is indexed each year in accordance with the increase in the consumer price index so that the real rate of interest would be known at the time of the deposit and the real value of the loan would be maintained permanently. The present arrangements with high nominal interest and inflation rates for the repayment of housing loans lead to a situation in which there is de facto an early repayment of loans although the real burden of the repayment is concentrated in the early years of the loan and in the later years of the loan, given the continuing high rates of inflation, the repayments at the end of 30 years become almost negligible. Obviously that sort of repayment condition, although not intended and not deliberately planned by anyone, leads to a situation whereby it is extremely difficult for a very large number of borrowers to meet their commitments in the early years of a loan. For those reasons I move the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill:
Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'this Bill to be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for inquiry and report on the provisions of the Bill by 31 May 1982.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 August this year I gave notice of my intention to introduce the Banking Amendment Bill 1981. On the following day I introduced the Bill and made my second reading speech. That was some three months ago. In the intervening period the matters which are the subject of this Bill have not been far from the minds of the people in the electorate, the people in the community; nor have they been very far from the political stage. A number of meetings have been held across the country. The last that I recall was held on the first Saturday of this month. That was a fully co-ordinated national meeting of people complaining about constantly rising interest rates. I spoke at a number of those meetings. Australian Labor Party members and senators spoke at a number of those meetings. Liberal Party senators and members also spoke at them. On a number of occasions we shared the stage. The Opposition in this place and Ministers in State Houses, of all political persuasions, have kept up a constant barrage of criticism against the present Federal Government for not taking immediate action to do something about the high interest rates-a situation which is forcing more and more people out of their homes and making it more and more difficult for those who would like to buy or to build a home to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind honourable senators that an interest rate increase of one per cent is, in actual repayment rates to the people concerned, an increase of 8 per cent. In other words, if they have a mortgage which requires a repayment of $300 a month and the interest rate goes up by one per cent, their repayment goes up to $324 a month, which is an increase of 8 per cent-an intolerable increase. All that has happened over the past 16 months to two years, over which time interest rates have risen on at least four occasions, is that the Opposition has been complaining constantly and demanding that something be done by the Government. It has done nothing more concrete than that. It asked questions, it pestered, it raised matters of public importance. It got out on the hustings and raised the issue, but it did not do anything concrete. The action, the movement to do something positive to help people like the young couples living in the Adelaide suburbs of Elizabeth to the north and Hallett Cove to the south, for instance, was left to the Australian Democrats. The machinery for doing something has existed for a number of years under the Banking Act. It would appear not to have been terribly difficult to come up with a simple amendment which would take over from the banking world the power to control interest rates and give it to the members of parliament so that they, at least, could respond to the needs and wishes of the electorate.

I can understand the response of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to this Bill being at considerable variance with the philosophy of the present Government. The Government has made that demonstrably clear. It has never waivered from that and has never tried to hide it. This is in some contrast, however, to the behaviour of the Australian Labor Party, which has supported the contention of the Bill, that is, that something should be done to help the people in need, but it has never attempted to do anything at all positive about it. The fact that this Bill is, according to the list of woes put forward by Senator Walsh, considerably less than perfect is something for which I do not feel inclined to apologise. The Democrats do not have ready access to the Parliamentary Counsel. At this stage I pay tribute to the Senate staff, who have done what I consider to be a first class job in producing the Bill. It may be flawed, but it was something--

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot turn a sow's ear into a silk purse.

—Apparently not, but then apparently neither could the honourable senator with all his brilliant legal experience and brain in the three months that he has had to cogitate on the matter. Any rough edges that were incorporated into this piece of legislation could have been altered by a positive amendment or a series of amendments suggested by either the ALP or, if they had been so inclined, by any rebel Liberal senators. It is no justification for anybody to get up in this place and say that because only part of the problem is being solved we ought not to go ahead with it. If we all waited for perfection, none of us, especially Senator Evans, would ever get anywhere. I suggest to Senator Walsh that it is surely better to come up with some sort of palliative than to destroy the hopes and dreams and future of a lot of people who could have some of their problems solved by that palliative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have absolutely no option, if they want to help the people in Australia who are in need because of high interest rates, in the housing industry in particular, but to acquiesce in the ALP's referral of this Bill to a Senate standing committee. We have no option at all. If we oppose that, presumably the ALP will be sufficiently bloody-minded not to bother to put up any sort of amendment but simply to oppose the legislation lock, stock and barrel, good intentions and all. I suspect, however-it was for this reason that I asked Senator Walsh to add the time element to the amendment-that if the amendment were left open-ended in effect nothing would have been done and the Bill would have been dropped to the bottom of the list of the appropriate standing committee's agenda, never again to see the light of day. It would disappear into obscurity, along with all the young and old home owners in this country who will continue to be put out on the streets because of the situation that exists at the moment. It is cold comfort to them, I am sure, to know that after this Bill has been before the Senate for three months, the Australian Labor Party has opted to put it into the hands of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, which will not report until 31 May next year. It will be some comfort, if something comes of that report, to those people who will be affected after that date. Working on a system which appears to be anathema to the ALP that helping some people is better than helping no people at all, the Australian Democrats are prepared to allow this amendment to go through in order that the whole Bill is not sacrificed in its entirety.
Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill does two things. It finalises the long running dispute between the Government and people in various parts of Australia regarding the imputation for taxable income purposes of the subsidised rent on company provided houses. The second matter which it covers is the provision of income tax at the rate of 32c in the dollar on lump sum settlements granted to employees at the termination of a strike. The latter provision was quite clearly provoked by the settlement to the striking workers at the Loy Yang power station. The Opposition supports it on the grounds that it is absurd to tax wages and not tax lump sum settlements paid in lieu of wages at the conclusion of an industrial dispute. The Australian Labor Party is against all forms of tax evasion whereas the position of other parties on the question is quite clearly prevaricatory.

SPEECH.PARA: We also support what is proposed in the Bill regarding the settlement of tax on subsidised housing which arose from what is commonly referred to as the Utah dispute since it was among the Utah Development Co. workers in central Queensland that the dispute was most intense and prolonged. The provisions provided in this legislation are, in brief, that the value of a company or employer provided house will be assessed for taxation purposes at 10 per cent of market rental less any rent that is being paid. The eligibility criteria are that a taxpayer must live in a remote area which is defined as being 100 kilometres from a town of 130,000 people or 40 kilometres from a town of 12,000 people, using the 1976 Census figures as a base. There is provision that where a taxpayer does not meet either of those criteria he or she may be eligible under certain other criteria which were designed primarily to meet the requirements of certain sugar industry workers on the north Queensland coast.

The Government's approach to tax evasion has, as I said earlier, been highly selective over a number of years. It decided to crack down on taxation of imputed rental for the Utah miners after the $95 a week wage increase settlement of 1978. I have absolutely no doubt that that crackdown was motivated by a vindictive desire by the Government to get even both with the Utah workers concerned and, to a lesser extent, with the company. The dispute dragged on for more than two years. It was marked by a great deal of prevarication by on the one hand, the Government in its inconsistent attitudes towards basic policy issues and, on the other hand, a series of highly misleading statements from various Government Ministers, the most outstanding of which came, predictably enough, from the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser following a visit to Blackwater in late June 1979. He told a deputation of miners that they could 'sleep tight at night'. All the miners were led to believe that there would be no tax. From the reports that came from that meeting, quite clearly, all the Canberra journalists who accompanied the Prime Minister reached the same conclusion. As with so many other prime ministerial promises the miners were to discover, of course, that it was operative only for as long as Mr Fraser remained in Blackwater. The dispute dragged on for more than 12 months, finally reaching a climax with a pre-election backdown just before the 1980 election when the Government forecast the sort of legislation which is now before the Senate.

I do not want to speak for very much longer on this Bill, but I draw attention to the highly selective nature of the Government's attitude to tax avoidance, to the crackdown initiated against the Utah miners in 1978 and to some extent subsequently carried over to miners in the Pilbara, to sugar workers and to some-both State and Commonwealth-public servants in remote areas. I contrast that with the simultaneous actions by the Government to open up tax havens such as the income equalisation deposit tax rort under which a qualified person-and half the Fraser Cabinet qualifies-may borrow $15,000 from the Government for two years, lend $10,000 to the Government for one year and, for that action, receive a bonus of $4,600, half of which is non-taxable. I cite those figures but the proportions will hold whether lower or higher figures are used.

It is almost unbelievable that any government could have written legislation which permits this. I repeat: It is possible to borrow $15,000 from the Government for two years, lend $10,000 to the Government for one year and pick up a $4,600 bonus, half of which is free of tax. That is the rort which was designed and engineered by this Government and which can be exploited by half the Ministers in this Government. They refuse to give any assurances as to whether they are exploiting it. This is a rort preserved last week by the Australian Democrats. This is preserved by the Government with the assistance of the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine who at various times has purported to retain some residual Labor Party principles but who last week voted for a tax rort which enables eligible persons-which includes half the Fraser Cabinet-to borrow $15,000 from the Government for two years, to lend $10,000 for one year and to pick up a cash bonus of $4,600, half of which is free of tax. That is the rort. I am not so surprised that the Australian Democrats decided to support that. I must say I was genuinely disappointed that Senator Harradine, who purports to have some residual Labor principles, decided a week ago to preserve that tax haven.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were not surprised by the Democrats, were you?
—I do not think they understood it but I think Senator Harradine did. The final irony in that episode is that-
—There is a feeling of deja vu about this.

—The Senate will hear a lot more yet. There will be a lot more deja vu. The public will be continually reminded, Senator Mason, that the Democrats are on the side of the tax dodgers-along with Senator Harradine and the Liberal and National Country parties. The final irony in this issue was when a study by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association of New South Wales fell into my hands last week. The study concluded that any measures which made agriculture a tax haven attracted capital from outside agriculture and, to a lesser degree, capital from outside Australia purely to take advantage of the tax haven provisions. The predictable consequence of such a capital inflow is inflation of the price of land and other agricultural inputs. The conclusion reached in this study by the Livestock and Grain Producers Association was that the medium and lower income farmers actually dependent on agriculture for a living were harmed by it. That is not an original conclusion. I have been attempting to educate the agricultural community along those lines for about 10 years. The former Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics explicitly stated this at the Agro 79 conference in Perth more than two and a half years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: What is new, and what is very welcome, is that Australia's largest State based farmer organisation has reached a degree of sophistication whereby it has recognised that fact and, it has reached a degree of moral and/or intellectual honesty whereby it has given primary attention to the interests of the great majority of its members, who are disadvantaged by provisions which make agriculture a tax haven, instead of to the interests of the elite few who actually make a personal gain from it. I commend to the Australian Democrats a study of that paper and a study of the issue. I think that there might be hope for the Democrats in the long term, although they threw away the only weapon we have at the moment. Once they understand the issue, they might change the way they vote.

On the other hand, Senator Harradine, who postures and poses as a man having fundamental Australian Labor Party principles, showed himself last Wednesday night to be on the side of the tax dodgers. On the matter of inconsistent application, and inconsistent attitudes towards tax evasion and tax avoidance, less than six months ago the Government passed amendments for the film industry under which a hidden subsidy varying in magnitude between 90 and 120 per cent of the cost of making a film will be paid by the Treasury to film makers. I see that Senator Harradine has come into the chamber. I suppose he will now attempt to make a personal explanation to try to explain why he did what he did last week. I certainly hope he can make a better job of it than he has so far because so far he has given no explanation of why he voted for the tax dodgers last week instead of maintaining those fundamental Labor Party principles which from time to time he purports to hold.

As revealed in the most recent report of the Commissioner of Taxation, there has been a very large increase in the incidence of tax avoidance in the last 12 months. The Commissioner estimates that almost $1 billion is currently outstanding. In the past the Government has made puny attempts to recover a bit of revenue here and there, such as the attempt to impose tax on the imputed income of Utah coal miners. At the same time, it deliberately opened up tax avoidance schemes, the cost of which to revenue is greater than the cost to revenue of the Utah and Pilbara miners and sugar workers put together. Most importantly of all, quantitatively of course, it refuses to do the one thing which effectively will stop the social evil of tax avoidance: It refuses to legislate retrospectively to close off blatant tax avoidance schemes. The Opposition will support this Bill. We hope that, as a result of this legislation being passed, the disruptive, bitter and extremely costly disputes which plagued Queensland and to a lesser extent some other areas in a bit of 1978 and throughout 1979 and 1980, will not recur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the loans problem.

—I was about to do that because it impinges on taxation matters. I seek leave to table a copy of the letter dated 19 November written by Mr Stone, Secretary to the Treasury, to Mr Henderson, Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 2) and hope that it has a speedy passage. It is a matter in which I have had a considerable interest. This Bill was brought before the Parliament after an undertaking had been given two Budgets ago, from memory, that an inquiry would be established and that subsequent to that inquiry measures would be introduced into the Parliament. I was instrumental in urging that on the Government-not that that was the determining factor-because I realise that this question of housing is of great importance to both the workers and the entrepreneurs in mining areas. I urge a speedy passage for this Bill, which has the support, as I understand it, of all sections of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply take the opportunity of responding to what Senator Walsh said. He was referring to his attempt to disallow the regulations relating to income equalisation deposits. I make no bones about what influenced me to oppose his motion. I was influenced more by the Australian Labor Party shadow Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, than I was by Senator Walsh. If Senator Walsh accuses me, the Australian Democrats and presumably the Government of supporting tax dodgers by opposing his motion for disallowance, then he is making the accusation against the Labor Party's spokesman for primary industry, John Kerin, who in a media release on 22 October had this to say:

The decision by the Government to raise the interest rates on income equalisation deposits from 7 per cent to 9.5 per cent was predictable given the rise in market interest rates and will be welcomed by primary producers and their organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax dodgers' friend.

—Senator Walsh persists in accusing everyone who has opposed him on this issue of supporting tax dodgers. He is accusing the ALP spokesman, the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin, a well respected person, of supporting tax dodgers. I make no bones about the fact that I opposed Senator Walsh's proposition to disallow the regulations. I did so in good company-in the company of none other than the ALP shadow Minister for Primary Industry, John Kerin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, firstly, to discuss generally some of the points raised by Senator Walsh in regard to this Government's approach to tax avoidance. I think it has been demonstrated quite clearly, particularly since 1978, that this Government has adopted a very firm stand against tax avoidance in various areas. It is perhaps this Government's approach which has done a great deal to protect the revenue from the great rip-off schemes, the paper schemes, which have been devised by lawyers and accountants over the last few years, in order to ensure that the maximum revenue has gone into the hands of those who need it most. Perhaps we can just examine the approach, firstly, of this Government to tax avoidance and so get a clearer impression of the way in which this has been handled.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time, particularly since the advent of Senator Evans in this place, the Opposition has been advocating a different kind of approach to tax avoidance in that it has been advocating retrospective legislation. This is to apply to all forms of law as soon as those things become apparent. The Government's approach, on the other hand, has been to try to stem the tide of those schemes, which have been established over time within the commercial community, by legislating specifically in regard to them. It is certainly clear so far that that has been a very successful approach. I think even Senator Evans, who is in the chamber for a change, would recognise that matter. Senator Evans seeks to make a great deal of specific points but ignores the broader issues that are most important in the discussion of tax avoidance.

Of course, the most significant point of all is the fact that the Labor Party Opposition proposes retrospective legislation in respect of tax schemes and at all levels. This means that there is a non-discriminatory approach to matters of this kind. Clearly, the Opposition would have no regard to the issues of individual enterprise, to the problems of different kinds of businesses and to the difficulties which individual firms would face in this kind of legislative broad brush. This Government has taken a totally different approach to that advocated in such a normal way by the Labor Party-according to its socialist tenet-and by Senator Evans. Nonetheless, the Opposition's method has not been tested as has the Government's.

Clearly, significant changes have occurred in the industry with regard to tax avoidance and there has been a very considerable change in attitude in the business community to the exploitation of various paper schemes. That is very clear from the evidence and from the fact that if one mixes in the community today one can see that there is certainly a different atmosphere. One has to think back only 10 years or so to the days when tax avoidance was, indeed, practised from time to time but in such a way-things were designed in a very commercial way and this was and is condoned by the law-as to take advantage of particular situations rather than to devise artificial schemes in order to attract the least possible attention from the Commissioner of Taxation. It is that difference which has crept into the practice of tax avoidance over the last few years and which has significantly changed the atmosphere in the taxation avoidance industry in recent times.

As a result, this Government's attitude has been to approach the issues as they become apparent from the point of view of legislating specifically in respect of particular schemes. That necessarily has not been an easy task. Schemes today are certainly very complex and have been devised in such ways that it is extremely difficult to bind up all the corners which people might seek to exploit from time to time. Nevertheless, on the whole this has been a very successful exercise. Indeed, we might observe that starting in 1978, as I recall, the Government made one very significant decision, which it implemented via legislation, to tighten up those schemes that exploited the decision in Curran's case which was handed down by the High Court of Australia in 1974. It might be advisable to recall that at the time the Labor Government was in power. The decision opened a very wide hole for tax avoiders and did much to foster the tax avoidance industry. Of course, the Labor Government, which served until 1975, took no action to shut off that loop hole. I understand that an intention to do so was announced by the then Treasurer, the Honourable Frank Crean. He indicated that he would bring in legislation on the matter but, as with other matters that were of concern to the then Labor Government, its priority suffered amid the plethora of legislation brought down in 1975.

However, in 1978 the present Government did enact legislation on the matter and made clear its future intentions with regard to schemes which were associated with the Curran decision and which sprang from it. Indeed, the Government subsequently legislated accordingly. Additionally, further Bills have covered other areas of tax avoidance, specifically in relation to particular schemes found to be operating within the community.

Clearly, there is a major philosophical difference between the Government and the Opposition with regard to tax avoidance. On the one hand, the Government is prepared to do something about particular schemes as soon as they are brought to its attention, and ensure that they are brought under control. The Opposition wants retrospective legislation so as to ensure that it will cover a multitude of sins. In fact it wants to take a sledge hammer to crack a nut. By such action, it will merely ensure that the net is spread so widely as to ensnare, on the fringes, people who conduct legitimate activity in the business community. I highlight that point particularly by referring to the legislation that was passed in the Senate some six months ago in relation to Part IVB of the Income Tax Assesssment Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part IVA, you dolt.

—I thank Senator Evans. I knew I could rely on him to correct me on any detail if necessary. Part IVA is this Government's new provision relating to the general tax avoidance area and in particular to section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act as it applied at that time. This Government's legislation demonstrates maximum concern for those people in the community who in fact conduct legitimate business enterprises. The various tests set out in the legislation ensure that such people will not be drawn into the net of the tax collector by activities which are legitimate but which, by virtue of the application of some section of the law, might be interpreted as being illegitimate. As a result, I believe we have established the best possible circumstance for the continuance of the anti-avoidance thrust of the Government's policy. At the same time, we have ensured that maximum freedom is given to those who legitimately arrange their affairs in terms of the present law, who organise their business arrangements in a proper commercial way, so that they do not inadvertently become liable to pay more than they should

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to one or two other matters, we should perhaps direct our attention more particularly to the provisions of the Bill. We have been discussing the question of tax avoidance somewhat generally. We might, perhaps, address our minds to that very significant event that occurred last year in relation to the Blackwater coal fields and the determination of this Government's policy in relation to remote area housing. It is quite clear that this Government encourages development in remote areas. We know, of course, that there are significant resource developments in parts of Australia which need people to work there and to be attracted to those places in order to ensure that they get off the ground and create wealth for Australia and those Australians who work there. It is clear that by virtue of this Government's general encouragement of resource development and of industry generally that is our policy.

It follows that our taxation policy in relation to remote area housing should confirm that viewpoint. This is, of course, explicitly spelled out in this legislation whereby the amount of imputed rental which is attributed to the residents in houses that are available or are made available by employers in remote districts is, in fact, discounted by some 90 per cent of its value in order to ensure that there will be a minimum taxation effect on those workers who live and work there. That taxation, as we all know, does have its disincentive effects, irrespective of the point at issue as to whether or not taxation falls equitably or otherwise. But clearly it is important that the community, as a whole, enjoys the benefits of the resource development of Australia. Consequently, by encouraging resource development in the way that this taxation law is framed we will ensure that the maximum benefits are spread amongst the whole community.

In relation to the manner in which this decision was made some time during 1979 and in later times, we have seen much discussion on this matter on various occasions throughout the last 12 months or so. But clearly we do, in fact, encourage by this very positive move, our whole pragmatic and practical approach to this kind of resource development throughout Australia. This Government wants to see it go forward. We will be encouraging this kind of approach, not only in legislation but also by practical government effort, to ensure that this kind of thing does occur in the future. I think we have probably dealt very significantly with the major points which were raised by Senator Walsh during his speech concerning tax avoidance. I am sure that we have demolished his arguments quite well. The Government wishes the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981 is something of an Aladdin's Cave. Behind its bland and utterly uninteresting looking titles lies a wondrous miscellany of mysterious and interesting things. In the Bill 17 major Acts are amended in major ways, Acts ranging from the Commonwealth Electoral Act to the Bankruptcy Act, the Health Acts Amendment Act, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, the Trade Union Training Authority Act, the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act and a dozen others as well. Something like half a dozen significant or substantive changes are being made to each of them. It is not just a matter of a comma being added here or a drafting error being corrected there or an obvious piece of updating being made somewhere else. We are talking about substantive amendments. Perhaps the most substantive of all is the change to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which has the effect of changing the qualification to vote in this country, at least for persons coming on to the rolls in the future, from the traditional reference to British subjects now to Australian citizens. That change was foreshadowed by the Government earlier this year and it has the full support of the Opposition. Nonetheless it is not the kind of change which we believe ought to be hidden away in this fashion in this kind of Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Moreover, the Bill does not just stop with the 17 major Acts to which I have referred. If one turns to the schedules to the Bill one finds another 12 Acts which are amended in various ways, mostly in formal ways rather than substantive ways, but, of course, one does not know that until one examines them closely. Then another three Acts are repealed altogether. So the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill is not just one Bill but, in fact, 32. This Bill, being brought forward by the Government in this way, represents in the Opposition's submission a most unhappy development in our legislative practice, particularly following, as it does, the introduction in May this year of a Statute Law Revision Bill which similarly was full of substantive provisions, most notably the new section 15AA of the Acts Interpretation Act, and to which, at the time, we made similar objections.

In this kind of omnibus Bill which contains substantive amendments to the Act with which it deals, not merely formal ones, not the least of the difficulties presented to parliamentarians, and especially to Oppositions trying to consider its implications, is that one has to farm it out for reaction not just to one shadow Minister or to one Caucus or party committee as the case may be. To do the job properly one has to have, in this case, nearly a dozen different shadow Ministers and half a dozen different parliamentary party committees looking at its terms. This sort of scrutiny cannot always easily be accomplished in practice in the time available for us to consider these things, that is between the introduction of the Bill and the debate in this place. This means that perhaps one or two shadow Ministers and perhaps one or two committees simply try to scrutinise and understand the implications of these kinds of provisions which operate in areas outside their immediate expertise and experience.

If one takes the view that Parliament is a mere rubber stamp whose legislative role in particular is a complete formality, then one will not be very much moved by this state of affairs. But I believe that most of us have some larger sense of responsibility than that. Bills like this make it very difficult for us to exercise that responsibility. I make this point with all deliberation and seriousness. I appreciate the difficulties of accommodating a series of small legislative proposals to busy parliamentary timetables; but there are acute difficulties in dealing with legislation of this kind, not only for us as parliamentarians in trying to understand its implications and to deal with it in our rushed programs, but also, of course, for those outside this place who are trying to follow the tortuous web that statutory amendments weave in the statute book. Their task is not made easier by this kind of approach to the legislative process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you have 17 different Bills?

—Seventeen different Acts are dealt with in the major part of the Bill before us. Each of those 17 Bills is dealt with in a substantive way with up to, in each case, half a dozen different sections being amended and many pages of text being covered by the terms of those amendments. If one then goes to the Schedule one finds, as I have said before, another dozen Acts which are amended, some in significant ways but most, from the Schedule, in purely formal ways. However, we do not know this until we dig them out one at a time and look at them. Another three Bills are being repealed altogether. So we have a situation of not just one Bill before us now but 32 different Bills, and that is an unsatisfactory state of affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulties in dealing with this sort of legislation are compounded when one finds that the second reading speech of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) is inaccurate. One would think one could rely at least upon that for an accurate summary, in outline, of what the Bill contains and at least to alert one as to the substantive nature of the provisions which are being brought forward in this way. When one finds that the speech is inaccurate in significant respects, as it is in particular in the context of the changes to the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act, then that further weakens any residual faith one might have had in the legitimacy of this kind of approach to the legislative process. In the event, having gone through the very laborious task of checking in detail what all these various amendments are about, looking to the original Acts, checking with other shadow Ministers, checking with the relevant parliamentary committees, at the end we find that it does not appear that there is anything, apart from the amendment to the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act, which I will come to in the Committee stage, which is of a sufficiently either substantive or objectionable character for the Opposition to oppose this Bill at either the second reading or the Committee stage.

Nonetheless, a number of things could be said to put on the record the implications of these various changes and to describe them to the no doubt breathless public which listens to and reads our proceedings. Since that task has already been successfully accomplished by Mr Bowen, the Opposition spokesman in the House of Representatives debate on 17 November, I do not propose to delay the Senate any further at the second reading stage. The main object in my rising to speak to this Bill, and to do so quite forcefully on behalf of the Opposition, is to express our concern at what seems to be an accelerating pattern of legislative practice with these omnibus Bills. It is a pattern which we do not object to in the slighest when purely formal changes are being made, as they must be from time to time to accommodate drafting errors or very minor corrections to Bills. But when substantive provisions of very great significance are in issue here, we believe that the legislative process is not being treated with the respect that it should be. It is not possible for us to perform as parliamentarians, and particularly as Opposition senators, the functions that we would wish to as legislators, and we hope that the Government in this respect mends its way in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981. I will comment firstly on the remarks and views Senator Evans expressed, which I must say seemed somewhat inconsistent. Senator Evans said that 17 major Acts are involved. I think some of them are major and some of them are not; it is probably a matter of degree in interpretation. The honourable senator said that, altogether, 32 Acts are amended. Surely it follows logically from his statement that he believes we ought to have separate Bills in respect of each of these Acts. Apart from suggesting that, something like a cricket score, we pass so many Bills this year-we know that already we sometimes have to have separate Bills because of the requirements of our Constitution to have the numbers build up-to have separate Bills which have to go through separate stages in the legislative process is, to my mind, not justified. If the conclusion Senator Evans made was that there are some very tricky, difficult and objectionable matters in parts of this Bill, one could think that that might justify separate Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: But he came to the conclusion, albeit after quite a lot of hard work, that there is one part that he objects to. Actually, there is one thing I want to query among this miscellany, but I would suggest that apparently the Government has been right in its conclusion that these were relatively uncontroversial items. They may affect fairly major Acts in some respects, if we take the example the honourable senator gave in regard to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the very useful provisions that we now talk about in respect of Australian citizenship. Along this line, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, reporting on the qualifications of members of parliament, made the same sort of recommendations. I trust that the implementation of those recommendations may follow. We had the same view as in this example. Of course, the Commonwealth Electoral Act is an important Act but the fact is that this is not a controversial proposal, and pretty obviously is not judged as being so by the lack of objection here tonight. I therefore suggest that there is very little merit in the idea that these should be separate Acts and somehow-

TALK.START.PARA: —They would not get on without this vehicle.
—That is probably so. It would be a matter of time and so forth.
—How much legislative time does it take to deal with an uncontroversial Bill? Be fair.

—Thirty-two Bills will make a difference to that argument. It can be done here in one Bill. I suggest that is not really a fair criticism. I think Senator Evans and I will probably agree that in fact it is difficult to scrutinise Bills of this nature and other Bills. We have had some discussion about this in recent weeks. The Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which is now in operation, has not been able to turn its attention this week to Bills that are coming on for debate this week, although it has already met and made its plans. I will make a statement about it tomorrow. Indeed, one would expect that Bills like this would be carefully scrutinised by that Committee in the future. Therefore, I suppose it will assist members of this Parliament who at the moment find it difficult to put the time aside to check what is being done in a Bill like this and whether there are problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to one of the parts of this Bill and query one matter in it because it has had some history, and I am not too certain as to what the intention of the Government is in regard to it. I refer to Part V of the Amendment of Australian Capital Territory Evidence (Temporary Provisions) Act 1971. That is quite a short Part but it does two things. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) set out the reasons why this has come about. It has had quite a complicated history. The clause in this Bill now amends the Australian Capital Territory Evidence (Temporary Provisions) Act 1971. It seeks to enable that Act in future to be amended or repealed by an ordinance and not to require a further Act of the Parliament. That is an unusual provision. Over the years there has been a great deal of criticism of provisions in various Acts of Parliament which have enabled them to be altered without coming back to the Parliament but by an ordinance or some regulation introduced by a Minister. Clauses which are known as Henry VIII clauses have been criticised in a number of reports which my Committee-the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-has made. I think it is generally undesirable that changes be made to Acts or to Schedules to Acts taking away provisions or adding to them without reference to the Parliament. But there are, of course, some occasions when this might be done, and I think this is one.

The situation with regard to the evidence laws of the Territory is that in 1971 the Evidence Ordinance was put down. As the Attorney-General stated in his second reading speech, it 'contains comprehensive rules of evidence for civil and criminal proceedings in the Australian Capital Territory'. He also said that the Ordinance was disallowed by the Senate in 1971. That was done on the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. The reason it was disallowed was not really related to the actual terms of the Ordinance, but to the fact that that Committee took the view-and the Senate supported it-that those provisions ought to be contained in an Act of Parliament and ought not to be contained in an ordinance which was not capable of being debated in the Parliament, except by way of disallowance.

A series of actions was then taken because the effect of disallowing that particular Ordinance was that there were no provisions left in the Territory for evidence laws for criminal trials, for example. Those provisions had gone, so it was necessary to bring in Acts to reinstate, temporarily as it were, the Ordinance while the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee undertook an investigation. Year after year there were repetitions of this temporary law. At first it was confined to only one year; subsequently that provision was taken away and it became permanent. In fact, from 1972 to 1976 the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee did not turn to this investigation at all. When I became Chairman of that Committee in early 1976 we found this reference still sitting there, practically unattended to, although I think some evidence had been called for and a little evidence had been received. We held an inquiry and in November 1977 presented a report to the Senate entitled 'The Evidence (Australian Capital Territory) Bill 1972'. That report went into a number of areas. It went through the Ordinance and suggested quite a number of alterations to it. But it also suggested that the whole of the evidence laws for the Commonwealth ought to be re-investigated by the Australian Law Reform Commission and that it should not be done in a piecemeal manner.

In that report the Committee also made recommendations on this general question of whether matters such as the laws of evidence for the Territory ought to be dealt with by an Act of the Parliament or by ordinance. I think it is worth mentioning, because it affects this particular provision in the Bill, that among the recommendations which the Committee made was one which stated:
Legislation which, in Australian States, would usually be made by Act of a State Parliament, should normally be made by Ordinance.

It can well be said that this is one such provision in that matters of evidence are dealt with in the Australian States generally by an evidence Act. Therefore, it is proper that this legislation ought to be by ordinance, and that should be the final situation. To back-up that assertion, I point out that a further recommendation which we made in that report was:
Legislation of a particular Territory which is socially innovative or affects fundamental rights and liberties, if it is of the kind referred to in sub-paragraphs (d)-
Sub-paragraph (d) is the one to which I have just referred-
and (e) above, should be made by Ordinance.

I think that the new evidence Bill or ordinance which will come from the final determinations of the Australian Law Reform Commission probably will make quite considerable suggestions for change in the evidence law, because the evidence law of the Territory is very backward. In fact, it very much depends upon the New South Wales law. I think the original Act of 1898 has not been brought up to date in many respects. There is great dissatisfaction, I think, with the evidence law. Proposed new section 3(2) of the Bill states:
Nothing in sub-section (1)-
Sub-section (1) adds to the principal Act-
prevents the amendment or repeal by an Ordinance under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910 of the provisions continued in force by that sub-section.

That means that alterations can be made in the future, while the provisions continue by ordinance, without having to come back to this Parliament and legislate for them by Act. Curiously, the Minister, in his second reading speech, goes on to state:
Following a recommendation of the Commmittee-
That is, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs-

the law of evidence applicable in proceedings in Federal and Territory Courts was referred to the Law Reform Commission in 1979 for review and report. The Commissioner's report is not expected for some time. The amendmant proposed by the Bill is an interim measure only, pending the Report of the Law Reform Commission.

I appreciate what is in that statement. I take it that is the intention of the Attorney. There is, in fact, nothing in the clause which says anything about any interim nature. I suppose it would probably be very difficult to have such a provision. I am glad to see that there is in mind that this practice will be brought to an end and that there will be at some time in the near future a further and up-to-date law on evidence which will enable the Territory to join the twentieth century so far as these matters are concerned. I think the position there in regard to business records and the whole law of hearsay is very unsatisfactory. I hope that the position will be improved. I trust that this temporary provision will not apply for too long.

I wish to refer to one other matter which I think is somewhat mysterious. I draw the attention of the honourable senators to proposed new section 3 (3) in clause 12 which is concerned with the validation of provisions of the Australian Capital Territory evidence Ordinance. The proposed new section states:

''The Interpretation Ordinance 1967 of the Australian Capital Territory, as amended and in force from time to time, applies, and shall be deemed to have always applied, to the provisions continued in force by sub-section (1).''.

If one looks at the types of provisions in ordinances which have been objected to from time to time by the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee and the types of provisions in Bills which I would hope the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills will be looking at, one would like some explanation why this somewhat mysterious provision appears in the legislation. The legislation appears to be retrospective, if I can use that terrible word. I do not have a complete objection to retrospective legislation. I think that legislation of this type is necessary on some occasions. But I think that as a matter of general principle, it should be avoided. I would like to know why this provision is deemed to be necessary. Why do we deem the Interpretation Ordinance to have always applied to the provisions in force? One would like to be assured that there is no existing litigation that might be affected by this provision so that the introduction of this clause would affect people's rights retrospectively. It may be that this provision has been included for some cautionary reason and that there is no intention of that sort. I ask the Attorney why that provision is in the clause because I think we ought to know why any retrospective provision is included.

I hope that we will soon get to a situation where these temporary provisions involving a long and complicated procedure which has been followed to keep evidence laws on foot but in a rather sickly state will cease. We also have a curious and unexplained provision which is not mentioned in any way in the Minister's second reading speech. Apart from that, I believe that the provisions made in this Bill are worth while. They cover a considerable number of Acts. A great deal of busy attention has been given to updating the laws and removing unnecessary ones. Rather than the legislation being the subject of some criticism on the part of Senator Evans, it ought to have been the subject of some praise. Unfortunately, the honourable senator did not stay to praise tonight, but to criticise. On the whole, I think this is a very useful piece of work. The legislation may not be exciting for people who are listening to this debate but I think it will be taken as one of the useful pieces of law reform carried out by the Government this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of the second reading of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, despite the criticism levelled at the Bill by Senator Evans. However, unqualified support was given to it by Senator Missen, for which I am very thankful; as I am for all the support I can get in this Senate. Senator Evans continued his criticism of the policy behind this form of legislation. I do have some concerns that legislation of this sort should be very strictly confined to non-controversial matters but, as Senator Missen has pointed out, the alternative to legislation in this form is to bring in a great miscellany of separate Bills which, although they may be dealt with quite expediently, would certainly add to the time required of the Senate to attend to them. Provided this form of legislation is properly confined to non-controversial matters it seems that it is a convenient way of approaching the situation. I am conscious of the problem that is presented by making any judgment about whether matters are non-controversial. However, I think it is clear from the debate we have had that a fairly reasonable judgment has been made in that regard on this legislation because, subject to what Senator Evans may have to say about one particular part of it, nothing has been raised which would reflect in any way on the broad judgment that this legislation does contain non-controversial matters.

SPEECH.PARA: We have changed the title from the Statute Law Revision Bill to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill because it does contain more than just the ordinary statute law revision type of legislation. A change of title has been made to reflect that situation. I hope that the Parliament will continue to support the concept of tackling these problems in this way because of its convenience.
