However, I appreciate that if this form of legislation were abused and used to sneak in amendments of a controversial kind then the Parliament would not allow that abuse to continue. So long as we can confine such measures in broad terms to non-controversial matters this procedure has a role to play. It has now become accepted as part of the program for each session of Parliament and I think a lot of parliamentary time can be saved by legislating for this type of amendment in this way. The Government hopes to continue legislating in this way and hopes to have the support of the Senate to do so.

Senator Missen raised a matter in relation to one part of the legislation which it might be convenient to deal with now even though perhaps it would be appropriate to deal with it in the Committee stage. I am glad that Senator Missen has supported this provision. I must say I had some doubts about including this part of the legislation because I thought it may be controversial, the Senate having taken-albeit 10 years ago-the stance that it did in requiring amendments to the evidence laws of the Australian Capital Territory to be made by legislation. However, if 10 years ago the Senate had had the benefit of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on this subject it may well have taken a different and more reasonable approach than it took at that time. It would be really inappropriate for this Parliament to take up time in debating amendments to the evidence laws in the Australian Capital Territory unless they were being implemented pursuant to a codification of the law on evidence pursuant to the Law Reform Commission report. I have left that question open. I think it is a matter which, in an exceptional case such as that, may well be appropriate for the Parliament to deal with.

The problem we are faced with at the moment is that we have this strait-jacket in the shape of provisions of an ordinance being validated by an Act of the Parliament and amendments, even ones of only a fairly minor kind, being made by amendments to that Act of Parliament. The simplest way of overcoming the problem seemed to be the solution proposed in this legislation. I am glad that the Senate is obviously supporting it. As I have said, I keep open the question of what we may do if we receive ultimately from the Law Reform Commission a report which suggests a new code of evidence. The immediate reason for this amendment, as the Senate would be well aware from my answers to questions asked largely by Senator Ryan, is that we are ready to have a new rape ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory which will, of course, include a number of evidentiary provisions as well as provisions relating to substantive law of rape. It is much more appropriate for all of that to be done in the one ordinance.

Senator Missen raised a question in relation to proposed new sub-section (3) of section 3 as contained in clause 12 of the Bill. I understand that the reason for that is simply abundant caution. Obviously, an interpretation ordinance would have applied to the previous ordinance, but, as that had been continued by an Act of Parliament, the Acts (Interpretation) Act might be thought to apply to it and therefore there would be some doubt, after this Bill had gone through, as to which provision would apply. I understand that that was inserted simply for that reason. I thank the Senate for its support of this measure. I hope that, despite the fact that further matters may be raised by Senator Evans, the Bill will have a passage this evening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the points that were made by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his reply to the second reading debate. I do not propose to prolong the debate, on which there is obviously a difference of opinion between us, except to make a couple of points to introduce the matter to which I wish to draw attention, namely, clause 24. I appreciate what has been said by both Senator Missen and the Attorney-General about the Australian Capital Territory Evidence Ordinance provision that is buried in this Bill. The Opposition is well aware of the long history behind this provision. Indeed, it had a number of reservations about the legislative exercise being proposed; namely, to give the power of amending the Australian Capital Territory evidence law back to the Governor-General in Council by way of ordinance, rather than having it reside in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We knew what was being proposed. We had reservations about it because we were well aware of the long and and controversial history of this matter. But we accepted that because we were prepared to accept at face value the clear statement of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in his second reading speech that this legislation was simply a temporary approach to this matter until such time as the Law Reform Commission could bring down its full recommendations, that the Government was in no way foreshadowing its likely approach to the Law Reform Commission's recommendations and that it was indeed perfectly possible that the best way of dealing with those recommendations would be by way of an Act of this Parliament.

In the light of that clear ministerial statement in the second reading speech we on the Opposition side swallowed our reservations and, as I have done tonight, passed over any possible reservations or objections to that sort of clause. But that shows the importance of there being absolute scrupulousness in the presentation of these sorts of provisions, absolute accuracy in the description by the Minister in his second reading speech of what is understood is going on with these amendments and what is proposed to be accomplished by them. When in that ministerial statement in the second reading speech there is inaccuracy as to what is embodied in these provisions, that cannot do other than arouse our hackles about being confronted with this sort of legislation.

This is the point which comes in issue when we get to the provisions dealing with the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act. The second reading speech of the Minister, on which as I said we have had to rely necessarily to get the gist of proposals particularly when they are buried in compendius Bills of this kind, is quite misleading. What the Minister says in describing the ambit of these changes is this:

The amendments embrace four particular areas of concern and propose: (i) an expanded definition of 'development project' as contained in the Act to include projects concerned solely with the supply of services; (ii) the inclusion of a provision to enable the Corporation to engage directly in negotiations on overseas projects with overseas clients at the request of the Australian Government; (iii) the inclusion of a provision to enable the Corporation under certain circumstances to act at the request of an authority of the Commonwealth or a State government; and (iv) the replacement of the maximum contingent liability concept in the Act which has proved difficult to define precisely in terms of the Corporation's activities with the concept of assessed net commercial risk. The effect of implementing these amendments will be to enable the Corporation to operate more effectively and in line with the original objectives of the legislation.

We do not have just a bland general statement; we have what purports to be four rather precise descriptive statements about the ambit of these few new or amended sections in that Act-the amendments accomplished by this Bill. Yet when we look to the detail of the Bill-I refer to clause 24 and the proposed new section 8A that this clause will introduce into the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act-we see that something rather different, very different, is being accomplished. What is being accomplished by this new section is a significant limitation on the scope of the activity of the Corporation. The existing section 8 of the Act rules out the Corporation's capacity to compete directly against Australian private enterprise. This proposed new section 8A goes further than that and prevents the Corporation from assisting Australian public authorities or public consortia to compete against private enterprise to carry out an overseas project. So we have a further constraint being imposed, one that is not flagged, not foreshadowed, not identified and not referred to in the second reading speech, even though it is, on the face of it, a speech which purports to deal with this subject matter in some little detail.

What is being done in this proposed new section, to take one possible example, is to rule out the capacity of the Corporation to give assistance to some authority such as the Snowy Mountains Authority in competing for engineering contracts in South East Asia or anywhere else in the world. I will not mention the Australian Dairy Corporation in that respect. That is another example of an authority which has been operating overseas in a commercial way. There are other authorities which perhaps would want to get into those markets and would very much welcome the assistance of the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation in doing so. Their competition in those markets would quite likely be advantageous to the national interest.

That, of course, is a provision which is controversial. I do not go into the boring detail about why it is controversial; it should be obvious enough. We of the Opposition would not accept the kind of ideological proposition that is so dear to this Government's heart that anything that public authorities do ipso facto is less attractive and less in the national interest than anything of the same kind which private enterprise might be minded to do. We take the view that public enterprise is perfectly capable of acting to the nation's commercial and economic advantage and in fact is quite likely to be more efficient and certainly more equitable in the way it approaches the redistribution of the profits that it makes than a private competitor or private alternative. I will not go into those details; I simply make the point that the Opposition opposes this clause. We are unhappy about a clause of this naturally controversial kind appearing in a Bill of this kind, and we are even more unhappy about such a provision not being flagged as it should have been in the second reading speech. Having made that point and indicated the Opposition's opposition to this proposal, I resume my seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will comment very briefly. I agree with Senator Evans that the Parliament requires fairly detailed assistance with a second reading speech for a Bill of this kind although, of course, it is the obligation of members of parliament to scrutinise the legislation. They should realise that a second reading speech cannot cover every feature of legislation and remain within the bounds of readability. A compromise has to be struck in drafting second reading speeches. In this case the principle of the proposed new section 24, although not mentioned in the second reading speech, is covered already in the existing Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act. Section 8, of that Act states that the Corporation is not to take up work which private enterprise is interested in carrying out. Proposed new section 8A is really only an extension or a further application of that principle. I defend it on that basis. It is not a new principle being introduced. However, obviously no harm has been done. Senator Evans and his colleagues have picked up the point and have been able to make their comments about it. Obviously there are differences of ideological approach between the Government and the Opposition in relation to these matters. The Government's policies are already set out in the existing Act. The proposed amendment is only giving some further definition, and perhaps width to that policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Durack) read a third time.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. The Government's reasons for adopting this course are clear and unambiguous. On 2 June 1981, when I introduced the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1981 into this chamber, I indicated that at the time amendments were not being sought to the amalgamation provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904. The second reading speech-I quote from Hansard, page 2477, of 2 June 1981-stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The creation of industry based unions is an established policy of both Government parties and the ACTU. Work has been done, in the consultation with the NLCC, on amendments to the amalgamation provisions of the Act on the basis of a criteria of the community-of-interest of the unions desiring amalgamation. However, the Government parties wish to consider the full implications of such a criteria for amalgamation and its relevance to meeting the objective of encouraging the formation of industry based unions before proceeding further with any such amendments.

The Government parties will be examining what other means might be available to achieving the formation of industry based unions and also, within that examination, the possibility and practicability of the formation of enterprise based unions as part of the concept of industry based unions. The Government will be doing this, Mr President, because of the belief that the general public wish to see a stronger movement towards industry based unions.

As I said at the outset, there is nothing ambiguous about those words or the Government's course in this area. The proposals for amalgamation were to be subjected to further examination against the Government's overall objectives of encouraging the formation of industry based unions. Since that time the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) and the Government Members Employment and Industrial Relations Committee have been conducting a detailed examination of the proposals. The Government makes no apology for the fact that the proposals have been subjected to such detailed scrutiny and that earlier legislative drafts have been put aside whilst this is undertaken. The issues are complex. Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) said in this chamber on 2 June 1981:
the case for industry based unionism is overwhelming if we are to improve industrial relations in Australia . . .

The Opposition and the Government are on common ground on this but on opposite sides in believing that the amalgamation proposals will bring about the creation of industry based unions. The Leader of the Opposition went on to say:

I am not so naive as to say that it would be an easy task to change the basis of Australian trade-unionism to industry based unionism in the foreseeable future, but there is scope for consideration for union amalgamations on the basis of the community of interest concept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I say all that?

—Yes, the honourable senator did. I am not surprised that he should be resiling from it. The Government parties 1975 employment and industrial relations policy states that industry based unions would reduce the frequency and likelihood of industrial disputes. From what Senator Button has said, the Opposition would not contest that proposition. However, as Senator Button recognises, it is another thing to find the right legislative formula and to put such a policy into practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill which Senator Button has introduced reflects the provisions which the Government had recommended to it by the National Labour Consultative Council. Those provisions do no more than facilitate the amalgamation of organisations registered under the Act. In fact, it is simply an alternative course to be followed from the current provisions and would enable a return of 25 per cent of union members to vote rather than 50 per cent as provided for at present, if the Commission decides that the organisations proposing to amalgamate have been able to establish what is called a 'community of interest' between them. I would add of course that that means that one is looking for no more than a favourable vote of 12 1/2 per cent of the membership of the union plus one, a relatively small proportion.

Such a less stringent voting requirement was proposed by the NLCC because of the difficulties which organisations allegedly have in ensuring that a majority of their membership vote on the question of amalgamation. However, the fact that organisations find it difficult to obtain a 50 per cent membership vote as required by the existing provisions of the Act does not necessarily justify making it easier to amalgamate. It can be legitimately asked whether in those circumstances the desire for amalgamation by the rank and file as distinct from the leadership is in fact very strong.

If it is not then there is, of course, less reason to alter the law simply to make amalgamation easier. However, irrespective of that exercise in logic as far as democratic processes go, the proposals we are looking at do not guarantee that there will be amalgamation of existing organisations which will result in the formation of industry based unions. The criteria for establishing community of interest is not directed towards industry unions but rather would reinforce the existing structures and allow their aggregation without any change towards an objective common to the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and, apparently, the Opposition; namely, industry based unions. That is why the Government is not prepared at this stage to proceed with legislation in the form of the NLCC proposals or to support Senator Button's Bill.

We are conscious of the election statement on amalgamation but consider it prudent to take discussion and policy development within the Government parties a good deal further before putting firm legislative proposals before the Parliament. The kind of consideration being given to the most appropriate means of achieving industry based unions, for example, ranges over the sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which would need to be amended to ensure that new enterprise or industry based unions are capable of achieving registration. One measure which could be examined in this respect is the removal of the 'conveniently belong' limitation from section 142. Another matter which could be looked at is an amendment to the objects of the Act in section 2 as well as a definition of 'industry' for the purpose of union formation or the reformation of existing unions.

These and other relevant matters are in fact currently being examined by my colleague, the Minister for Industrial Relations, with a view to developing policy proposals for legislative change which will more accurately provide a framework for the formation of industry based unions. Honourable senators will appreciate that they are matters both important and complex and not lightly to be played with in the manner in which this private member's Bill is being put forward by the Opposition. The Government recognises that this process may cause some concern to members of the NLCC, especially as they spent considerable time and effort in formulating their proposals. However, consistent with the processes of the NLCC, my colleague has informed that body of the work being carried out on the issue and, when the policy proposals are formulated, he will be taking them back to NLCC for the necessary consultations. The Government, therefore, opposes the Bill which is at present before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — Union mergers are vital for the future well being of workers and employers in this country. The existing crazy patchwork quilt of unions and staff associations is a legacy of industrial history with which we should long ago have dispensed. Recent events, notably the abandonment of wage indexation, have increased the pressure for this long overdue reform. Why have there been so few amalgamations if merger is such a good thing? The first impediment was the requirement for the registration of trade unions at the turn of the century. The intent of this requirement was to bring unions under judicial control. Its effect was almost to freeze the number of Australian unions at 19th century levels for 80 years. The development of unions in other democracies has continued apace in all this time. As already pointed out by Senator Button, the Federal Republic of Germany has only 16 unions despite the fact that it has a large number of workers and is highly unionised unlike, for example, the United States. Most other European countries have followed a similar path but the impediments to union amalgamation in Australia have prevented much progress to date in this country. Instead, we have followed the conservative example of the United Kingdom in this, as in so many things, and have remained blind to the changed shape of modern industrial society.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian unionism continues to try to adapt this society to its own antiquated shape. Industry unions have so many advantages. Sensible, rational countries adopted them long ago and abolished craft unions. Industry unions make for better relations between management and staff by giving the staff a closer identification with and involvement in the fortunes of the industry rather than, as now, a tendency to be locked into their own separate craft union boxes. As Senator Button has already mentioned the virtues of union amalgamation in regard to demarcation disputes, I will not belabour this point. Suffice it to say that several major disputes, notably on the waterfront and among the postal unions, had nothing to do with employers and cost the country dearly. Anything which would prevent or resolve disputes such as those without recourse to strike action is certainly to be welcomed.

Earlier I said that the abandonment of wage indexation had increased the pressure for amalgamation. In a collective bargaining situation the strong thrive and the weak suffer. I have long advocated, and will continue to do so, collective bargaining on the American model. I believe employers and employees should be able to negotiate legally enforceable contracts which give both sides stability and prosperity. In fact, such a system has begun to arrive in this country on a de facto basis. Within the overall framework of the Australian system we now have major unions negotiating directly with employers for mutual benefit. Such a development is to be welcomed and could lead to an unparalleled period of industrial peace and prosperity in this country.

It might be asked along what lines union amalgamations should proceed. In the Melbourne Age of 28 August 1980 the former Prime Minister, Mr Gough Whitlam, suggested that unions amalgamate along the same lines used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics when it publishes industrial information. In fact, the ABS uses 15 groups, including mining and quarrying; engineering, metals and vehicles; textiles, clothing and footwear; food, drink and tobacco; sawmilling and furniture; paper and printing; railway services; road and air transport; shipping and stevedoring; communications; wholesale and retail trade; public authorities; and amusements and hotels. Although one might quarrel with a couple of the details, this at least provides an intelligent basis on which to discuss details and perhaps guidelines for amalgamation. I stress guidelines for amalgamation only.

The essential thrust of union amalgamations must be at the grass roots. In the final analysis the unions themselves must decide who shall amalgamate with whom. At least we have to have guidelines. I suggest that these 15 groups could be used as a basis for discussion and as a general objective for the unions concerned. At present a major impediment to amalgamation is the 50 per cent rule brought in by McMahon in 1972, and this was covered at some length in Senator Button's speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —The DLP.

—I agree that it was under strong pressure from the Democratic Labor Party. I have always thought it was strange that McMahon did this because he was generally regarded as a sensible Minister in this portfolio during the 1960s. Nonetheless, as Senator Button has pointed out, it is completely arbitrary and foolish, and the existing Bill should be changed so that we can get on with the business of union amalgamation. The question of union amalgamation is like the weather. Everybody complains about it but nobody does anything about it. The Democrats are happy to be seen to be helping to do something about it on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. I stress that in opposing this amalgamation Bill the Government does not take the view that amalgamations in the union field are not ultimately of great significance and in proper measure to be encouraged.
—'Ultimately' is the word, isn't it?
—Since Senator Button said that 'ultimately' is the word, I refer him to his very intelligent remarks when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not so naive as to say that it would be an easy task to change the basis of Australian trade-unionism to industry based unionism in the foreseeable future. . .
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Australian Navy: Purchase of Aircraft Carrier-The Senate: Answers to Questions-Mildura District: Application for Radio Broadcasting Licence-Mr Alan Carroll-Queensland: Proposed International Exposition 1988

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

Before I call Senator MacGibbon, I point out to honourable senators that the timing clock mechanism has failed the Senate this evening. Six honourable senators have indicated that they wish to speak in the adjournment debate. Each honourable senator is entitled to speak for one hour. I inform honourable senators that they will be timed manually.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Deputy President, I hope that I do not lapse into my old habit and speak for an hour as I used to do in lectures. My purpose in talking at such an unconscionable hour is to discuss a matter of considerable national importance to Australians, namely, the purchase of another aircraft carrier for the Royal Australian Navy. Indeed, according to the Press reports and rumours in this town-it is a very topical subject-it is widely believed that the Department of Defence has recommended the purchase of a British ship and that a Cabinet decision favourable to purchase is imminent. I sincerely hope that those rumours are not true because there is absolutely no case for panic buying in this matter. What I have to say is relevant to the purchase of a carrier, irrespective of the stage the negotiations have reached.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to take two issues separately. The first is the purchase of another carrier and the second is the purchase of the Invincible or one of the three British Invincible class ships. The Navy justifies the need for a new carrier on two broad grounds. The first is convoy protection. In that it is talking about providing organic air, in the jargon of the Navy, which just means having air power at sea, and about providing an anti-submarine warfare capacity by means of rotary or fixed wing aircraft. The second justification which the Navy gives for its decision is the power projection argument, the gunboat diplomacy argument, of being able to send a great big ship into a harbour and convince a dictator that he really should not do what he has set out to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is a much smaller ship now.

—It is a little toy; the honourable senator is right. I reject the puerile, semantic argument that we are talking about a Department of Defence decision in this. Sure, it is a Department of Defence decision insofar as it comes through that Department but what we are talking about is specifically a Navy decision, a Navy need as it perceives it. I propose to call a spade a spade and talk about the Navy's case justifying the purchase of a carrier.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I examine those two cases that the Navy has established it is as well to remind honourable senators of some points that they know very well, fundamental points about a carrier. The overwhelming point about a carrier in today's weapons systems is its vulnerability. It is an extremely vulnerable weapons system, an extremely expensive weapons system. We are not talking about something of the calibre of the USS Enterprise or one of the Forrestal class ships of about 70,000 or 80,000 tonnes. As Senator Mason said we are talking about a very small and a very poorly defended ship. The reason this ship is so vulnerable is that there is no secrecy about its position. A carrier or any other ship cannot be hidden on the surface of the water any longer, in this age of satellite technology. The Navy claims that when we reach the point of war there will be no satellites. The only scenario to which that could apply is one in which there is total war with Russia; then the killer satellites may eliminate the surveillance satellites of the opposing power, but I think is very unlikely. I do not know what the Russians have, but it is my advice that despite many millions spent on laser technology for killer satellites, the United States has not got to the level where it can knock out Russian surveillance satellites. I would think that we would be involved in much lower levels of conflict than World War III, so it is a safe presumption that satellite technology will always exist. While that is so, the position of the ship will be updated hour by hour.

We also have the problems of air surveillance by maritime reconnaissance aircraft, to say nothing of surface ships and underwater surveillance. An important point in relation to the vulnerability of the type of carrier that the Royal Australian Navy wants to buy is that it will have no radar defence of its own against low level strike aircraft, or against low level surveillance aircraft for that matter. It will have a capacity from its own seaborne radar to pick up high flying aircraft to ranges in excess of 200 nautical miles, but the radar horizon is only 20 nautical miles away and any aircraft coming in on strike or surveillance mission below the radar horizon will come to within 20 nautical miles of that carrier before it can be detected. The reaction time from a 20-nautical mile radius is very small and, unless there is a standing air patrol over the carrier, effectively no counter-defensive capacity can be mounted.

The answer to this that the Americans adopt with their bigger carriers is to use a standing radar picket flying over the fleet, a Grumman E2C or one of the radar surveillance aircraft. But the RAN cannot use those aircraft with the type of ship envisaged because the flight deck is too small to allow them to land. Also, the type of aircraft we are proposing to buy, the Sea Harriers, do not have the radar capacity, the look-down capacity, to mount an effective radar picket. Added to that, the number of Harriers that would be embarked on a ship of this nature is very limited and there would be great difficulty in maintaining a continuous air patrol over the ship. So, the ship's position can be fixed continuously by an aggressor force. In an age of missile technology-air to surface, surface to surface and underwater-the carrier can be taken out. Indeed, this has been the record of the Royal Australian Navy with the Melbourne in all the Kangaroo exercises that have been held. I do not know how many times it was destroyed in Kangaroo 81 last month, but it did not survive at all; it was being refurbished by the umpires every few hours.

The second fundamental point about this type of carrier is the poverty of the air defence system that it can carry. The type of carrier we are talking about has a very short deck. It is committed to operating only one type of aircraft, the VSTOL aircraft. There is only one of those in the Western inventory and that is the Sea Harrier or the AV8B which is being developed for the United States Marine Corps. The Sea Harrier has a very limited capacity as a fighter. It has quite a short range and is very slow. Not only is it subsonic but it is also considerably subsonic. As I said earlier, the development of its radar, the Blue Fox radar of Ferranti, is not coming along as it might. It has the inherent problems, as had the radar of the F16, of being limited by the small amount of accommodation available in the fuselage and nose of this aircraft. It will not have an adequate look-down capacity to pick up low flying aircraft against the sea returns to the level needed for the security of the carrier.

The unfortunate thing about the Sea Harrier is that it is a very old design. It is a development of a design that I first saw fly at Farnborough in 1959. One cannot really do much with it. We have to go ultimately to supersonic aircraft, but the problems in developing an engine with the required power are considerable. The AV8B is the alternative aircraft. Basically the AV8B is being built for the United States Marine Corps. Quite simply, it is a bomb truck. It is a very effective bomb truck. It will carry a good load, come back, rearm and go out again. But it is a close support weapons system for the United States Marine Corps in beach landings and in a land environment. It is not a fighting aircraft at all in the sense of being an air to air weapons system and, while it could be modified to provide it with some air to air radar and air to air weapons systems, the cost of doing so would be quite unmanageable.

Let us look at the Navy requirements that were advanced. Firstly, there was the requirement of convoy protection. That is not a realistic need for the Royal Australian Navy at present. The Navy puts the case that we are a great trading nation, that we rank seventh, fourteenth or whatever it is in the world and that nearly all of our exports and imports move by sea. That happens to be perfectly true. It also happens to be perfectly true that Australia owns very few of the ships that are engaged in international trade. In a time of tension, the ships of foreign nationals would have to fly under Australian flag escorts; and this simply is not a realistic situation. The countries either would not trade with Australia or, if they were going to trade with Australia, would use their own Navy ships to provide the escort services for that trade.

I go to all the lectures that the Navy has on justifying the need for this carrier, sea power and all the rest of it, and I hear senior naval officers talking about fighting oil convoys through from the Persian Gulf. Frankly, I cannot comprehend anyone who suggests that, with one small carrier, the Royal Australian Navy would be able to keep Australia supplied with oil by operating a convoy system from the Persian Gulf to Australia. It would be very much better to take the $1,500m that the Navy proposes to spend on this vessel and put it into researching alternative forms of energy in Australia such and putting it towards a Sasol plant or something like that so that we have 100 per cent self-sufficiency of fuel supplies.

The second basis on which the Navy justifies its proposed purchase is the ground of gunboat diplomacy. That has never been practised by Australia and the opportunities for practising it in the foreseeable future are just nil. We do not indulge in that sort of operation and we are unlikely ever to do that in the future. At a lesser level two other cases can be considered. The first is the business of amphibious landings and the second is the evacuation of Australian nationals from islands in the Pacific area. There is no way that the Australian Navy would have the capacity to mount opposed landings over the beach. We do not have the technology for it. It is very complex technology. The United States is the only country practising amphibious warfare techniques at any level at all. The standard approach, of course, is by air insertion-to take an airfield and fly troops in until a beachhead can be established. The better way for the Australian Navy to go would be to use the great advance it has in HMAS Tobruk, which provides a support facility for getting stores across a beach either by direct beach landings or in LCHs-that is, landing-craft (heavy)-and the smaller landing craft which can be loaded through the bow and the stern of the ship.

As for the evacuation of Australian nationals, the country often mentioned is New Guinea. Again, that is not a practical scenario. We will never get all Australian nationals at one point at one time. If we had to evacuate nationals out of New Guinea or any other Pacific island, such as Indonesia or anywhere like that, we would have to look at multiple pick-up points. We would need to have either multiple ships or multiple aircraft going into multiple airfields to get them out. I can see that it would be nice to have a carrier in some ways, but I do not believe there is an overwhelming priority for it in view of the great cost involved. We are talking about an involvement of around $1,500m, when everything is counted. It is not a matter of $200m or $300m-as the Navy likes to say-for a carrier.

I believe approval went through this chamber in this session for the spending of $1,000m on the funding for one of the three ships which are under review in America. Presumably that is an accurate estimate of what one ship would cost in the end-to which we have to add aircraft-and remember we are talking about the Sea Harriers, which are probably more expensive than the F18. A great deal of money would be involved. In addition to that we would need to have all the training and support facilities. A figure of at least $1,500m is the sum involved. We would have this great, expensive, vulnerable asset sitting out there which we could not use for much. Just by way of comparison, we can buy two squadrons of P3C Orions for $400m to $500m. For about one-third of the cost we could buy 24 Orion aircraft. Such aircraft have a far greater range and surveillance power in anti-submarine warfare. Moreover, with four Harpoons each, they have a far greater offensive power than a carrier and its embarked aircraft would have.

What Australia needs is a balanced force structure for the Army, Navy and Air Force. Also, it needs a balance of all three arms. We cannot have the Navy fighting the battles of Midway and the mid-Atlantic all over again. They passed us by 40 years ago and technology has proceeded enormously since. One does not get the idea at all that senior people in the Navy realise the great changes that have taken place in technology and modern weapons systems. They have not appreciated the way in which submarines, when coupled with smaller surface ships, would provide most of the defence capacity that Australia needs. A diesel-electric submarine, with its crew of 60 to 65, as opposed to a carrier with its crew of 1,000, represents a far more cost-efective way to go. When you add to that the fact that a submarine is virtually undetectable-I do not believe that the submarines which took part in the recent Kangaroo 81 exercises were detected by any of the Services at any time-you realise the attractiveness of alternative systems to the big ship syndrome from which the Navy is suffering.

I turn now to the second part of my discussion and relate it specifically to the rumours concerning the purchase of a British ship, whether it be the Invincible, the first one of the class built, or the Ark Royal, which was launched the other day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. I raise the question of Senator MacGibbon abusing the normal courtesies of the adjournment by making a full-blown speech on defence. The adjournment is normally understood to be an occasion when senators can raise with Ministers matters of concern which, quite often, relate to their electorates. To test the patience of honourable senators at the end of a long session in this way, by making a full-blown speech on defence, is going beyond the normal civilities of the Senate.
—There is no point of order.

—To take up Senator Tate's point, the subject I am discussing is a matter of considerable concern to most people in my electorate. Maybe it does not matter in Tasmania. The point of concern to most of us in relation to the rumours that the British ship is now being considered is the position that the Navy adopted right up to recent times-that it would not consider any of the British ships in any way. Now its former rejection has apparently turned to acceptance, based purely on the fact that the ship may be available more cheaply than was initially thought. There are very grave problems in the Royal Australian Navy buying a ship of this type. For many years, ever since the purchase of the DDGs, the Royal Australian Navy has adopted United States equipment as the standard for its ships. Ships are very complex. They have in them a lot of equipment, and great cost is involved in maintaining a spares inventory for them. One of the great advantages of the FFGs, the buying of which we are now embarked upon, is the fact that they are one-design and will give us considerable savings in our support equipment holdings. The British ship comes with an entirely alien equipment fit. The power units are Bristol or Rolls Royce marine turbo-jet engines which are not used in any ship of the Australian Navy. Incidentally, they are very old engines and have no commonality at all with anything that Australia has. The electrical services are all British. The weapons sensors, armaments and missiles are all British and most significantly the communications system, which is very important to a capital ship, would require considerable modification to produce a degree of commonality with the communications systems that we have on all our ships, and on all our proposed ships, in the Australian fleet. The net effect of all of this is that the operational cost of the ship and the modifications inherent in raising it to the level of compatibility that we would want it to have with other ships in the Australian fleet would be considerably greater than the purchase price. (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.PARA: Now that we have an audience for Senator Grimes, I will deal with the characteristics of this British ship. It is basically an anti-submarine warfare ship built for the North Sea. It embarks only five Harriers, although it would take 20 at a pinch. But that would mean that about 12 of them would have to be stored permanently on deck because the underdeck accommodation out of the weather is not available. It has only a six degrees ski jump on the front of it, which means that in the high ambient temperatures in which it would be operating in the tropics there would be a limitation in the all-up weights that we could put on those aircraft. Most importantly, it has a range of only 5,000 nautical miles at 18 knots, which is less than the Melbourne and only half that of the LPH, which was one of the ships from the United States Navy being considered for the Royal Australian Navy. Incidentally, the RAN's specification was for a range of 10,000 nautical miles at 18 knots.

By all accounts the ship has been plagued by mechanical problems. It is rather interesting that it was commissioned on 11 June 1980, last year, and was worked up to full operational standard only in June 1981. However, the British Navy is very keen to get out of it as fast as it can. The cost rumoured for this ship is $320m or about #stg200m. Since the British paid #stg184m, according to their parliamentary estimates, it is hardly a cheap ship for us to buy on those grounds.

I want to deal with the position of the Department of Defence and the Navy in relation to this projected purpose. We have just been through the whole exercise of the new tactical fighter. The need for that was justified. The specification was written, the evaluation teams were appointed and an exhaustive and impartial examination was made of the contenders, extending over nearly 10 years. We came to the point where a decision was deferred nearly 12 months ago. Finally the announcement was made last month. But at every point in that investigation, the Air Force, the Department of Defence and the Government could substantiate what they were doing in public. No justification for the need for the carrier has ever been established in public. We went to the level of reviewing designs and at that initial review point the British design was rejected. We then went into an investigation or a feasibility study last year of three ships-the LPH Iwo Jima class, the Sea Control ship and the Garibaldi class. Now we have jumped away from those we were reviewing and we are apparently going to look at a British ship. Last year's Auditor-General's report showed that we expended $7.27m in 1980-81 on the evaluation of those three ships alone and a budget was approved of $8.6m-odd for the evaluation of the three ships I have already mentioned. To throw that away and buy a ship-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Tate

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator MacGibbon is not only in a general way abusing the patience and the usual courtesies of this chamber by giving a long speech on defence issues tonight during the adjournment debate but also in specific terms he is offending Standing Order 406 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Senator shall read his speech.
I ask you to ask him to tear up his notes and to finish for the evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw Senator MacGibbon's attention to the fact that senators are able to use copious notes but that they should not read their speeches.
—Mr President, I assure you that I am not reading my speech. I have notes because I have a penchant for accuracy, although it is probably wasted on Senator Tate.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, there is no need at all for haste in this decision of whether to buy a carrier. If the decision is correct then it must be justified. If an argument is valid in private then that same argument is valid in public. I emphasise that there is no need for haste in this decision at all. One thing is certain, and that is that the British cannot sell this ship to anyone else. If they do not sell it to the Australian Navy it will just be put into mothballs in Britain.

Finally, I wish to deal with the politics of it all. There is an increasing level of interest in defence in Australia. The interest is in having an appropriate defence capacity for this country's needs. We do not want to go back to fighting the last World War. The Navy has had a massive public relations campaign through the Navy League of Australia, through retired admirals and serving officers to sell the concept of a new carrier to Australia. I regret to say that it has failed because the great majority of people to whom I have spoken-I am interested in defence-volunteered the information that they think we should not buy a carrier. It is impossible for the Government to proceed in the face of this community rejection of the idea of a carrier. A case must be established for its need. A case must be established also that the most appropriate ship, if we are to buy one, is bought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this late stage of the night I will not take 27 minutes of the Senate's time. However, I remind the Senate that this is the second time this week that we have been subjected to a rather lengthy speech on defence by Senator MacGibbon. We have to look at the Standing Orders, which reflect the attitudes expressed in this Parliament, if the adjournment debate or any other debate is to operate in the manner in which it is anticipated it should.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise a matter tonight as a result of an attitude expressed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) during Question Time this morning. I express not only my surprise but also my disappointment at that attitude. It is the first time in my parliamentary career, which now spans in excess of seven years, that I have been the object of what could be considered to be a sexist attitude by a person who should certainly know better-a Minister of the Crown. I stress that it is little wonder that the cause of that half of the population of Australia which happens to be female is not being furthered by a government whose Ministers demonstrate attitudes such as this.

I remind honourable senators that I am speaking only because of the attitudes expressed by the Minister this morning and his refusal to endeavour to obtain information that I sought. I asked a series of questions without notice relating to the use of private hire cars by the Department of Trade and Resources. It is a matter of great concern to me and I am sure that it is a matter of great concern to other members of this Parliament. It certainly is a cause for concern by members of the community. Senator McLaren raised this matter quite recently and I have raised it on a number of occasions. When I insisted during Question Time by way of a supplementary question that it would take a phone call to the Department of Trade and Resources to obtain the information I required, the Minister then jumped to his feet and described me as being petulant. As I said, the connotations of that word are sexist-perhaps only by common usage; nevertheless, they are sexist. I cannot imagine the same Minister ever describing the attitude of a male colleague or, more particularly, a male outside this place as being petulant, because he would be bound to get a belt on the nose. I assure him that if he used the same word to describe the attitude of a female outside this place he would get a belt on the nose.

If the Minister is really aware of what goes on in this chamber, he would know that I never ask a question in this place unless I am genuinely looking for information. I think this has been demonstrated on a number of occasions and I have always found the Minister to be most obliging and even helpful in giving answers to questions. In fact on my desk tonight I have a two-page response to a question which I asked in June which the Minister has very kindly provided me with and for which I am extremely grateful. But let me give the Minister a piece of information that he may not be aware of and perhaps it will enlighten him a little as to why I feel so strongly about his attitude and the phraseology that he chose to use this morning. The Oxford English Dictionary defines 'petulant' in three ways. The first is 'forward or immodest in speech or behaviour; wanton, lascivious'. My question could not in any way be described as forward or immodest; nor could my behaviour-unless the Minister took exception to the fact that by way of a supplementary question I insisted that the information I sought could be available if he took the time to make a telephone call. In no way could my attitude be described as wanton or lascivious and I accept, without being told, that that was not the intention of the Minister. The second definition by the Oxford English Diction- ary is 'saucy, insolent or rude'. I maintain that my attitude was none of those unless, of course, the Minister felt that I was insolent or rude in suggesting that I was entitled to receive answers to questions and that he could have quite easily made a telephone call. The third definition by the Oxford English Dictionary is 'displaying peevish or pettish impatience and irritation, especially on slight occasion'. It could be said that I displayed some impatience or irritation when I asked my supplementary question but I would not and could not agree that it was especially on a slight occasion.

As I have said, on most occasions I have found the Minister to be most helpful and obliging in obtaining information. I am interested to know why he was so concerned at the questions that I raised this morning to the extent that he suggested that I should put them on the Notice Paper, knowing that if I did so I would not get a printed response in Hansard, the sort of response which is of interest to other people, until after 16 February next year. The use of non-government cars for government work is of great importance, as I have said. My question was asked because of my concern that Government departments are using private hire cars when Commonwealth cars are available. Because of my concern that Commonwealth drivers are being made to appear inefficient so that the Government can turn that area over to private enterprise and because of my concern that if hire cars are used and Commonwealth drivers are sitting around picking their noses because there is no other work for them then dual payments from the public purse are being made. I am given to understand that the standard rate for a private hire car in Canberra is $30 an hour but the two vehicles that I mentioned this morning are apparently-I say apparently because I am waiting for the Minister to tell me that the matters that I put before him this morning are not factual-on a special hire rate of $18 an hour each. That, of course, is part of the information that I wanted to get from the Minister.

I have never professed, nor would I ever profess, to be an economist but I can multiply a 40-hour week by $36 an hour-that is, two cars at $18 an hour, if that is the going rate. I come up with the extraordinary figure of $1,440 a week. Is the Minister now saying that the Senate is not entitled to ask whether this is happening? Is the Minister saying that the figure for a 40-hour week for two vehicles over a 52 week year would come to nearly $75,000 and we have no right to ask whether this is being done by one department? Of course we are entitled to ask, and of course we are entitled to get the response. If in fact the Department of Trade and Resources has on permanent hire two private hire cars and drivers at the rate of $18 per car per hour, then that amount of $75,000 would pay an awful lot of Commonwealth drivers' wages. I remind the Senate that already we have seen in the last four or five years a diminution in the number of Commonwealth drivers here in Canberra so that more and more work is being farmed out to private car hire operators.

My question also raised the issue of who owns the cars. I think we are entitled to know whether there is a permanent contractor who has these two cars. All of this is supposition because I cannot get a response from the Minister as to whether this is actually happening. But the information I have been given is that those two cars are part of a package deal with a private hire car owner in the Australian Capital Territory-that to get two other cars that he wanted he had to buy four. Having got those two extra cars and recognising that perhaps there was not sufficient work for two more private hire cars in Canberra he shopped around for a permanent client and got the Department of Trade and Resources. That is a question to which I am entitled to have a response.

Another question I raised was whether this was authorised by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) or the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony). I assert that this is very real information that we are entitled to have. It is not a privilege; it is a right that members of this Parliament can ask questions and get responses. The use of Commonwealth cars, as we all know, comes under the direction of the Minaster for Administrative Services. If in fact he has authorised this then I believe we are entitled to ask when the request was made, by whom it was made and when and if it was acceded to. As I said, we are noticing some strange things happening in regard to Commonwealth vehicles. We are seeing departments make bookings with private hire firms-this is government departments I am talking about-without ever establishing whether a Commonwealth car is available.

Let me tell honourable senators about an incident that occurred as recently as last Sunday afternoon when an overseas trade delegation arrived in Canberra. One would anticipate that an overseas trade delegation would be extended not only the courtesy but also the security of a Commonwealth car. The counter at Canberra Airport where the Commonwealth car drivers wait for their passengers was approached and the question was put about the four cars for the Department of Trade. The gentleman inquiring was informed that no Commonwealth cars had been booked. Surprise, surprise-within a matter of minutes four private hire cars arrived.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can be lucky, can't they?

—They can be extremely fortunate. It is interesting to note that they left Canberra yesterday, so for Sunday, Monday and Tuesday they had a private hire car when Commonwealth car drivers and Commonwealth cars were available. I am not raising queries in other senators' minds but I have a number of questions in my mind and I am entitled to the answers because it is becoming more and more obvious to me, as I am sure it is to other members of the Senate, that whoever is responsible for booking the cars for the Department of Trade and Resources goes straight to the private hire car firms and at no time establishes whether in fact a Commonwealth car is available.

SPEECH.PARA: One other very important aspect is that of security. If two cars are posted at the Department of Trade and Resources all day one presumes that they are there for the purpose of transporting documents and people from point A to point B. Are documents which may be considered not public rather than top secret being transported by private hire car firms across or around Canberra? Is this perhaps one of the explanations for the spate of leaked documents from a number of departments? Has that been considered by those departments which constantly use private hire car firms?

I have raised these questions in relation to the Department of Trade and Resources but I believe we are also entitled to know what other departments consistently use private hire cars without establishing whether in actual fact Commonwealth cars and drivers are available. We are all aware, I am sure, that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation never uses Commonwealth cars but uses taxis or private hire cars. I want to know just how many other departments do that. My point at this time-I informed the Minister this morning that more comprehensive questions would be placed on notice-is to establish just what the situation is with the Department of Trade and Resources. I am sure that government departments would be able to organise themselves in such a way that if they have documents going from point A to point B their travel officer could ring and find out whether a Commonwealth car is available. If one is not available then it would be up to the Commonwealth cars transport office-not to the departments themselves-to arrange a separate booking. May I suggest that perhaps there is a directive to travel officers, at least in the Department of Trade and Resources, that whenever transport is required private hire cars are to be used. I maintain that we should expect that a directive be issued by the Minister for Administrative Services to all departments that Commonwealth cars be fully utilised.

I took the liberty, and paid the courtesy, of advising the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs this morning that I intended to pursue this matter during the adjournment debate. I can only anticipate that, even given the lateness of the hour, he will have the information I requested at that time. If there is any further information which the Minister has available I will listen agog.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to be raising this matter at this hour but it is one which has been worrying me for nearly two years and it must be referred to the Senate at this time before it rises for the Christmas recess. It relates to the attempts by Mr Max Thorburn and other persons in the Mildura district to try to obtain a licence for a radio station under the name of Mildura News Group Pty Ltd. Negotiations with successive Ministers concerned with communications in that period have been frustrated and, I believe, do not reflect creditably on the Ministry and the way these matters are conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: The application by these persons is to establish a 250 watt low-powered commercial operation broadcasting daily from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. and servicing an area of 16 kilometres radius with a population of 26,000 people. The service would be in addition to an existing 2,000 watt station, 3MA, which serves a 100 kilometre radius with a population of 41,000. Good reason was shown why it was necessary to have an additional service. In America, such an area with such a population would have four commerical operations but in Australia there is only one radio station for 78,000 people. Rather than provide Mildura with additional radio through overlapping of high-powered stations, it was suggested that a low-powered additional station be established in Mildura. The details of this proposal are in the hands of the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair). They seem to me to be very sensible. They have the support of all three municipalities in the area. The Mildura Shire Council, the Mildura City Council and the Wentworth Shire Council have supported the proposal unanimously, as have the Mildura Chamber of Commerce and the Mildura Tourist Association. So the representatives of 38,000 people have pledged their support. There were no known objectors to the proposal at that time.

It has been the attempts ever since to get some action in regard to that matter which have been a cause of concern to them and to me. This matter was brought to my attention by a former mayor of Mildura. At various times I have made representations to the Ministers involved, first to Mr Staley and subsequently to Mr Sinclair. On 8 February 1980 I wrote to the then Minister for Post and Telecommunications, the Honourable A. A. Staley, M.P. I pointed out the details of this application, the problems that they were then having, and the strong local community concern and emphasis on the need for this station. I set out the reasons why it should be supported. I drew attention to the employment it would give to townspeople in the district and the support it had from the various municipalities. I said:

Given both the merit of the proposal and the wide support which it has I ask that consideration be given to granting an experimental licence to the Mildura News Group whose operation could be monitored by the Federal Government for, say, a period of three years.

It has a belief in the economic viability of this proposal, and that seemed to me to be a reasonable proposal. I wrote again to the Minister on 28 March. I had received a reply from him dated 26 March in which he acknowledged having received the proposal form Mr Max Thorburn. He said:

In circulating the proposal to the industry, I have stressed that no commitment to proceed further should be implied. Nevertheless, I feel there is some merit in the concept as outlined and have therefore, invited comment on both the principle involved and the detail of the proposal.

Some merit appears to have been accepted by the Department. So the matter proceeded. However, the application was subsequently refused in June 1980. It was rejected because of the hours of operation, in the first place, and because it was said it would run the existing operator broke. The first objection was easily cured by changed proposals from the persons who are concerned in this and who are men of experience in the commerical world. The second was, as they said, a matter of the viability of the operations in this district and that should have been referred to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and not be determined by the Department. The Mildura News Group pointed out to me in a letter in November of last year that Mr Staley had conceded this point before leaving office and had advised that it should go to the tribunal for ultimate decision and allocation of licence. It has never gone to the Tribunal. It has never been determined. Of course, the monopoly which exists in Mildura continues to this day.

I summarise the material and debate since that time. In November the proponents of the scheme made a statement about the supplementary licence system which was then favoured for the establishment of FM rural radio in areas where an AM station already existed. This is said in a letter dated 23 September 1980:

Under the proposed scheme, prosperous expanding radio markets such as Mildura, geographically and radio signal isolated, would be denied a fully independent FM operation. Mildura, for example, has been cited by the former Minister for Post and Telecommunications Mr Tony Staley as 'a very viable commerical radio market and believe that a second commerial outlet could be established under certain conditions'.
That, of course, has not happened. Many other matters raised in documents in support of that proposal are in the Minister's possession. Further, Mr Thorburn told me by letter that year:
Now further information is available and as the growth rate in Mildura has jumped 100 per cent in the past 12 months, new relevant information is available justifying further consideration.
In November of last year I wrote to the Minister again setting out the situation and advancing further arguments. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard my letter dated 28 November 1980.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
28th November, 1980 Mr. Max Thornburn,
Managing Director,
Mildura News Group Pty Ltd,
P.O. Box 101,
MILDURA ...VIC...3500
Dear Mr. Thornburn,
Re: Second Commercial Radio Station for City of Mildura

Further to my letter to you of the 12th November, 1980 I have had a further discussion with Mr. Kaye Gambetta in respect to this matter. In view of what I'm told I will certainly write to the Minister suggesting that the matter be reconsidered, and asking whether he would be prepared to receive a deputation. I will suggest that alternatively the application should be referred to the Tribunal for a decision.
Yours sincerely, Alan Missen Senator for Victoria

TALK.START.PARA: —I jump then to July of this year, when we find that the situation is no better. Mr Thornburn wrote to me and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, has again delayed any action on moving this project by calling for departmental reports.

While he did say he would accept a planning proposal from us at the end of May, there has been no action on the document because his department, so he claims, has not been able to establish priorities.

As we have previously informed the Department, because of no forward planning, it has come to the task of now deciding where stations should go in the FM mode. Obviously the system cannot possibly introduce 125 FM stations at once, in places where AM stations already exist.
There are only THREE centres in Australia where planning has been carried out for independent FM operations by private groups.
The letter goes on to state that one of those centres is Mildura. While I was overseas my office wrote to Mr Sinclair following receipt of this information. The letter stated, amongst other things:

While I understand that your Department accepted a planning proposal from the Group at the end of May, I am informed by Mr Thornburn that they have again delayed any action on moving this project by calling for further reports.

That seems to be the situation that has continued. It has also been a matter of passing the buck from one person to another. We had an acknowledgement from Mr Sinclair on 7 August in which it was stated that he had asked for this matter to be considered promptly and that he would write as soon as possible. But apparently this is the type of reply which Mr Thorburn has been receiving for some considerable time, and he finds this to be very unsatisfactory. I must say that following there has been a continual effort an pressure by the Mildura News group to try to get some satisfaction. Yet, in a letter to me the News Group refers to the following situation:

When asked about the 'spectrum' of FM broadcasting . . . the Minister says the Department will give him a report. Mr Tony Norris of the engineering division says it is not his problem. So does Keith Sandman of the same department. Mr Don Kelly of Broadcast and Planning says that it is not his and he does not know whose it is.
In a further comment in the letter to me, the News Group states:
Bluntly, we have a Minister who does not know enough about radio to know if what the Department says is plausible or not.

That is the view of some very indignant people. They have good cause to be quite unsatisfied with the way in which this matter has proceeded and the way in which it has not been referred to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. It is their belief that the existing owners of the monopoly in Mildura have altogether too much influence in this area. It is said-my discussion with Mr Thorburn indicated this-that the argument might be raised that the Group cannot do anything about the situation at the moment because the supplemental licences may be dependent upon the removal of television stations from the FM band. I am told that that is not so and that it would be possible to introduce a number of new stations at this stage.

It is important that persons who want to undertake new radio stations and who have the finances and the desire to create employment in this way should have that opportunity. It is apparently said that nothing can be done at the moment but that is not right. At least one or two FM stations-perhaps more-could be put on the band. But for all this time there has been constant delay, constant refusal to refer the matter to the Tribunal and an inability for people in this community to create new enterprises and to create competition where monopolies exist. I believe that this is a disgraceful situation and I urge the Minister to take action to get this matter before the Tribunal as early as possible so that these people will have justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must commence by thanking honourable senators who are here at this hour tonight for being here and listening to me. At the moment South Australia is entering a rather heated, emotional and distorted debate. It is a debate of lies, deceit and, as I have said, distortions in an endeavour to maintain the political skin of the State Liberal Government. The debate is centred about the proposal for a mining development at Roxby Downs. I would like to refer to one aspect of this campaign and discuss the performance of one particular person both in respect of this campaign and also generally in Australian business and political affairs. The person is Alan Carroll, who has quite often been used by the Australian Broadcasting Commission and has often been used as an independent business analyst. On the ABC news in South Australia on 29 September Mr Carroll said that Roxby Downs clearly does represent the biggest opportunity South Australia faces. In the news items of that day he went on to say that Roxby was unquestionably the centrepiece of a development approach to South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Carroll was introduced on that news service and on other Australian Broadcasting Commission radio and television services as a leading business analyst. In fact, as I said earlier, he has been used quite often. He regularly appears on the ABC programs AM, PM, Money Talk, and talk back and other current affairs slots. During 1979 and from 1 January 1980 to the end of 1980 he appeared 41 times on ABC radio and 27 times on ABC television. He has continued to appear on both ABC forums this year. When the ABC uses Mr Carroll it does not tell the whole story. Mr Carroll is not an independent analyst. It should be carefully explained that he is a man at the centre of an enormous amount of business wheeling and dealing and political manipulation in Australia. In fact, he is the director of Business International Asia Pacific Ltd, a subsidiary of the giant New York based firm, Business International Corporation, and he is also director, Australia and South East Asia, of Business International Corporation. This company is a service organisation for almost three-quarters of the world's transnational corporations. Many of those transnational corporations have great interests in Australia. They are crucially intertwined with the Australian economy in terms of both investment and employment.

Let me list some of the companies involved. There are companies based in Sydney which include General Electric, Mitsubishi, IBM, Union Carbide, Warner Lambert, Parke Davis, Goodyear, Pioneer Concrete, the Swiss Bank Corporation, Richardson Merrell and Wormald. The Melbourne based companies include ACI, Beatrice Foods, Chase Manhatten Bank, Conzinc Riotinto, Monsanto, Nicholas International, Sperry Rand, Hoechst, Billington ACI and Coopers and Lybrand. A brief profile of the participating firms with which Business International is involved, firms with over $4,000 billion in local assets, would show that the largest United States company, General Electric, the largest Japanese company, Mitsubishi, the largest British company, CRA, and the largest German company, Hoechst, are currently operating in Australia. It would also show that the four largest Australian multinational corporations in terms of income derived from their overseas operations are ACI, Pioneer Concrete, Wormald and Nicholas. It would show that the Japanese firm responsible for almost 33 per cent of the total trade flows between Australia and Japan is Mitsubishi and that two of the most influential foreign banks operating in Australia are the Swiss Bank and the Chase Manhatten Bank.

Allegations have been made about Mr Carroll in the past. They have concerned Mr Carroll's deep involvement in political events in Australia. He was reputed to be the driving force behind the organising of British and American financial houses which mobilised against the former Victorian Premier Hamer, a mobilisation which we all know led to the downfall of that man. Mr Carroll is also said to be deeply involved in the political destabilisation going on within the Federal Liberal Party-a move aimed at removing the present Prime Minister; a move with which we on this side of the chamber would not disagree. But Mr Carroll's political meddling is not confined to the right wing of politics. He has also tried to involve himself in Australian Labor Party affairs and in the trade union movement. In a supposedly secret speech to the American Chamber of Commerce in Australia in April this year he laid his scenario for the future of the Labor movement and the machinations of the Labor Party, both federal and State, as well as the political wing and the trade union wing. On the trade union front he actively called for the removal of Cliff Dolan. So when it comes to assessing the role of Mr Carroll one should see him as being intricately intertwined with vested political and business interests that have major concerns in the Australian economy. Just to show how serious Mr Carroll and his associates are about running countries and undermining democratic governments, I will quote from a Business International document which was released quite recently. It states:

International corporations possess a high proportion of the technology, the managerial talent and the private capital required for the solution of the economic and social problems of this planet. They can tackle development of the resources of the sea, economic development of poor countries, new housing everywhere, the protection of the human environment, the training of people for skilled managerial and technical work, and the creation of jobs for underprivileged people.

This quotation is from the Business International conference in Jamaica in 1971 which was attended by the presidents of 38 leading global companies. What the quote shows is that Business International has no respect for the democratic right of people to their own self-determination within their own communities and countries.

Let me turn once again to the South Australian situation. In the rash of speculation about an early election in South Australia, Mr Carroll bobbed up on the main Australian Broadcasting Commission news services in Adelaide. As I said, he was introduced as a 'leading business analyst'. He said that Roxby Downs was the biggest opportunity South Australia faced. What was not stated in all those news services was that Mr Carroll was a consultant for the Western Mining Corporation and BP Australia, the two giant firms exploiting the ores of Roxby Downs. In evidence of that statement, I turn to the report in the Adelaide News of 14 September 1980 in which the financial editor, Mr Frank Moore, said:
And Alan should know-he is a consultant to both partners in the amazingly rich uranium-copper-gold prospect, Western Mining Corporation and BP.

Mr President, the problems raised in this instance are not the direct ones of Mr Carroll trying to sell up a project but they are twofold and in both instances the public is the loser. For a start, we have this political interference in the community's affairs and interests. We also have a situation which has been defined time and time again in Government and parliamentary reports, that is, one in which a business analyst, a business commentator or a journalist comments on the activities of a company in which he or she has a direct or an indirect interest.

Let me turn very briefly to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange. In Part 1 of Volume 1 at page 205 of that report very much the same problem is identified. The report, in commenting on Australian Investments Counsellors Pty Ltd and Patrick Partners, said:

What is relevant is the fact that it was possible to act in two roles at the same time, that is, as a tipster and a share trader, and to use the combination of those roles for personal interest, while acting irresponsibly to the public.

The problem was raised there; it was identified there. It was a problem of financial interest conflicting with public interest. The Riordan Committee, the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament, which reported in 1975, also identified this problem. As a response to this problem the Committee advocated setting up a media council with a media register of pecuniary interests. It advocated a code of conduct on all media elements and all media programs. It also advocated an enforcement tribunal. The Riordan Committee in fact suggested that the general guardianship of the highest professional and commercial standards which would include the preservation of a free, varied and non-monopolistic media devoid of myopic and base propaganda should be the aim of the operations of such a body.
