So the problem has been recognised in the past. It has not in fact been recognised by this Government despite the two initiatives with which this Government has been involved. The Bowen report, from the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest in 1979, neglected all aspects of this problem. In fact, the Securities Industry Act of 1980 does not cover the position of business analysts. It may cover the position of journalists but not business analysts. The problem raised by Mr Carroll's intervention in South Australian politics is a very serious one. It is serious because it has the effect of aborting rational debate in that a person is portrayed as an independent business analyst but, at the same time, has a very vital financial interest in the business on which he is commentating.

The other problem that is raised by Mr Carroll's intervention is the continued problem of his use by the ABC. The problem has been raised in this place in the past by my colleague Senator Ryan and in another place by another one of my colleagues, the honourable member for Lalor, Mr Barry Jones. The point is that Mr Carroll should not continue to be used by the ABC and described as an independent business analyst. His continued use is nothing more than a manipulation of a very important information flow to the public and should cease.
Thursday, 26 November

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is very late and I will be as brief as I can. A number of honourable senators have taken the opportunity this evening to raise in the adjournment debate matters of general interest because at this stage of the session the opportunities of doing that are limited and patience gets worn a little thin. I will do my best not to weary my fellow senators any more than is necessary this evening. I want to take the opportunity before this session ends to raise a subject of concern; that is, whether Australia will host an international exposition in 1988. The Government has to come to a decision on this matter within the next few days. I will place on record for the benefit of honourable senators and others some of the factors that need to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: The present situation is that Australia has indicated-and indicated several years ago-that it would like to stage an international exposition in 1988 to coincide with Australia's bicentenary. The Bureau of International Expositions, which is headquartered in Paris, has been aware of this for some time and we have had a tentative bid to hold an international expo in Australia in 1988. This matter was raised with me as long ago as 1974 by a group of Brisbane businessmen and activists who were then putting forward a proposal that there be an international exposition in Brisbane in 1988 for the purposes of the bicentenary. With the passage of seven years the situation has developed past that; it developed to the stage where it appeared that Melbourne was to stage the international exposition if Australia in fact finally decided that it wanted it. I understand that feasibility studies were undertaken. These studies indicated something very favourable for Australia if Melbourne were to stage it. Subsequently the Government of Victoria decided that it did not want to be involved in staging an expo in 1988 and Sydney became the centre of attraction. I understand that a feasibility study was done in relation to Sydney. The outcome of that study was not altogether unfavourable. Due to certain happenings in New South Wales, it indicated that it would not go ahead with it. At that point the whole business went full circle and it then went back to Queensland.

The Queensland Government from the beginning has enthusiastically supported the concept of an international exposition in Australia to coinside with our bicentenary in 1988. It now says, just as enthusiastically, that it is prepared to be the host State. The basic situation is that the cost of mounting the exposition, as it has been discussed throughout with all the State governments I have mentioned, is that half the cost would be met by the Commonwealth Government and half by the host State government. The Queensland Government has indicated firmly and enthusiastically that it is prepared to undertake half the cost of staging an international exposition up to an upper limit of $200m in 1981 terms, which is the amount of money which was talked about when it was also discussed in relation to Sydney and Melbourne. For several years it looked as though, if Australia wanted the exposition in 1988, it was Australia's. That situation has changed. France has now entered a firm bid to host an international exposition in Paris-as I understand it, in 1988. Australia's bid is not firm. In early December of this year, just a few days away, there will be a meeting of the Bureau of International Expositions at which the city where Expo 88 will be staged will be finally determined. At that meeting the Commonwealth Government, as the national government, must say to the Bureau of International Expositions: 'Australia wants the expo in 1988 to coincide with our bicentenary'. If Australia does not say that at the meeting it will be lost to us forever and it will go to France.

I would like to play my part in urging the Government not to allow that to happen. World fairs are things that seem a little distant to Australians in general terms. That makes it a little more difficult to persuade people that it is very important that we make that a firm bid to the Bureau of International Expositions. Australia has not hosted a world fair for several years. In the nineteenth century we hosted three of them-in Sydney in 1879 and in Melbourne in 1880 and 1888, which coincided with our first centenary. We have not hosted one since, but we have been participating in them in recent years. We participated in twentieth century expositions in 1967, 1970, 1974 and 1975, so Australia is established as an exhibitor in international expositions. That certainly assists our bid.

What are the benefits of an international exposition? For those of us who have not actually witnessed one and been intimately involved, it is very difficult to envisage. But it does give a country a unique opportunity to display itself to the world. Countries are invited to participate and to mount part of the exposition. They are meant to be expositions of human achievement and, of course, countries take the opportunity to indicate particular things in relation to themselves. It is not, I emphasise, a trade fair. Nevertheless, it does give a country an opportunity to display to the world its achievements and aspirations. The host country, of course, is the country on which the main spotlight falls. We have not hosted an exposition for almost 100 years. We last hosted an exposition in 1888. But we have been an exhibitor. The time for being a host country again is well and truly due.

All things are favourable to us to be the host country. There are advantages to the citizens of the host country. They have the opportunity of seeing at first hand the achievements of their own country in a global context. They can see the advances we have made in areas of technology and in society and they can compare them with the bright ideas that come from other countries that exhibit. They give us the stimulus to look ahead. No year could be more appropriate for this than our bicentenary year. It would have a very particular meaning to our very large population of recent migrant origin. The very large proportion of our population which is first generation recent arrival migrants or refugees would have the opportunity to look at what their own country is achieving and to be proud in their new country of part of their heritage. It would give us the opportunity to understand even better that heritage.

There are specific material benefits relating to an international exposition. Local industries, businesses, motels and, of course, the travel industry benefit. During the construction phase there is a huge boom. Permanent facilities remain in the host country and have benefit to the country for ever. The economy receives a very direct and major stimulus at the time of the staging of the exposition. World attention is focused, in particular, on the host city and the host State with all that that means to them. I say unashamedly as a Senator for Queensland that I hope very much that Expo 88 will be held in Brisbane. It would be very appropriate if it were to be held in Brisbane. Queensland is now Australia's number one tourist State in terms of both domestic tourism and growth of international tourism. The Commonwealth Government has committed itself to and is proceeding with the construction of a fully international standard airport.

One of the facilities that must be provided in the staging of an international exposition is a convention centre of international standard. Australia does not have a convention centre of international standard. This would be the fillip that would give us that facility and put us on the map for that form of international tourism, which is probably the most significant in terms of single sectors of types of international tourism. All of that would ultimately benefit Australia. The facilities would be permanent. The benefits to Australia would be permanent. There would be specific benefits, of course, for Queensland. But, I repeat, the basis of staging the exposition is that the host State government pays half the costs. It would be, in that sense, earning the permanent facilities. As I understand it, the benefits that would flow during the staging of the exposition would be not only to the host city or State. The types of activities and the things that would come to the exposition would be spread ultimately throughout Australia so that all States and all major cities would have the benefit of seeing at first hand significant parts of the exposition. A good number of Australians would travel to Brisbane if it hosted that international exposition. Even those who did not travel would have brought close to them some of the interesting aspects of the exposition and would be able to participate in and benefit from them.

It is a very exciting concept. It is appropriate that we should be thinking in those terms for our bicentenary year. We should take a bold step and put ourselves on the world stage in that way. We should show people that it is our bicentenary and, in a very special way as an international happening, show what has been achieved in this country in 200 years and what we hope for in the future. If we do not host that exposition I suggest respectfully, Mr President, that Australia's bicentenary in 1988 will be, in international terms, a non-event. That year South Korea will host the Olympic Games. If it happens that coincidentally the other major international event, the international Expo, is held in France, Australia's bicentenary will have very little attraction in competition with those two events. To stage the exposition would bring to world attention the fact that it is our bicentenary. We have much to be proud of. I hope that the Government will take what is a bold step.

The down side of the proposal is, I suppose, the fact that in current terms it is estimated that it would cost $200m. We are talking about that sort of expenditure over the next seven years. In the current economic climate I can understand that the Government would feel some small hesitancy about committing itself to a sum of that size. I emphasise, however, that the Queensland Government has committed itself to half the cost. In those circumstances one would hope that the national Government would have the same sort of courage to commit itself to half the cost spread over a period of years. The benefits, financial and otherwise, would come back many times over. I do not have available to me the content of the feasibility studies that were done in relation to Melbourne and Sydney but I am informed by those who have seen them that they show that the cost of staging the exposition would be more than met by the benefits that would come in the time that the exposition was being staged.

I reiterate that it is necessary that Australia make what might appear in current terms to be a bold move. It is a move that would do us credit as a nation of the future. It would demonstrate some of the pride that we have in ourselves as a nation and the aspirations that we have for the future. Australia aspires to be a world leader. I think we can be proud of many of the things that we have done. I very much hope that our Government will, in the next few days, show the sort of moral, if not political, courage which is necessary in the short term to make that decision. I emphasise that if the decision is not made in the next few days the exposition will be lost to us forever. That would be a very great pity, not just because 1988 is our bicentenary but because it is time we gathered ourselves together and put ourselves on the world stage given that it is 100 years since we have had that sort of courage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The adjournment debate has taken one and a quarter hours. I think that five senators have contributed to the debate. My aviator colleague Senator MacGibbon addressed us first on matters of aircraft carriers. I am sure that at least a number of senators will feel better informed in their understanding of the strategic options facing Australia and the machinations of retired admirals. I will undertake to make sure that Senator MacGibbon's comments are brought to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). I doubt whether there is much else I can say to address the particular matter he raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen raised the question of Mr Thornburn in Mildura. Of course, Mildura is of interest to those New South Wales senators who are interested in the reception of radio and television across the other side of that body of water which separates New South Wales from Victoria. I also have had contact with Mr Thornburn in Mildura and have been aware of his problem for some time. Senator Missen set out a sequence of events which he considers to be unsatisfactory and has indicated his concern that there is a continuing unresolved problem. It is appropriate that that be referred to the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) for response. I doubt whether there is much else I can do tonight except to undertake to pass on that matter on Senator Missen's behalf.

As Senator Coleman raised substantial matters I will leave my reply to her comments to the end. Senator Bolkus in his interesting and partly read address made some comments about a Mr Alan Carroll on an ex parte basis. Many contributions in the Senate on the adjournment are on an ex parte basis. That does not mean they are incorrect but it means that one has to remember that there may be another side to the story and one has to take them on that basis. I do not know whether I agree that all practitioners in any field should be disqualified from commenting. I think it is important that people know who is addressing them. If Senator Bolkus was seeking to have certain people disqualify themselves from public comment on certain matters I hope that he was seeking to do so in a broad and even-handed way. I think he was stating certain matters which do not require ministerial consideration at the Federal level. I have noted what he had to say.

My colleague Senator Martin commented about an exposition in 1988. Again as a senator from New South Wales I am aware that in 1788 an event occurred not on the banks of the Brisbane River but at Sydney Cove. If we are going for panem et circenses and looking for circuses for 1988, as a New South Wales senator expressing a preference, I would like to see them in New South Wales. Having said that, I think Senator Martin is quite correct. There are a number of propositions before government in relation to 1988 and if, as she says, there is a proposition in relation to an expo in Brisbane and if in fact it requires a decision by government that is a decision which has to be taken by government. It is not proper for me to anticipate that decision or to say anything of substance in response to the matter she raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are too shy.
—I think that is an appropriate and proper response.
—Why don't you tell her that Brisbane was much later than that?

—I think I have already told Senator Martin that the events of 1788 took place on the edge of Sydney Cove in a most beautiful part of Australia which will be the focus of our celebrations in a few years' time.

SPEECH.PARA: I now come to Senator Coleman's contribution. It contained some matters of detail to which I have some answers. I am glad she looked up the dictionary meaning of the word 'petulant'. The third meaning she quoted is the sense in which I used the word. That she considered it sexist is something that surprises me. I cannot see how that could have been. I will be happy to discuss with her later how I could possibly have been sexist in using that word. It is a word I think I might use in relation to anyone who spoke the same way. Knowing that the honourable senator asked some questions this morning and that she was keen and quite concerned that some information should be given tonight, I have in fact tried to locate some information on the matters she raised. In fact it seems that in raising the matters of concern she has probably drawn the incorrect conclusions or has been given incorrect information, probably on all of them. I will give her the information I have. Senator Coleman may wish to test that and to take the matter further. I have spoken to people in the office of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and they in fact have been in touch with the Department of Trade and Resources. The Minister for Administrative Services has supplied answers to the questions asked by Senator Coleman. Senator Coleman's first question was:

Is it a fact that two private hire cars and drivers are stationed at the Department of Trade and Resources all day each working day in case the Department has a need to transport persons or documents to other departments?

The answer I have been provided with is that the Department of Trade and Resources has advised the Department of Administrative Services that it only hires vehicles through the Department of Administrative Services. There are no private hire cars allocated on a continuing basis to the Department of Trade and Resources by DAS in Canberra. Apart from casual car pool car-with-driver hirings, and for which a Commonwealth car, a hire car or a taxi may be provided, there are only a few vehicles which the Department of Trade and Resources has on permanent hire without driver which are provided to the Department of Trade and Resources in Canberra. I have been told that they are the only vehicles-the word 'only' was emphasised-on hire to the Department of Trade and Resources in Canberra. Those vehicles constitute two Datsun 200B sedans, two Datsun 200B station sedans-I have the licence numbers but I am sure the honourable senator does not want them-two Toyota Corolla sedans, all fairly small cars, plus two Holden utilities and a Toyota panel van. That, for a large department, is not a large number of vehicles. The second question asked by the honourable senator was:
Is it a fact that those two cars at the moment carry New South Wales number plates?

Both that question and the honourable senator's third question are irrelevant in view of the answer I have just given. I was offered some additional comments, which I now make available to the Senate. I am advised that the Department of Trade and Resources is accommodated within the Edmund Barton Building in Canberra and that several other departments also occupy that building. Therefore, the presence of vehicles outside the building may not necessarily have any relationship to the Department of Trade and Resources. The Department of Administrative Services has not arranged the allocation of any private hire cars to those other departments on a continuing basis. That covers the second matter.

The office of the Minister for Administrative Services has advised me also that it is not familiar with the details of any privately owned vehicles which might regularly park in the vicinity of the Edmund Barton Building and which might not in fact be on hire to anyone. I have been advised by the Minister, whom I represent, that two luxury sedans with New South Wales registration plates were parked outside the Edmund Barton Building today. Those vehicles were not hired by the Department of Administrative Services for allocation to any Commonwealth department or Commonwealth authority; nor were they hired by the Department of Trade and Resources. I must say to the honourable senator that, in the light of that information, there is no basis for the concern she has expressed. The vehicles were not hired-

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree. Would it not have been much easier if you had offered to provide me with any information this morning? Had that happened we would not have had this hassle tonight.

—I asked the honourable senator to put her questions on notice so that I could get the information for her. There is no other purpose in having questions put on notice. That is the way to get the information required. I emphasise that the information shows that the matters which Senator Coleman has been raising and which she emphasised tonight are without foundation. In fact, there is no problem of the kind she has ascertained. There are no vehicles on hire to the Department of Trade and Resources. In fact, the whole matter is a furphy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senate adjourned at 12.29 a.m.
